(64,65) The articular pillar is formed by the superior and inferior articular processes, which fuse to form a rhomboidal-shaped structure. Articular pillars are best demonstrated by specific pillar views or on bone window CT images. (66)
Pillar fractures most commonly occur at C4-C7, with C6 representing the site of approximately 40% of cases. (23) The most common form of pillar fracture is the compression type. Most articular pillar fractures are caused by automobile accidents owing to combined compressive hyperextension and lateral flexion of the cervical spine. During hyperextension, the anterior soft tissues of the spine may also be injured. Esophageal perforation has occurred in association with cervical facet fracture. (67)
Articular pillar fractures exhibit an altered shape with loss of vertical height being the most common change. There can be associated anterolisthesis of the segment. (65,68) (Fig. 9-43) It is important to note that congenital developmental asymmetry and flattening of the articular pillars is common. (69) On routine frontal radiographs a fractured pillar can manifest as a recognizable joint space owing to rotation of the pillar (horizontal facet sign). (46) Bone scan can be helpful in the detection of occult lateral mass fracture.
Clay Shoveler’s Fracture
Clay shoveler’s fracture (coal-miner’s or root-puller’s fracture) is an avulsive injury of the spinous process. The injury derives
P.822

its name from its common occurrence in clay miners in Australia during the 1930s. (70) It results from abrupt flexion of the head, such as is found in automobile accidents, diving, or wrestling injuries or from repeated stress (71) caused by the pull of the trapezius and rhomboid muscles on the spinous process. The spinous avulsion most commonly occurs at C7, with C6 and T1 also frequently involved. (72) It may also be caused by a direct blow to the base of the neck. This is a stable fracture without neurological deficit.
Figure 9-43 PILLAR FRACTURE. A. Lateral Cervical Spine, Associated Dislocation. Note the significant decrease in the vertical height of the articular pillar of C6, along with an increase in density of the compressed articular pillar, which is characteristic of a pillar fracture (arrows). A fracture through the pedicle can be seen (arrowhead), and dislocation of the C6 vertebral body has occurred. B. Compression Fracture, Pillar View. In a different patient, observe the notable loss of height in the C7 articular pillar (arrow). (Courtesy of Thomas M. Goodrich, DC, DACBR, Indianapolis, Indiana.)
Figure 9-44 CLAY SHOVELER’S FRACTURE. A. Acute Fracture, Lateral Cervical Spine. Note the avulsion fracture of the spinous process of C7 with inferior displacement of the distal fragment (arrow). Observe the fracture line, which is irregular and exhibits no sclerosis. B. CT Scan, Acute Fracture. Observe the sites of fracture at the base of the spinous process (arrows). C. Old Fracture. Note the presence of smooth and sclerotic opposing margins, indicating an old clay shoveler’s fracture. (Panel B courtesy of Steven P. Brownstein, MD, Springfield, New Jersey. Panel C courtesy of Peter Christensson, DC, Rome, Italy.)
P.823

Figure 9-45 DOUBLE SPINOUS PROCESS SIGN: CLAY SHOVELER’S FRACTURE. Observe the two spinous process shadows at the T1 segment, the first of which shows the intact base of the spinous process (arrow). The second shadow is the caudally displaced distal fragment (arrowhead). (Courtesy of Lawrence C. Pyzik, DC, DACBR, Chicago, Illinois.)
On the lateral projection an oblique radiolucent fracture line through the base of the spinous process or distal tip may be visible. (Fig. 9-44) Its margins are rough and serrated, a helpful roentgen sign to differentiate non-union of the secondary growth center for the spinous process or a nuchal bone. (73) The distal portion of the spinous process that is fractured is often displaced caudally, a sign not seen with non-union.
The frontal radiograph demonstrates the apparent presence of two spinous processes for a single vertebra, which is called the double spinous process sign. (74) (Fig. 9-45) This is especially useful when the cervicothoracic junction is poorly visualized on lateral radiographs and may be the only sign present.
Lamina and Transverse Process Fractures
Laminar fractures occur in the middle to lower cervical spine, with C5 and C6 being the most common sites. (75) While difficult to see on standard views, they are readily depicted on CT images. (Fig. 9-46) Transverse process fractures are decidedly rare, with C7 the
P.824

most exposed protuberance. Severe trauma with lateral flexion is necessary, and, as such, these often coexist with other cervical fractures and brachial plexus lesions. (Fig. 9-47) The fracture line tends to localize near its junction with the pedicle and, if in continuity with the transverse foramen, may produce vertebral artery injury.
Figure 9-46 VERTEBRAL BODY AND ASSOCIATED NEURAL ARCH FRACTURE. A. Lateral Cervical Spine, C7 Fracture. Note the anterior compression fracture with a step defect at the anterosuperior corner of the body of C7 (arrow). B. CT, C7 Fracture. Note that the fracture line extends through the vertebral body, pedicle, and base of the transverse process (arrows). The extension into the posterior arch could not be appreciated on the plain film radiographs. (Courtesy of Reed B. Phillips, DC, DACBR, PhD, Los Angeles, California.)
Figure 9-47 TRANSVERSE PROCESS FRACTURES OF C7 AND T1. A. AP View. Note the small avulsion fracture at the tip of the C7 transverse process (arrow), along with an oblique transverse process fracture of T1 (arrowhead). In addition, observe the fracture with malalignment of the middle third of the clavicle. B. Nerve Root Avulsion. Note the myelogram demonstrates an outpouching of the dural sleeve owing to avulsion of the T1 nerve root (arrow). COMMENT: Transverse process fractures in the cervical spine are infrequent and often are markers of brachial plexus injury.
Whiplash Syndrome
The so-called whiplash syndrome is a common clinical condition that has received a high volume of published material since the 1960s, much of which—when scrutinized scientifically for validity—is found flawed. (76) Neck sprains are common in all Western countries and are reported in 20-60% of all motor vehicle accidents. (77,78) Classically, the injury follows a forced hyperextension-hyperflexion of the cervical spine, most commonly associated with a rear-end motor vehicle collision. The lay press and legal profession have popularized the term whiplash as an all-embracing term for a wide variety of soft tissue neck injuries from a broad spectrum of causes. Synonyms are numerous including acceleration-deceleration, flexion-extension, hyperflexion-hyperextension, sprain-strain, myofascial injury, and soft tissue injury. There is no consensus on terminology, though the most contemporary and appropriate term appears to be cervical sprain-strain injury.
A wide variety of presentations is found, ranging from relatively minor complaints to severe incapacitation. Pain in the posterior neck is a cardinal manifestation, and that may be either dull and aching with exacerbation on movement, sharp related to movement, or a combination of the two. (76) Pain may also radiate to the head, shoulder, arm, or interscapular region. Associated stiffness of the neck is common. As many as 85% of these patients may have as their pain source the cervical facet joints. (79,80,81) Palpation and assessment of joint characteristics can accurately isolate the involved painful joints. (82,83) Other common complaints include headache, visual disturbances, memory impairment, and dizziness. (76) Current research advocates the use of rehabilitative procedures with limited rest and immobilization during the treatment of acute whiplash injuries. (84)
Imaging of whiplash injuries is limited to or is dominated by soft tissue rather than osseous abnormalities. Exclusion of fractures and dislocations is a first priority, though frequently unrewarding. Identification of soft tissue injury is often difficult and inherently limited by the technical restraints of the imaging modality employed. A number of soft tissue imaging findings have been described. (Table 9-9)
Conventional Imaging.
The standard post-traumatic plain film radiographic series consists of a minimum of frontal, lateral, and oblique projections. (46,85,86) The most important view is the lateral, which is positive in 70-90% of cases. (86) Because certain fractures and intersegmental instabilities may not be demonstrated on this survey, clinical consideration should be given to employing the use of flexion-extension studies, once
P.825

the initial frontal and lateral studies have been scrutinized for contraindications (Davis series). (87) A key rule in post-traumatic radiography of the neck is “to see all seven.” Especially on the lateral projection, the C1-C7 segments should be adequately imaged because serious lesions at each caudad and cephalad extreme may be overlooked.
Table 9-9 Soft Tissue Imaging Findings in Whiplash Injuries

Conventional imaging

Abnormal soft tissues

Widened retropharyngeal space

Widened retrotracheal space

Displacement of prevertebral fat stripe

Tracheal deviation and laryngeal dislocation

Soft tissue emphysema

Abnormal vertebral alignment

Loss of the lordosis

Acute kyphotic angulation

Widened interspinous space

Altered flexion patterns

Vertebral body rotation

Sagittal translation

Torticollis

Abnormal joints

Widened median atlantoaxial joint (ADI)

Widened or narrowed intervertebral disc

Displaced ring epiphysis

Widening of the zygapophyseal joint

CT

Herniated intervertebral disc

MRI

Discovertebral endplate separations

Anterior longitudinal ligament injuries

Occult endplate fractures

Disc herniation

Cord contusion

Prevertebral edema or hematoma

Nuclear bone scan

Occult fractures

Negative for postinjury inflammatory facet joint

Diagnostic nerve blocks

Facet syndrome

Discography

Internal disc disruption

Pain provocation

ADI, atlantodental interspace.
Figure 9-48 POST-TRAUMATIC RETROPHARYNGEAL HEMORRHAGE. A. Lateral Cervical Spine. Note the abnormally increased retropharyngeal interspace from C2 to C4, which occurred in the absence of fracture after a whiplash injury (arrows). B. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Observe the bright signal intensity of post-traumatic hemorrhage anterior to the C2, C3, C4, and C5 vertebral bodies. This hemorrhage has occurred as a result of a whiplash injury to the cervical spine. (Panel A courtesy of Norman W. Kettner, DC, DACBR, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Three key areas for review for evidence of extraosseous injury are the soft tissues, vertebral alignment, and joints. (88)
Abnormal Soft Tissues.
Perusal of the paravertebral soft tissues should include the prevertebral spaces (retropharyngeal, retrotracheal) and trachea. As many as 20% of motor vehicle accident patients presenting to an emergency department may have prevertebral swelling. (89)
  • Widened retropharyngeal space. The tissue immediately anterior to the anteroinferior aspect of the C2 body should not exceed 6 mm in children or adults. (88,90) Hematoma or edema within the longus colli, torn anterior longitudinal ligament, or torn discovertebral junction will manifest as a widening of this soft tissue landmark. (88,91) (Fig. 9-48)
  • Widened retrotracheal space. The tissue immediately anterior to the anteroinferior aspect of the C6 body should not exceed 14 mm in children or 22 mm in adults. (88,91) Hematoma or edema within the esophagus, longus colli, anterior longitudinal ligament, or discovertebral junction will manifest as a widening of this soft tissue landmark. (88,91)
  • Displacement of the prevertebral fat stripe. A thin radiolucent vertical linear shadow corresponding to fatty areolar tissue is frequently observed adjacent to the anterior aspects of the C6-C7 bodies. (92) Hematoma or edema from tears within the longus colli, scalenes, anterior longitudinal ligament, or discovertebral junction will manifest as a widening of this soft tissue landmark. (88) Compression and subtle endplate fractures will also displace the prevertebral fat stripe.
    • P.826

  • Tracheal deviation and laryngeal dislocation. Lateral or anterior tracheal displacement after injury may be the result of hematoma or torticollis. Elevation of the hyoid bone above the plane of the superior endplate of C3 is found in tracheal transection. (93)
  • Soft tissue emphysema. Gas within the neck’s soft tissues indicates either tracheal laceration or transection, pneumomediastinum, or pneumothorax. (93) Epidural pneumatosis (pneumorachis, air in the spinal canal) may accompany these air-escaping injuries. (94)
Abnormal Vertebral Alignment.
Spatial relationships should be carefully assessed using various lines and angles.
  • Loss of the lordosis. This is the most commonly observed finding on post-whiplash radiographs. (88) The significance of a lordosis or hypolordosis, however, remains controversial and on its own cannot be construed to be a strong indicator of underlying soft tissue injury. (89) Traditionally the clinical implication of a reduced lordosis has been that it is secondary to muscle spasm. (88) Reduction of the lordosis is readily reproduced with degenerative disc disease, a small degree of head nodding, or if the exposure is made while recumbent. (88,95,96,97,98) (Fig. 9-49)
    Figure 9-49 LOSS OF THE CERVICAL LORDOSIS. Note the loss of the cervical lordosis. Observe the degenerative disc disease at C5 at the apex of the kyphosis (arrow). COMMENT: Altered cervical patterns of lordosis may occur as a result of patient positioning, muscle spasm, or posterior ligamentous injury. An arcual kyphosis is often associated with muscle spasm, whereas the acute cervical kyphosis sign indicates localized intersegmental posterior ligamentous damage.
  • Acute kyphotic angulation. At a single level an abrupt angular change in the configuration of the cervical curve (acute kyphosis sign) with two adjacent spinous processes widely separated (divergent spinous process sign) is suggestive of disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex. (88,99,100) The C5 and C6 segments are the most common levels of involvement. This deformity can be exaggerated in the flexion view and is always associated with significant facet subluxation almost to the point of dislocation. (Fig. 9-50) The widened interspinous space can be appreciated on frontal radiographs. The incidence of disc degeneration at this level 5 years later may be higher. (100) If found in combination with an absence of cord injury, it requires no special treatment. (89)
  • Widened interspinous space. A generalized multisegmental uniform widening of the interspinous space (fanning) usually co-exists with a comparable reversal of the cervical curve (arcual kyphosis). (Fig. 9-50) At a single level (divergent spinous process sign) this may denote significant posterior ligamentous injury and is readily recognized by an abrupt transition to kyphosis (acute kyphosis sign). (72,85) This is identifiable by the interspinous space being wider by > 2 mm compared to other levels. Developmental variation of the spinous processes can simulate ligamentous disruption. (Fig. 9-51)
  • Altered flexion patterns. Four patterns of cervical flexion have been described in studies obtained shortly after trauma. (101) No intersegmental motion is seen in up to 25% of cases, only at one level in 25%, at two levels in 30%, and at three or more in 20%. No movement or movement at only one level most closely correlates with the presence of soft tissue injury. Three or more levels of motion is a normal pattern.
  • Vertebral body rotation. Rotatory deformities can be subtle but important as they can accompany serious facet subluxation or even dislocation. These may be considered to occur in three planes but typically occur as combinations.
Sagittal Rotations (Flexion-Extension).
Greater than 11.5° of intersegmental angular incongruence constitutes evidence for significant ligamentous injury. (102,103,104)
Coronal Rotations (Lateral Flexion).
Divergence of adjacent endplates may indicate facet instability with disruption of the joint capsule or even unilateral facet dislocation.
Axial Rotations (Rotatory).
At middle and lower levels evidence for intersegmental rotation can be established by displacement of the spinous processes from the midline. (88) On the lateral film the articular pillars on the side of anterior rotation will lie superimposed over the vertebral bodies. In addition, the posterior borders of these pillars will be duplicated. Axial rotation may be a result of torticollis or artifactual rotation of the head, or it may be the first indication of a unilateral subluxation or even dislocation of a cervical facet joint. Rotatory subluxation of the atlantoaxial joint is often traumatically induced.
  • Sagittal translation. On the lateral study four lines (cervical arc lines) are used. (86) These lines connect the
    P.827

    anterior body margins, posterior body margins, spinolaminar junctions, and tips of the spinous processes and serve as useful visual inspection landmarks for identifying AP displacements. Such displacements are best demonstrated on flexion-extension studies. Greater than a total of 3.5 mm intersegmental excursion identifies clinically significant intersegmental instability. (103) (Fig. 9-52)
    Figure 9-50 ARCUAL KYPHOSIS WITH C3-C4 AND C4-C5 INSTABILITY. A. Neutral Lateral Cervical Spine. Note the marked reversal of the cervical lordosis. Localized widening of the C3-C4 interspinous space is apparent (divergent spinous process sign). B. Extension, Lateral Cervical Spine. Observe that the curvature remains fixed with only slight extension of the atlas on the axis. C. Flexion, Lateral Cervical Spine. Note that at C3-C4 there is anterior translation and increased angular divergence between the segments. At C4-C5 less pronounced but similar changes are apparent. Observe the distinct lack of intersegmental mobility from C5 to C7. COMMENT: This configuration of cervical curve reversal and isolated intersegmental increased motion patterns may provide some objective evidence for ligamentous injury. Care must be taken, however, to correlate the findings with the clinical history and presentation because such radiographic findings can be found in the absence of significant trauma. (Courtesy of W. Michael Spurlock, DC, Moorehead, Kentucky.)
    P.828

    Figure 9-51 PSEUDO-DIVERGENT SPINOUS PROCESS SIGN, C7-T1. A. Flexion, Lateral Cervical Spine. Note the interspinous process distance appears significantly increased between C7 and T1 (arrows). B. T1-Weighted, Sagittal Cervical MRI. Observe the increased interspinous distance, though no underlying dislocation, disc, or soft tissue injury is identified (arrows). COMMENT: A localized widening of the interspinous space suggests possible underlying instability, such as facet instability, even dislocation (divergent spinous process sign). In this case, developmental variation in spinous process orientation has simulated this finding (pseudo-divergent spinous process sign). (Courtesy of Norman W. Kettner, DC, DACBR, St. Louis, Missouri.)
  • Torticollis. On the frontal study there is disparity in the levels of the inferior aspects of the mandible, scoliosis with coupled intersegmental motions of lateral flexion and rotation. (88)
Abnormal Joints.
Three joint complexes should be scrutinized for abnormal widening: the median atlantoaxial joint, the intervertebral disc spaces, and facet joints.
  • Widened median atlantoaxial joint. This is reflected in an increase of the ADI of > 3 mm in adults and > 5 mm in children. (88) It is owing to post-traumatic disruption of the transverse ligament. (105) (Fig. 9-29)
  • Widened or narrowed intervertebral disc. Alterations in height and symmetry may signify significant discal injury. (88) Widening of a single space in the neutral position is a potentially serious marker of severe ligamentous disruption. Axial distraction may demonstrate alarming instability not otherwise apparent. On extension, anterior “gaping” of a disc may correlate with disruption of the anterior longitudinal ligament. (88,91,106,107) Narrowing of a disc can correlate with disc rupture. (108) In the presence of a vertebral body compression fracture the disc adjacent is often narrowed owing to disc disruption.
  • Vacuum phenomenon. The presence of a small, smooth lucent cleft (vacuum phenomenon) adjacent to the anterior vertebral endplate often seen only on the extension lateral has been implicated as evidence of annular avulsion from the discovertebral junction. (109) (Fig. 9-53) Contemporary opinion is that such a finding is most commonly degenerative in nature and cannot be reliably linked to a traumatic lesion. (110)
  • Displaced ring epiphysis. A dislodged anterior ring epiphysis in a young patient is a bony marker of significant discovertebral injury and usually co-exists with a prevertebral hematoma. (91,111,112) The superior epiphysis is displaced in flexion injuries while the inferior epiphysis avulses in extension trauma. (112)
  • Widening of the zygapophyseal joint. A joint space of > 2 mm may denote tearing of the facet joint capsule. (59,86,88) The tetrad of a wide facet joint, wide interspinous space, compression fracture, and loss of the cervical lordosis may denote significant tearing of the posterior ligamentous complex and instability. (113)
P.829

Figure 9-52 STRESS EVALUATION IN LIGAMENTOUS INSTABILITY. A. Neutral Lateral Cervical Spine. Note that anterolisthesis of C4 is accompanied by a widened interspinous space. B. Lateral Cervical Flexion. Note the increase in the anterolisthesis of C4 in the flexion attitude. C. Lateral Cervical Spine Extension. A reduction of the anterolisthesis is noted in the extension position. COMMENT: Radiologic signs of ligamentous instability may be minimal or absent on neutral cervical films. Flexion and extension radiographs are necessary to demonstrate the presence of intersegmental ligamentous instability, which otherwise may be overlooked. (Courtesy of Kenneth E. Yochum, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 9-53 VACUUM CLEFT SIGN. A. Neutral Lateral Cervical Spine. Observe closely the discal area adjacent to the anterosuperior corner of the C4 vertebral endplate. No abnormality is seen. B. Extension Lateral Cervical Spine. Note that in the same area a radiolucent linear shadow has appeared owing to a focal accumulation of nitrogen within an annular tear of the disc (vacuum cleft sign) (arrow). COMMENT: The formation of this vacuum cleft sign is usually identified only on the extension radiograph. This is a subtle and often overlooked sign of a traumatic intervertebral disc injury, which is primarily seen in instances of whiplash. This may also be seen as a degenerative phenomenon. (Courtesy of Donald M. Kuppe, DC, Denver, Colorado.)
P.830

Figure 9-54 INTERVERTEBRAL DISC HERNIATION, WHIPLASH INJURY. A. Neutral Lateral Cervical Spine. Observe the arcual kyphosis with generalized loss of intervertebral disc height at all levels. On flexion-extension there was generalized loss of intersegmental movement. B. T2-Weighted, Sagittal Cervical MRI. Note two intervertebral disc herniations indenting the ventral aspect of the thecal sac (arrows). COMMENT: MRI is particularly useful in whiplash patients who exhibit neurological changes for which a cause cannot be determined. The finding of a disc herniation may not, however, determine if it is the result of the injury as it may have predated the event. Other signs of acute disease may be necessary to establish the correct diagnosis.
CT.
The primary role of CT is in the detection and assessment of fractures, disc herniations, prevertebral lesions and hematomas, relationship of bone fragments to the cord, and actual cord lesions. (86)
MRI.
Use of MRI in the detection of soft tissue injuries in both the acute and chronic settings is often rewarding. MRI clearly shows lesions of the ligaments, discs, cord, prevertebral tissues, and muscles that would otherwise be overlooked. (85,86,106)
Ligamentous lesions include rupture or incomplete tears, especially of the anterior longitudinal ligament. Healing of these structures can also be demonstrated. Discal abnormalities may include separations at the discovertebral junctions, annular avulsions, herniations, and progressive degenerative changes. (Fig. 9-54) Epidural hematomas, myelopathy, and cord contusion (edema) are well depicted. (Fig. 9-55) Muscle tears, edema, and hematomas similarly can also be identified in other soft tissues.
Nuclear Bone Scan.
In the presence of fracture that may not be depicted by plain films, tomography, or even CT, the sensitivity of scintigraphy may allow identification. However, it is not a useful procedure in identifying symptomatic joints that are not fractured, even when augmented by single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT). (114) The isolation of anatomic sites of soft tissue injury in acutely injured patients has been demonstrated with technetium-99m scans. (115)
Figure 9-55 SPINAL CORD CONTUSION, MRI DEMONSTRATION. T2-Weighted, Sagittal Cervical. Observe the focal area of increased signal intensity within the cord, representing edema (arrow). There is a disc herniation at C5 (arrowhead). COMMENT: This 35-year-old female had been involved in a motor vehicle accident and developed widespread upper and lower extremity migratory paresthesias. It is the cord edema that precipitated these symptoms, a finding that only MRI can identify.
P.831

Medicolegal Implications
WHIPLASH SYNDROME
  • The first priority is to exclude the presence of fracture, significant instability, and dislocation. High-quality radiographs with sufficient projections are essential. There should be clear differentiation between congenital variations, pseudo-fractures, artifacts, and positional errors that may be simulating traumatic lesions. (Fig. 9-56)
  • Prognosis is multifactorial, embracing clinical, psychosocial, and medicolegal issues. (76,116,117) There is a paucity of meaningful and reliable data upon which to predict an outcome. (76,118,119) Increasing age, cognitive impairment, and severity of initial neck pain have been shown to be predictive for persistent neck pain after 6 months. (120) Other associations, but not predictive of a poor outcome, include objective neurological signs, degenerative changes, and thoracolumbar pain. (89,121,122,123) The role of secondary gain (litigation neurosis) in recovery remains controversial. (76)
  • A constellation of imaging findings have been at varying times purported to be of prognostic significance, including pre-existing degenerative changes, (124) segmentation defects (congenital and acquired block vertebrae, Klippel-Feil syndrome, occipitalization), (124,125,126) narrowed central canal, (124) intersegmental instability, (124) altered cervical lordosis, and intervertebral disc vacuum phenomena. Reversal of the lordosis does not appear to be associated with long-term disability. (100,123) Prevertebral swelling does not diminish long-term prognosis. (89)
  • Degenerative changes found in a patient some time after the injury are difficult to evaluate as to whether they were caused by the injury or predated it. Previous films are helpful. It is known that if degenerative changes are present at the time of injury the prognosis is poor. (121,122) In the presence of degenerative spondylosis, hyperextension can precipitate cord edema and hematomyelia owing to a pinching mechanism between the anterior protruding disc-osteophyte complex and thickened posterior ligamentum flavum. Current literature supports that whiplash injuries do predispose patients to premature disc disease. (106,120,125)
  • Restricted post-traumatic cervical motion has been shown to develop a high incidence of degenerative changes in the following 5 years. (84) The earliest plain film findings of degenerative disc disease, including loss of disc height and early osteophyte formation, may be demonstrated as early as 3 months following injury. Patients undergoing discectomy for unresolved discogenic pain after whiplash do so at an average of 8 years postinjury. (125)
  • Following acute injury, plain films are often normal despite significant disc or cord trauma. MRI may show diminished disc hydration within weeks of the injury. (109) In addition, post-traumatic cord contusion (edema) may be demonstrated only with MRI. (127)
Figure 9-56 CONGENITAL SPONDYLOLYSIS SIMULATING FRACTURE. A. Lateral Cervical Spine. A wide cleft is visible extending through the pedicle-lamina region of the axis (arrow). Note the congenital fusion of the C2-C3 spinous process, lamina, and facets (arrowheads). B. Flexion Cervical Spine. The separating pedicle-lamina cleft widens (arrow) but there is no direct evidence for significant C2-C3 instability. COMMENT: The patient had been in a motor vehicle accident and on the basis of this film was initially thought to have developed a hangman’s fracture of the axis. The recognition of associated markers for an underlying congenital basis for the appearance, however, confirms that this abnormality was a pre-existing condition. (Courtesy of Ted F. Durling, DC, DABCO, New Port Richey, Florida.)
P.832

Dislocations of the Cervical Spine
Atlanto-Occipital Dislocation.
Atlanto-occipital dislocation is a rare and usually fatal injury following hyperextension and distraction applied to the head. (128) The injury is more prevalent in pediatric patients, who survive three times more often than adults. (129) Most dislocations of the cranium occur in an anterior direction and can be detected by specific measurement methods. (130,131) (Fig. 9-57) (See Chapter 2.) The injury usually results from motor vehicle accidents—more frequently in pedestrians, though falls from heights and neonatal forceps delivery have been described. (129)
Atlantoaxial Dislocation.
Anterior atlantoaxial dislocation was discussed under “Rupture of the Transverse Ligament.” Rotary atlantoaxial fixation (subluxation) is a unique condition of the upper cervical complex that is frequently undiagnosed and poorly understood. (132) First described by Corner (133) in 1907, the exact pathophysiology remains enigmatic, though spontaneous occurrence, trauma (even minor), upper respiratory tract infection, oral surgery, and inflammatory arthritis are known precipitants. (134) Proposed theories focus on joint effusion, tearing of the atlantoaxial joint capsule, and the entrapment of intra-articular inclusions (fibroadipose meniscoids, fat pads, synovium, capsular rims). (132,134,135,136) It is more common in children.
Clinically, the acute patient exhibits torticollis, the head is held in the cock robin position (lateral flexion, rotated to the opposite side and slight flexion), neck pain is prominent, and there often is subjective upper limb weakness without objective neurological deficit. Some resolve with no sequelae; others follow a chronic course with persistent head tilt, neck pain, and reduced range of motion. Treatment consists of hospitalization with cervical traction for up to 7 weeks followed by a cervical collar for several months. (132) Unresolved cases, especially types II-IV, may require posterior Gallie fusion. The efficacy and role of active manipulation has not been investigated though some authors consider it a contraindication. (132)
Four types have been described: (134)
  • Type I. Rotatory fixation without anterior displacement and within the normal range of motion. This is the most common type.
  • Type II. Rotatory fixation with 3-5 mm anterior displacement of the atlas.
  • Type III. Rotatory fixation with > 5 mm anterior displacement of the atlas.
  • Type IV. Rotatory fixation with posterior displacement of the atlas. The odontoid needs to be deficient to allow this type.
Diagnosis depends on radiographic findings with adequate views, which are technically difficult to obtain owing to the head and neck distortion. (Fig. 9-58) On the frontal view the key findings are as follows: (a) on the side of anterior rotation the atlas lateral mass is wider and closer to the dens, (b) on the side of posterior rotation the lateral mass is narrower and away from the dens and the atlantoaxial joint space is obscured, and (c) the axis spinous process may be rotated. (134) The presence of fixation is demonstrated when these findings remain unchanged with four additional frontal views: views obtained in 15° lateral right and left bending and another pair in 15° of right and left rotation. (135,137) On the lateral film the only features may be an increased atlantodental interspace > 3 mm, visualization of the entire atlas posterior arch as a ringlike structure, and a lateral flexion-rotation of the cervical spine owing to torticollis.
CT scan is the definitive method of diagnosis and can employ the same principles of unchanged relationships on right and left rotation in relation to the static position. (137)
Bilateral Interfacetal Dislocation.
Bilateral interfacetal dislocation (BID) is the result of a severe hyperflexion injury and is most often found affecting C4-C7. This injury primarily involves the soft tissues rather than fracture of the skeletal structures. (Fig. 9-59) Those soft tissue structures that are torn are the posterior longitudinal ligament, the posterior ligamentous complex, the annulus fibrosus, and, occasionally, the anterior longitudinal ligament. Disc herniations are common. (138) Bilateral interfacetal dislocation is an unstable lesion that has a high incidence of cord injuries. Dislocation is more prone to occur one segment above a congenitally or surgically fused segment. (139) Anatomically, the superior facets are seen to lie fully anterior to the inferior facets and in such a position are referred to as being locked because they will not reposition spontaneously.
In a complete bilateral interfacetal dislocation the facets come to lie within the intervertebral foramina. The body of the dislocated segment is usually displaced anteriorly a distance greater than one half of the AP diameter of the body below. (140) If the dislocation is incomplete, oblique radiographs will establish the bilaterality of the lesion. On axial CT images the absence of one articular surface at a single facet joint owing to dislocation may be seen (naked facet sign). Dislocations at the cervicothoracic junction are notoriously difficult and may be suspected on plain films (divergent spinous processes, prevertebral fat stripe displacement, posterior cervical line, widened interspinous distance) and confirmed with CT or MRI. (141)
Chip fractures from the tip of the articulating processes are often found in association with bilateral interfacetal dislocation. Surgical arthrodesis is the usual mode of treatment. (Fig. 9-59B)
Unilateral Interfacetal Dislocation.
Unilateral interfacetal dislocation (UID) is one of the few injuries caused by a flexion-rotation force. Flexion causes a distraction force of the facets while the rotational injury around one of the interfacetal joints causes it to dislocate into the intervertebral foramen. (142) This is sometimes referred to as a jumped facet. (Fig. 9-60) In this position the dislocated articular mass is mechanically locked in a dislocated position; however, upon reduction the segment will become inherently unstable. (142) Surgical fixation may be of benefit in these patients. (143)
On the lateral radiograph, unilateral interfacetal dislocation is characterized by forward displacement of the vertebral body. Alteration in the superimposition of the articular pillars on the lateral view represents a subtle sign of unilateral interfacetal dislocation. (144) The combination of the anteriorly displaced articular pillar with its former opposing pillar produces the bow tie sign. Frontal radiographs reveal upward rotation of the spinous process of the dislocated segment, the level marked by a sudden intersegmental rotational deformity. (144) Oblique projections are necessary to identify the dislocated facet joint. On axial CT, unilateral absence of one facet surface can be present (naked facet sign), though the appearance of a false joint can be simulated. (145)
P.833

Figure 9-57 ANTERIOR ATLANTO-OCCIPITAL DISLOCATION. CERVICAL SPINE. A. Vertical Translation. Note the complete vertical dislocation of the occipital condyles on the atlas. Note the associated posterior arch fracture of the atlas (arrow). B. Severe Anterior Dislocation. Note that this extreme degree of translation and distraction has a poor prognosis. C. Pediatric Anterior Dislocation. Note that the occipital condyles (arrow) are well displaced from the atlas lateral masses (arrowhead). This 4-year-old was involved in a rollover motor vehicle accident in which the neck became entrapped in a shoulder strap, exerting a distraction-type force. COMMENT: These injuries are frequently fatal, follow severe trauma—usually motor vehicle accidents—and most frequently are found in pedestrians. (Panel A courtesy of Steven B. Wasserman, DC, Long Beach, California. Panel B courtesy of Rebecca Kane, DC, New York, New York. Panel C courtesy of Alan Plunkett MD, Denver, Colorado.)
P.834

Figure 9-58 ROTATORY ATLANTOAXIAL FIXATION. A. AP Open Mouth. Note the distinct discrepancy in the width of the lateral masses of the atlas with the narrow side posteriorly rotated (arrow). B. Neutral Lateral Cervical Spine. Note the altered appearance of the atlas. The posteriorly rotated lateral mass can be seen (arrow). C. CT, Atlas. Observe that the cranium and atlas maintain their normal alignment with posterior rotation on the left (arrow). D. CT, Axis. Observe that the axis relative to the atlas is considerably rotated in a contralateral direction (arrow). COMMENT: These are characteristic findings of rotatory atlantoaxial fixation. If functional views were obtained in bilateral 15°, lateral bending, and rotation, these features would not change. (Courtesy of Thomas Ulmer, DC, Sioux Falls, South Dakota.)
P.835

Figure 9-59 BILATERAL INTERFACETAL DISLOCATION. A. Lateral Cervical Spine. Note the displacement of the superior anterior articular pillar of C5 in conjunction with an acute deflection deformity of the vertebral body. B. Lateral Cervical Spine. Observe the postsurgical reduction and wire arthrodesis of the previous interfacetal dislocation. COMMENT: A bilateral interfacetal dislocation frequently remains locked, requiring surgical reduction and fusion. Observe the acute widening of the C5-C6 interspinous space.
Figure 9-60 UNILATERAL INTERFACETAL DISLOCATION: C6. A. Oblique Cervical Spine. Observe the altered contour to the C6 intervertebral foramen, with anterior displacement of the articular pillar and vertebral body (arrow). B. Opposite Oblique Cervical Spine. Note that no abnormality is visible, with a normally shaped intervertebral foramen, articular pillar, and vertebral body alignment. C. Diagram. Unilateral interfacetal dislocation occurs in an anterior direction, following a severe rotational trauma. COMMENT: Unilateral interfacetal dislocations are frequently overlooked and are best visualized on oblique radiographs.
P.836

Medicolegal Implications
CERVICAL SPINE INJURIES
  • The minimum study is an AP open-mouth, AP lower cervical, right and left obliques, and a lateral view. Supplemental projections include flexion, extension, and pillar views, as indicated by mechanism of injury, clinical findings, and abnormalities visible on initial studies.
    Close inspection for odontoid and atlas fractures with adequate AP open-mouth or specific odontoid views must be obtained in cervical spine trauma. Consideration should be given to supplemental reconstructed CT images in questionable cases or to exclude pseudo-fractures owing to overlying structures and mach bands (teeth, tongue, etc.).
  • Inclusion of all seven vertebrae on lateral views should be attempted as is practicable to identify obscured fractures and dislocations of the cervicothoracic and craniocervical junctions. Supplemental views may be required (e.g., swimmer’s lateral).
  • Evidence for intersegmental instabilities clinically and on the lateral view should be searched for before performing flexion-extension studies.
  • Recognition of pre-existing congenital variations (block vertebra, odontoid anomalies), degenerative diseases (disc degeneration, diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis), or other disease states should be made and correlated with the mechanism of trauma and the resultant clinical features.
    In the presence of post-traumatic neurological deficits, even with normal radiographs consideration of MRI (when available) should be contemplated to determine cord or nerve root injury. CT with myelography may be useful if MRI is not available.
Figure 9-61 ISOLATED COMPRESSION FRACTURE: THORACIC SPINE. A. Lateral Thoracic Spine. Note the focal depression of the superior endplate (arrow) of the T10 vertebral body, with a displaced anterior fracture fragment (arrowhead). A characteristic trapezoidal vertebral shape has been formed owing to anterior compression of the superior vertebral endplate. B. Diagram. The usual precipitating force is an anterior compression injury focusing the compressive forces to the anterior aspect of the vertebral body. C. AP Thoracic Spine. Observe that the most notable features are a decrease in vertebral height, with approximation of the vertebral endplates, and associated lateral displacement of the vertebral body margins (arrow). (Panel A courtesy of Richard M. Nuzzi, DC, Denver, Colorado. Panel C courtesy of Lawrence P. Rosenbaum, MA, DC, MD, Linkoping, Sweden.)
P.837

Thoracic Spine
Compression Fracture
The most common site for thoracic spine compression fractures is between T11 and T12 owing to a combination of axial and flexion injury. (146) Compression fractures between the T4 and T8 segments occasionally occur in association with injuries related to convulsive seizures (147) or electric shock therapy as a result of violent contractions of the thoracic and abdominal muscles. Most compression fractures in the thoracic spine are wedge shaped, with few having any associated neurological deficit unless there is significant retropulsion of fragments into the spinal canal. (Figs. 9-61 and 9-62) The presence of a paraspinal mass (hematoma) may be an indirect clue to the presence of a fracture. Pathologic fractures may be identified by loss of the posterior body height, pedicle, and other structures and a paraspinal mass. On MRI, abnormal marrow can be demonstrated. (Fig. 9-63) Additional views (swimmer’s lateral), CT, and MRI may be necessary to demonstrate fractures of the thoracic spine and assess involvement of the spinal cord. (146)
Radiographic signs of compression fracture are discussed under “Fractures and Dislocations of the Spine.”
Figure 9-62 COMPRESSION FRACTURE WITH CORD COMPROMISE. T2-Weighted, Sagittal Thoracic MRI. Note that an anterior wedged compression fracture can be delineated at T7 (arrowhead). There has been retropulsion of the posterior aspect of the vertebral body, compromising the spinal canal and distorting the spinal cord (arrow). COMMENT: This patient was rendered paraplegic from the injury, which was incurred from a motorcycle accident.
Figure 9-63 MULTIPLE COMPRESSION FRACTURES COMPLICATING OSTEOPOROSIS. Lateral Thoracic Spine. Note the multiple compression fractures within the midthoracic spine, as evidenced by decreased anterior body height and biconcave deformities of the vertebral endplates. COMMENT: Thoracic wedge compression fractures are a frequent complication of osteoporosis and may accentuate the kyphotic curvature. The loss of posterior vertebral body height is consistent with a pathologic fracture; the differential diagnosis includes causes of osteopenia such as postmenopausal osteoporosis, multiple myeloma, and metastatic carcinoma.
Fracture-Dislocation
Fracture-dislocation of the thoracic spine occurs most often in the T4-T7 area. Fractures of the lamina, facets, or vertebral bodies are often associated (Fig. 9-64) with neurological damage (148) or paralysis because the spinal canal is small and the blood supply is relatively sparse. (149,150) Unstable thoracic injuries may benefit from surgical stabilization. (151,152) A great majority of these patients have been in severe automobile accidents; and these injuries are particularly common in motorcyclists who have been catapulted into stationary objects. (153) Radiographic depiction can be initially difficult and requires an overpenetrated frontal view. Features consist of loss of vertebral body height, displacement, widened interpediculate distance, and paraspinal widening. (146,153) Associated injuries include fractures elsewhere, aortic arch tears, sternal fractures, thoracic disc herniation, instability, and, rarely, Kümmell’s disease (delayed post-traumatic vertebral collapse owing to complicating avascular necrosis). (146,150)
P.838

Figure 9-64 FRACTURE-DISLOCATION: THORACIC SPINE. AP Thoracic. Note the compression deformity of the T5 vertebral body, in combination with a lateral dislocation of the fractured segment. COMMENT: Fracture-dislocations of this variety are frequently associated with severe trauma and complicating paralysis.
Medicolegal Implications
THORACIC SPINE INJURIES
  • Minimum study consists of AP and lateral views. Supplemental projections of the cervicothoracic and thoracolumbar regions are often required to overcome exposure difficulties.
  • Instances of persistent pain or neurological deficits even in the absence of plain film findings may require further imaging such as CT and MRI. Bone scan findings may reveal evidence of subtle compression or other fracture.
  • Subtle compression fractures are easily overlooked. Careful attention to the anterior body margin for evidence of a step sign and displacement of the paraspinal line may reveal the only clues to the presence of fracture.
  • Key variants should not be confused with evidence of fracture—physiologic wedging up to 5°, Schmorl’s nodes, Scheuermann’s disease, degenerative osteophytes, and Hahn’s venous channel.
  • Compression fractures in the absence of significant trauma should raise the suspicion of an underlying pathology. Loss of posterior vertebral body height is indicative of pathologic fracture and should instigate a search for its cause, including the many causes of osteoporosis, multiple myeloma, and metastatic carcinoma.
Lumbar Spine
Compression Fractures
Compression fractures are the most common fractures of the lumbar spine. They result from combined flexion and axial compression. (154,155) The most common segmental levels to develop compression fractures are T12-L1. (156) The extent of the vertebral compression and degree of comminution depend on the severity of the force applied and the relative strength of the vertebra. (22) In children they are torus-type fractures. The incidence of vertebral fractures increases with age. (2) In the elderly, osteoporosis usually precipitates spontaneous compression fractures during everyday activities, which technically render them classifiable as insufficiency fractures (grandma fracture). These most commonly occur in women. (2) Up to 35% of compression fractures in female patients over the age of 45 years may be the result of early menopause and 30% to secondary osteopenia, most often from corticosteroids (15%), hyperthyroidism (8%), and malignancy (> 2%). (157) The disruption of the cortical vertebral endplate causes acute symptoms of only 10-14 days’ duration, as long as no dislocations accompany the fracture. (158) Treatment protocols are based on the nature of the collapse and whether or not there is associated neurological symptomology. (159)
Post-fracture stability is determined based on the classification by Denis. (160) Three columns are recognized: anterior column (from the anterior longitudinal ligament to the mid-vertebral body), middle column (from the mid-vertebral body to the posterior longitudinal ligament), and the posterior column (from the posterior longitudinal ligament to the supraspinous ligament). If two or more compartments are disrupted the fracture complex is unstable. The likelihood of neurological injury is high and interventional surgery is likely to be necessary.
Radiographic Signs of Vertebral Compression Fracture.
Radiographs of optimum quality are necessary to adequately demonstrate these fractures. Lateral radiographs best demonstrate fracture features. Radiographic signs of vertebral compression fracture include a step defect, wedge deformity, linear zone of condensation, displaced endplate, paraspinal hematoma, and abdominal ileus. (Table 9-10)
The Step Defect.
Because the anterior aspect of the vertebral body is under the greatest stress, the first bony injury to occur is a buckling of the anterior cortex, usually near the superior vertebral endplate. (Fig. 9-65) This sign is best seen on the lateral
P.839

view as a sharp step off of the anterosuperior vertebral margin along the smooth concave edge of the vertebral body. In subtle compression fractures the step defect may be the only radiographic sign of fracture. Anatomically, the actual step off deformity represents the anteriorly displaced corner of the superior vertebral cortex. As the superior endplate is compressed in flexion, a sliding forward of the vertebral endplate occurs, creating this roentgen sign. (Fig. 9-65B)
Table 9-10 Radiologic and Pathologic Correlation in Compression Fractures

Radiologic

Pathologic

Step defect

Cortical offset

Wedge deformity

Anterior impaction

Linear zone of condensation

Impaction, callus

Endplate displacement

Impaction, disruption

Paraspinal swelling, psoas obliterations

Bleeding, hematoma

Abnormal small bowel gas

Reflex adynamic ileus
Figure 9-65 COMPRESSION FRACTURE: STEP DEFECT. A. Single Level. Note the L1 vertebral body is wedge-shaped with a characteristic step defect at the anterosuperior border (arrow). B. Diagram. C. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the step defects (arrows) at the anterosuperior corners of the L2 and L4 vertebral bodies, along with a minimal decrease in the anterior vertebral body height. There is an unusual vertical fracture line through the vertebral body of L3 (acquired coronal cleft vertebra). COMMENT: This step defect may be the only sign of an acute vertebral body fracture. With time, the fracture fragment will be remodeled and will no longer be visible. (Reprinted with permission from Yochum TR: Compression fractures of L2 and L4: An L3 vertical vertebral body fracture. ACA J Chiro 1982.)
P.840

Wedge Deformity.
(Fig. 9-66) In most compression fractures, an anterior depression of the vertebral body occurs, creating a triangular wedge shape. The posterior vertebral height remains uncompromised, differentiating a traumatic fracture from a pathologic fracture. This wedging may create angular kyphosis in the adjacent area. The superior endplate is far more often involved than the inferior endplate. Up to 30% or greater loss in anterior height may be required before the deformity is readily apparent on conventional lateral radiographs of the spine. (161) Normal variant anterior wedging of 10-15% or 1-3 mm is common throughout the thoracic spine and most marked at T11-L2. (162,163)
In all compression fractures there should be clear differentiation from an underlying pathology that has produced the fracture. Key features of pathologic fractures include loss of the posterior body height, pedicle, and other structures. There may be a paraspinal mass. On MRI abnormal marrow can be demonstrated. (164)
Linear White Band of Condensation (Zone of Impaction).
Occasionally, a band of radiopacity may be seen just below the vertebral endplate that has been fractured. The radiopaque band represents the early site of bone impaction following a forceful flexion injury where the bones are driven together. (Fig. 9-67) Callus formation adds to the density of the radiopaque band later, in the healing stage of the fracture injury. This radiographic sign is striking when present; however, it is an unreliable sign because it is not present as often as might be expected. Its presence, however, denotes a fracture of recent origin (< 2 months’ duration).
Figure 9-66 TRAUMATIC VERSUS PATHOLOGIC VERTEBRAL BODY COMPRESSION FRACTURES. A and B. Traumatic Compression Fracture, Lateral Thoracolumbar. Note the characteristic trapezoidal configuration of the vertebral body. C and D. Pathologic Compression Fracture. Observe the uniform collapse of the L3 vertebral body (arrow). A subtle loss of bone density owing to multiple myeloma accompanies this deformity. COMMENT: In all compression fractures of the spine, the posterior aspect of the vertebral body must be assessed. A decrease in this posterior dimension is a radiographic sign not found in traumatic benign compression fractures and signifies underlying bone pathology. The most common causes for pathologic fractures of this nature are metastatic carcinoma and multiple myeloma.
Disruption in the Vertebral Endplate.
A sharp disruption in the fractured vertebral endplate may be seen with spinal compression fracture. (Fig. 9-68) This may be difficult to perceive on plain films and tomography; CT provides the definitive means of identification. The edges of the disruption are often jagged and irregular. The superior endplate is more commonly fractured than the inferior endplate.
Paraspinal Edema.
In cases of extensive trauma unilateral or bilateral paraspinal masses may occur, which represent hemorrhage. These are best seen in the thoracic spine on the AP projection but may occur adjacent to the lumbar spine, creating asymmetrical densities or bulges in the psoas margins.
Abdominal Ileus.
Abdominal ileus may occur with severe spinal trauma and is a warning sign to the observer that the trauma has been severe and the likelihood of fracture is great. It is seen radiographically as excessive amounts of small or large bowel gas in a slightly distended lumen. (Fig. 9-69) It occurs as a result of disturbance to the visceral autonomic nerves or ganglia from pain, paraspinal soft tissue injury, edema, or hematoma.
P.841

Figure 9-67 COMPRESSION FRACTURE WITH A ZONE OF IMPACTION. A. Lateral Thoracolumbar Spine. Note the linear radiopaque band extending through the midportion of the L1 vertebral body (arrows). This represents the area of trabecular impaction, resulting in a trapezoid deformity of the vertebral body. B. 3-Year Follow-Up, Lateral Thoracolumbar Spine. Note the absence of the zone of impaction signifying a resolved compression fracture; however, the trapezoid or wedge deformity of the vertebral body remains permanent.
Figure 9-68 DEPRESSED ENDPLATE FRACTURE VERSUS NUCLEAR IMPRESSION DEFORMITY. A. Compression Fracture, Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the significant depression of the superior endplate of the L5 vertebral body, along with a step defect (arrow) at the anterosuperior corner, characteristic signs of acute injury. B. Nuclear Impression Deformity, Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the broad-based, smooth indentation of the inferior surface of the L5 vertebral endplate, characteristic of a nuclear impression (notochordal persistence). No acute disruption of the vertebral endplate is demonstrated.
P.842

Figure 9-69 ABDOMINAL ILEUS ASSOCIATED WITH VERTEBRAL COMPRESSION FRACTURE. A. AP Lumbar Spine. Note the excessive amount of small bowel gas (arrows), along with distention of its lumen. B. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the wedge-type compression fracture, along with a step defect (arrow), at the superior vertebral endplate of L2. COMMENT: The paralytic form of abdominal (adynamic) ileus is often seen after severe trauma and, when present, indicates a likelihood of associated fracture.
Old Versus New Compression Fracture
Differentiation between old and recent compression fracture is often difficult. (Table 9-11) In general, the presence of a soft tissue hemorrhage, step defect, and the white band of condensation are signs of an active or current fracture (< 2 months old). These signs vanish with the healing, which may take up to 3 months in the adult spine. The presence of contiguous disc degeneration is common in old compression fractures owing to altered discovertebral mechanics.
MRI will reveal bone marrow edema with recent fracture. This edema is readily identifiable on MRI studies for approximately 6-weeks post-trauma (Fig. 9-70) Radionuclide bone scan may be helpful, showing increased uptake (hot spot) with recent fractures undergoing active repair. (158) These fractures, however, may remain active for up to 18-24 months after injury, which diminishes its usefulness. (158)
Table 9-11 Radiologic Criteria for Determining Old and New Compression Fractures of the Spine

Feature

Old

New

Shape

Wedge

Wedge

Step defect

Absent

Present

Band of condensation

Absent

Present

Degenerative disc

Present

Absent

Bone scan

Negative or positive

Positive

Bone marrow edema

Absent

Present
Burst Fractures
A burst fracture is a specific form of compression fracture of the vertebral body wherein a posterosuperior fragment is displaced into the spinal canal. (165) Considerable forces of axial compression and flexion create a burst fracture. Posteriorly displaced bone fragments may cause neurological injury in up to 50% of cases to the spinal cord, conus medullaris, or cauda equina, which is best demonstrated by CT and MRI. (156) In cases with associated canal stenosis, surgical treatment should be implicated (152,166); however, most burst fractures are stable and can be treated adequately with conservative measures. (166,167,168)
On the frontal radiograph a vertical fracture line is often seen, a characteristic that helps differentiate the simple wedge compression fracture from the burst fracture. (Fig. 9-71) Widening of the interpediculate distance on conventional frontal films signifies a fracture within the neural arch. In patients with relatively normal discs, a coronally oriented fracture may separate the vertebral body into anterior and posterior halves (acquired coronal cleft vertebra). (169) (Fig. 9-65C) Central depression of the superior and inferior endplates occurs with comminution of the vertebral body and is best seen on the lateral film. Careful examination of the posterior vertebral body surface (posterior vertebral body line, George’s line) may identify the posteriorly displaced fragment, though CT is most definitive. (170) On CT images, the degree of fragmentation is determined as well as the location of any retropulsed fragments and associated neural arch fractures. MRI is used in the assessment of neurological involvement. (Fig. 9-72)
P.843

Figure 9-70 COMPRESSION FRACTURE OF THE L1 VERTEBRA. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar. Observe the compression fracture of the superior vertebral endplate of L1, with significant low signal intensity in the marrow of the L1 vertebral body. This represents hemorrhage (fluid). B. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar. Note that with T2 weighting the fluid turns bright, consistent with recent or active fracture. COMMENT: MRI scans are excellent to help differentiate old (no fluid) versus new (fluid present) fracture or deformities in the spine. The bone scan is not as accurate because the lesion may stay active for up to 2 years after trauma to the spine.
Figure 9-71 BURST FRACTURE: LUMBAR SPINE. A. AP Lumbar Spine. Note the vertical fracture line through the vertebral body of L4 (arrows). B. CT, L4. Observe the vertical fracture line in the body of L4 (arrow). A transverse vertebral body fracture (arrowhead) and a fracture through the lamina (crossed arrow) are well demonstrated. (Courtesy of Gary L. Whitehead, DC, Las Vegas, Nevada.)
P.844

Figure 9-72 BURST FRACTURE: LUMBAR SPINE. A. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the wedged-shaped deformity of the L3 vertebral body with a disruption of the posterior vertebral body line (George’s line) due to a retropulsed fragment (arrow). B. Proton Density MRI, Sagittal Lumbar. Note that the effect of the retropulsed fragment (arrow) on the adjacent cauda equina can be appreciated. COMMENT: The recognition of the retropulsed fragment is decisive in assessing the neurological relevance of a compression fracture. This fragment carries a substantial risk for inducing significant neurological deficits. (Courtesy of Robert M. Kelty, DC, Central Point, Oregon.)
Posterior Apophyseal Ring Fractures
Separation of the posterior vertebral body ring apophysis (posterior limbus bone) is a relatively uncommon abnormality. Though more common in adolescents and young adults, it can be encountered into the 4th decade owing to delayed apophyseal fusion. (171) Clinical features include stiffness and spasm, numbness, weakness, neurogenic claudication and, occasionally, cauda equina syndrome. (171,172) Some will be found with no associated clinical findings. The most common levels are L4-L5 and L5-S1, respectively, though all lumbar levels can be affected, and even T12. (171,172,173) Trauma, including motor vehicle accidents, weightlifting, and gymnastics constitute up to 50% of known precipitants. (171) Surgical removal may be indicated after failure of conservative care and in the presence of significant neurological compromise. (171,174)
Various morphological types are described, including simple central separation of the entire posterior rim, the central rim with some underlying vertebral body, posterolateral separations, and those that extend well beyond the body margins. (171,173) Coexisting disc herniation is common.
Between 15% and 20% will be visible on plain film examination, usually the lateral view. (171) (Fig. 9-73) A thin linear arc of calcification may be seen extending from near the posterior body corner across the intervertebral disc. A posterior focal Schmorl’s node may be seen and the disc height can be marginally diminished. CT is the definitive method for identifying the separated fragment, the indentation from its site of origin, the associated disc herniation, and the effective compromise of the spinal canal and neural contents. MRI is generally ineffective in identifying the separated rim. (171)
Kümmel’s Disease
Kümmel was the first to describe delayed post-traumatic vertebral collapse, originally describing a rarefying process in the vertebral bodies of an injured patient occurring months after an episode of spinal trauma. (175) The existence of this condition is controversial with few cases reported. (176,177,178) It appears to be caused by complicating avascular necrosis resulting in progressive compression deformity. An intravertebral vacuum phenomenon may be evident on radiographic examination. (178)
Fractures of the Neural Arch
Transverse Process Fractures.
Transverse process fractures are the second most common fractures of the lumbar spine, with compression fracture being the most common. They occur from avulsion of the paraspinal muscles, usually secondary to a severe hyperextension and lateral flexion blow to the lumbar spine. Large forces are usually involved. (179) The most
P.845

common segments to suffer transverse process fractures are L2 and L3. (Fig. 9-74)
Figure 9-73 POSTERIOR VERTEBRAL APOPHYSEAL RING FRACTURE, L4. A. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the arc of calcification extending from the posteroinferior corner of the L4 vertebral body (arrow). Note the discontinuity of the posterior vertebral body cortex. B. CT, Sagittal Lumbar Reconstruction. Observe the uniform posterior arc of calcification of the displaced ring apophysis (arrow). A Schmorl’s node is also evident beneath the displaced posterior rim (arrowhead). C. Axial CT, L4. Note the displaced posterior apophyseal rim, which is clearly delineated (arrow). The Schmorl’s node is also evident anterior to the displaced posterior rim (arrowheads). COMMENT: Only 15-20% of these lesions are apparent on conventional radiographs. They are frequently found in adolescents and young adults, often symptomatic, and most likely traumatic in origin. (Courtesy of Kevin A. Szekely, BAppSc (Chiro), Henley Beach, Australia.)
P.846

Figure 9-74 TRANSVERSE PROCESS FRACTURES, LUMBAR SPINE. A. Healing Fractures. Note the left transverse processes of L1-L3 display evidence of callus formation adjacent to the fracture lines (arrows). B. AP Lumbar Tomogram. Note the irregular fracture lines at the base of the L3 and L4 transverse processes (arrows). These were difficult to identify on the conventional frontal radiograph as part of the investigation for post-traumatic hematuria, a sign of renal damage. C. Ununited Fractures. Note that the left L3 and L4 transverse processes have been previously fractured, as evidenced by their characteristic inferior displacement and smooth, sclerotic borders (arrows). (Panel A courtesy of Deborah E. Springer, DC, and George E. Springer, DC, Clearwater, Florida.)
Radiographically, transverse process fractures are frequently missed on the initial examination. (180) The fracture line appears as a jagged radiolucent separation, usually occurring close to its point of origin from the vertebra. Frequently, the separated fragment is displaced inferiorly. If the fracture line is horizontal, close inspection for a transverse or Chance fracture should be performed. Fractures often occur at multiple levels. Fractures of the L5 transverse process are frequently found in association with pelvic fractures, particularly fractures of the sacral ala, or disruption of the sacroiliac joint. Occasionally, loss of the psoas shadow may occur secondary to hemorrhage. Ossification within this hemorrhage (myositis ossificans) can result in bony bridging between transverse processes (lumbar ossified bridging syndrome; LOBS). (181) Owing to the large forces involved, transverse process fractures should always raise suspicion of abdominal organ injury. (179,180) Associated renal damage may be associated with hematuria. CT examination will better identify the fracture and provide information on the integrity of the abdominal contents. (180)
A fracture of the transverse process can be simulated by overlying fat lines; intestinal gas; and by developmental non-union, especially at L1, where the psoas margin crosses the tip of the transverse process. (Fig. 9-75) Oblique or tilt views may be necessary to rule out fracture.
Pars Interarticularis Fractures.
True fractures (not stress fractures) of the pars interarticularis are uncommon. (182) The
P.847

mechanism of injury is violent hyperextension of the lumbar spine, usually producing the pars fracture at the L4 or L5 level. (Fig. 9-76) The fracture line is seen as a jagged radiolucency that is usually vertically oriented and is best seen on oblique radiographs (collar sign).
Figure 9-75 DEVELOPMENTAL NON-UNION, L1 TRANSVERSE PROCESS. AP Lumbar Spine. Note the characteristic non-union of the apophysis of the L1 transverse process (arrow). COMMENT: The smooth opposing borders, lack of inferior displacement, and incidence of the variant make differentiation from fracture possible.
Figure 9-76 UNILATERAL FRACTURE OF THE PARS INTERARTICULARIS, L4. Note the jagged radiolucent fracture line of the L4 pars (arrow). A bilateral spondylolysis of the pars interarticularis is present at the L5 vertebra (arrowhead). COMMENT: Fractures of the pars interarticularis are uncommon and usually follow violent hyperextension of the lumbar spine, as was the case in this 16-year-old male patient, who was clipped while playing football. It is of particular interest to note that the force required to fracture the pars at L4 had no effect on the position of the L5 vertebra, which had bilateral spondylolysis present before the trauma. (Courtesy of Barton W. DuKett, DC, Bigelow, Arkansas.)
Acute fractures of the pars interarticularis should not be confused with spondylolysis of the pars, which is usually the result of a stress fracture. (183) Acute fractures are invariably unilateral, whereas spondylolysis is usually bilateral. Acute fractures frequently heal without residual defects or anterior displacement.
Chance or Lap Seat Belt Fracture
In 1948, Chance (184) described a peculiar fracture of the vertebra consisting of “horizontal splitting of the spine and neural arch, ending in an upward curve that usually reaches the upper surface of the body just in front of the neural foramen.” Use of lap-type seat belts in the 1950s and 1960s coincided with an increasing occurrence of Chance fractures. (185) Severe abrasions can be seen on the lower anterior abdominal wall, outlining the position of the seat belt at the time of impact. Internal visceral damage may also occur, such as rupture of the spleen or pancreas and tears of the small bowel and mesentery. (186) Neurological deficit occurs in 15% of cases. (187) The most common location for the transverse Chance fracture is in the upper lumbar spine (L1-L3). (187)
This fracture has also been referred to as a fulcrum fracture of the lumbar spine. The mechanism of injury is produced by the seat belt acting as a fulcrum over the abdomen, creating flexion and distraction forces in the lumbar spine. The posterior and middle columns fail, and different patterns have been described: (156,188)
  • Chance fracture. Horizontal splitting of the spinous process and pedicle continuing though into the posterior vertebral body to involve the superior endplate.
  • Horizontal splitting fracture. Horizontal division of the spinous process, pedicle, and posterior vertebral body without involvement of the endplate.
  • Smith injuries. Rupture through the interspinous ligaments partially rupturing the intervertebral disc (type A), avulsing the posterior inferior corner of the vertebral body (type B), or fracturing the superior articular process (type C). (156,189)
Radiographic detection of the Chance fracture can be represented by two appearances on the frontal radiograph: a clear transverse fracture through the posterior elements and a rupture of the soft tissue structures and angulation of the superior portion of the fractured vertebra. (Fig. 9-77) This leaves a wide radiolucent gap between the two fractured segments, which has been referred to as the empty vertebra. (158) Often, a break in the oval cortex of the pedicles or a split in the spinous process can be seen. (Fig. 9-77C) The lateral radiograph usually demonstrates the radiolucent split through the spinous process, lamina, pedicle, and the upper corner of the posterior aspect of the vertebral body. (Fig. 9-77B) This appearance is characteristic of the Chance or lap seat belt fracture.
Fracture-Dislocation
The vast majority of the fracture-dislocations of the lumbar spine occur in the thoracolumbar area after a violent flexion injury. (188) Avulsion fractures (teardrop) are commonly found associated with dislocations of the lumbar spine. (Fig. 9-78) Complete luxation with lateral shift of the spine may create cord or cauda equina paralysis. Most dislocations are anterior in position, without lateral displacement. Shearing injuries with disc and ligament rupture and fractures of the posterior arch are common. (Fig. 9-79) On axial CT scans the absence of apposed articular facets is diagnostic of facet dislocation (naked facet sign). (188,190)
P.848

Figure 9-77 CHANCE OR LAP SEAT BELT FRACTURE. A. AP Lumbar Spine. Note the clear transverse fracture through the pedicles, pars interarticularis, lamina, and spinous process of the L3 vertebra (arrows). B. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the superior angulation of the superior portion of the fractured vertebra, creating a wide radiolucent gap between the two fracture segments (arrows). This has been referred to as the empty vertebra. C. Horizontal Splitting Fracture. This is a variant of a true Chance fracture because it does not involve the superior endplate. COMMENT: The Chance or lap seat belt fracture represents an injury caused by the seat belt acting as a fulcrum over which the vertebral body and neural arch are split transversely into two parts in severe motor vehicle accidents. This has also been referred to as a fulcrum fracture.
Figure 9-78 FRACTURE-DISLOCATION AT THE THORACOLUMBAR JUNCTION. Note the complete dislocation of T12 on L1 with an associated teardrop avulsion fracture at the anterosuperior corner of L1 (arrow). COMMENT: This injury resulted in severance of the spinal cord and paralysis. (Courtesy of David P. Thomas, MD, Melbourne, Australia.)
Figure 9-79 FACET DISLOCATION. AP Lumbar Spine. Note the inferior facet dislocations affecting the L2 vertebra (arrows). Associated fractures of the superior vertebral endplate of L3 (arrowhead) and unilateral transverse processes of L2 and L3 (crossed arrows) are also present.
P.849

Medicolegal Implications
LUMBAR SPINE FRACTURES
  • Minimum studies of AP and lateral views must be obtained. Supplemental views including obliques, spot, and lumbosacral tilt are often also required.
  • Instances of persistent pain or neurological deficits even in the absence of plain film findings may require further imaging such as CT and MRI. Bone scan may reveal evidence of subtle compression or other fracture.
  • Compression fracture in the absence of significant trauma should raise the suspicion of an underlying pathology. Loss of posterior vertebral body height is indicative of pathologic fracture and should instigate a search for its cause, including the many causes of osteoporosis, multiple myeloma, and metastatic carcinoma.
  • Compression fractures must be assessed for the presence of retrolisthesis, anterolisthesis, retropulsed fragment, and widening of the interpediculate distance as markers for possible neurological complications.
  • The differentiation between old and recent fracture is a common contentious issue. Signs of acute fracture include a linear sclerotic zone of impaction or callus (0-8 weeks), angular cortical disruption, normal adjacent disc space, and displacement of the paraspinal line. Bone scan is not helpful, as it may show activity for at least a year after occurrence. MRI shows high signal intensity on T2-weighted images owing to bone marrow edema in recent fractures (< 2 months).
  • Transverse process fractures require assessment by ultrasound, CT, or intravenous pyelogram for renal damage. Persistent hypertension after injury should also invoke investigation for renal involvement.
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE PELVIS
Fractures
Sacral
Sacral fractures usually occur as a result of a fall on the buttocks, direct trauma, or in association with pelvic fractures. Isolated fractures of the sacrum are uncommon, and a diligent
P.850

search for an associated fracture of the pelvic ring or symphysis pubis is often beneficial. Two types are horizontal and vertical.
Figure 9-80 HORIZONTAL SACRAL FRACTURE. AP Sacrum. Note the radiolucent fracture line just inferior to the S4 foramina (arrows). COMMENT: A horizontal fracture is the most common type of sacral fracture. The most common location is near the lower end of the sacroiliac joints, around the level of the S3 and S4 tubercles.
Figure 9-81 SACRAL FRACTURE, DISRUPTION OF FORAMINAL LINES. A. AP Sacrum. Note that no definite fracture line is evident. Scrutiny of the left foraminal cortical outlines (foraminal or arcuate lines) shows disruption at three levels owing to a vertical fracture through the sacral ala (arrows). B. CT Sacrum. Observe the disruption of the anterior sacral cortex and foraminal walls (arrows). An additional vertical fracture is seen on the contralateral side (arrowhead). COMMENT: Frequently the only evidence for sacral fracture is disruption of the foraminal lines. Many sacral pathologies, including tumors and Paget’s disease, can also result in alteration to the appearance of these lines. (Courtesy of John C. Slizeski, DC, Denver, Colorado.)
Horizontal (Transverse) Fractures.
Transverse fractures are the most common types of sacral fractures. The most common location is at the level of the S3 and S4 tubercles, which are near the lower end of the sacroiliac joint. (Fig. 9-80) The fracture line is frequently difficult to identify owing to overlying intestinal contents, which may require re-examination or enema. Radiographic evaluation of transverse fractures should consist of an AP view, lateral view, and an AP tilt-up view with 35° cephalad angulation. (1) Careful identification of the cortex outlining each sacral foramen (foraminal lines) should be scrutinized for disruption or distortion. (2,3) (Fig. 9-81) The lateral radiograph occasionally demonstrates the fracture with disruption of the anterior cortex. (Fig. 9-82) Often, the lower segment of the sacrum may be displaced or angled forward. (4) (Fig. 9-83) Complications of sacral displacement may include compromise to the sacral roots and plexus. (5)
A horizontal fracture of the upper sacrum, affecting the S1 or S2 segment, may occur from high falls, such as attempts at suicide (suicidal jumper’s fracture). (6)
Vertical Fractures.
Vertical fractures usually occur as a result of indirect trauma to the pelvis, with > 50% suffering pelvic organ damage. (7) They are visible in the frontal radiograph but not the lateral view. The cephalic tilt view, tomography, or CT may be necessary to demonstrate the vertical fracture line, which usually runs nearly the entire length of the sacrum. (2,7) (Figs. 9-81 and 9-84) The normally symmetrical transverse sacral foraminal lines
P.851

should be carefully scrutinized for detection of the fracture line. (2,3) Sagittally orientated fractures occurring through the midline of the sacrum tend to have a low incidence of neurological compromise. (5)
Figure 9-82 SACRAL FRACTURE. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the fracture through the anterior surface of the S2 segment, creating an acute offset of its anterior cortical surface (arrow).
Figure 9-83 DISTAL SACRUM FRACTURE. Lateral Sacrum. Observe the fracture of the distal sacrum, with slight anterior displacement of the fracture fragment (arrow). (Courtesy of Phillip C. Lening, DC, Houston, Texas.)
Figure 9-84 VERTICAL FRACTURE OF THE SACRUM. AP Pelvis. Note the radiolucent vertical fracture extending through the entire height of the sacrum (arrows). Fractures of the superior and inferior pubic rami are also noted (arrowheads).
Coccygeal
Most fractures of the coccyx are transversely oriented, similar to those of the sacrum. Seldom are they seen on the frontal radiograph; the lateral film best demonstrates this type of fracture. The fracture line is usually oblique in presentation, and slight anterior displacement of the distal coccyx is quite common. (Fig. 9-85) Developmental variation in the position of the distal coccygeal segment may provide some concern to the inexperienced observer.
Ilium
Iliac Wing Fractures.
Duverney (8) first described the iliac wing fracture that now bears his name. Direct force from a lateral direction causes a splitting of the iliac wing. The fracture line is best seen on oblique views as a single radiolucency or may appear as a stellate radiating pattern of fracture lines. (Fig. 9-86) This is generally a stable fracture because the surrounding large muscle attachments prevent separation of the fracture fragments; however, comminuted fractures have been noted. (9).
Figure 9-85 COCCYX FRACTURE. Lateral Coccyx. Observe the oblique fracture through the distal surface of the coccyx, with minimal anterior displacement (arrow).
