Figure 9-86 DUVERNEY’S FRACTURE OF THE ILIAC WING. A. AP Pelvis. B. Diagram. Note the large radiolucent fracture line through the lateral surface of the iliac wing.
P.852

Malgaigne’s Fracture
The Malgaigne’s fracture is a double injury to one hemipelvis. It is defined as an ipsilateral double vertical fracture of the superior pubic ramus and the ischiopubic ramus, with fracture or dislocation of the sacroiliac joint. (Fig. 9-87) There may be superior or posterior displacement of the entire hemipelvis with fracture of the L5 transverse process. The fracture results from vertical shearing forces to the pelvis (10) and is by far the most common fracture, representing approximately one third of all pelvic fractures. (11) All features are usually readily appreciated on plain films. (12) It may be complicated by rupture of the diaphragm and bowel, is unstable, and has a high morbidity and mortality rate.
Bucket-Handle Fracture.
A bucket-handle fracture represents a fracture through the superior pubic ramus and ischiopubic junction on the side opposite the oblique force of impact to the pelvis. A fracture or dislocation of the sacroiliac joint on the side of impact is part of the injury. (13) (Fig. 9-88) The pubic component of the fracture is usually displaced inward and superiorly. This lesion often results from an automobile or vehicle-pedestrian accident and may be associated with injuries to the head, thorax, and abdominal viscera.
Acetabular Fractures.
Approximately 20% of all pelvic fractures in adults involve the acetabulum. (14) Most occur in automobile or vehicle-pedestrian accidents. Almost all acetabular fractures are the result of indirect injury (injury to the foot, knee, or greater trochanter of the femur). These fractures are affected by the position of the femur at the instant of impact.
Signs of capsular distension may be present in fractures around the acetabulum, including displacement of the obturator internus muscle, widening of the teardrop space, and distorted fascial planes of the psoas and gluteus medius muscles. (15) The fat plane overlying the obturator internus muscle should be observed for medial displacement or asymmetry (obturator internus sign). This indicates a hematoma beneath or within the obturator internus. (Fig. 9-89) Widening of the teardrop may be seen in children but is unusual in adults.
There are four basic types of acetabular fractures.
Figure 9-87 MALGAIGNE’S FRACTURE OF THE PELVIS. A. AP Pelvis. B. Diagram. Observe the unilateral superior pubic ramus fracture (arrow), inferior pubic ramus fracture (arrowhead), and fracture-dislocation through the ipsilateral sacroiliac joint (crossed arrow). This patient has an old healed Malgaigne’s fracture. (Courtesy of Joseph W. Howe, DC, DACBR, Fellow, ACCR, Los Angeles, California.)
Posterior Rim Fracture (Dashboard Fracture).
This type of fracture usually occurs after a blow to the knee while the leg is in flexion and adduction. Often, there is a posterior dislocation of the hip. This fracture represents one-third of all acetabular fractures. (11)
Simple Posterior Column Fracture.
The simple posterior column fracture is uncommon. The fracture is best seen on an external oblique projection, though the frontal view may also reveal the ilioischial line displaced medially and separated from the teardrop.
Central Acetabular Fracture (Explosion Fracture).
The central acetabular fracture is the most common acetabular fracture. It divides the innominate bone into superior and inferior halves. In the transverse type, the fracture line bisects the ischial spine. (Fig. 9-90) In the oblique variety, the fracture extends posterosuperiorly to the sacrosciatic notch. This fracture is difficult to diagnose, and a positive obturator internus sign may be the only roentgen finding. If the fracture is severe, there may be central dislocation of the femoral head.
Simple Anterior Column Fracture.
The simple anterior column fracture may terminate anywhere along the pubis or ischiopubic junction. On the frontal view, there is a loss of continuity of the iliopubic line and medial displacement of the teardrop. This fracture is best visualized on an internal oblique view.
Avulsion Fractures.
An avulsion fracture of the ilium is a separation of a bony fragment, usually a tuberosity or bony process (apophysis or epiphysis). They are also referred to as tug lesions. These fractures may be owing to a single acute episode or the result of chronic, repetitive injury. Adolescents and young adult athletes are especially predisposed, usually before fusion of the involved growth center; lesions are mediated by severe, uncontrolled muscular contractions. (16) They are particularly common in sprinters, long jumpers, gymnasts, hurdlers, and cheerleaders. (11,16) These fractures might be considered the adolescent equivalent of muscle pulls in mature athletes. (11)
P.853

Figure 9-88 BUCKET-HANDLE FRACTURE OF THE PELVIS. A. AP Sacrum. Note the diastasis of the sacroiliac joint (arrows). B. AP Pelvis. Observe a contralateral fracture of the pubic ring. C. Diagram. Bucket-handle fracture of the pelvis.
Figure 9-89 OCCULT ACETABULAR FRACTURE, OBTURATOR INTERNUS SIGN. A. AP Pelvis. Observe the medially displaced fascial fat plane of the obturator internus muscle (arrow). B. CT Pelvis. Note the clearly defined obturator internus muscle, which bulges medially (arrow). No definite fracture line is depicted. COMMENT: Frequently the only evidence for an acetabular fracture is displacement of the obturator internus muscle. Many acetabular pathologies, including tumors, infections, and fractures, can also cause this sign. (Courtesy of Appa L. Anderson, DC, DACBR, Fellow, ACCR, Portland, Oregon.)
P.854

Figure 9-90 CENTRAL ACETABULAR FRACTURE (EXPLOSION FRACTURE). AP Pelvis. Note the complete dissolution and bony fragmentation of the acetabulum, as the femoral head has been driven through its roof. The bony fragments are also seen, and an associated fracture through the ipsilateral ischium is present. COMMENT: Central acetabular fractures (explosion fractures) are the most common acetabular fractures and divide the innominate bone into superior and inferior halves.
Figure 9-91 AVULSION FRACTURES OF THE PELVIS. The three most common areas of avulsion fractures of the pelvis are shown. ASIS, anterosuperior iliac spine; AIIS, anteroinferior iliac spine, ischial tuberosity.
Figure 9-92 AVULSION FRACTURE OF THE ANTEROSUPERIOR ILIAC SPINE. A. AP Pelvis and Hip. Note the avulsion of the anterosuperior iliac spine (ASIS), leaving a bony fragment in the adjacent soft tissues (arrow). B. Bone Scan. Observe the large area of increased radionuclide uptake present in the area of the focal avulsion of the ASIS (arrow). The large semicircular black area near the pubic rami represents the distended urinary bladder.
P.855

There are two types of avulsion fractures of the ilium: (Fig. 9-91)
Anterosuperior Iliac Spine.
An avulsion by the sartorius muscle appears radiographically as the displacement of a curvilinear bony fragment from the anterosuperior iliac spine (ASIS). (17,18) (Fig. 9-92) A healed displaced ASIS avulsion may simulate an osteochondroma. Pain is classically relieved by hip flexion following acute injury. Chronic disability is uncommon. (16,18) Treatment by open reduction and internal fixation reduces convalescence to 3-4 weeks. (18)
Anteroinferior Iliac Spine.
Avulsion by the rectus femoris muscle results in the inferior displacement of a fragment from the anteroinferior iliac spine (AIIS). (Fig. 9-93) Active flexion of the hip in acute injuries is painfully limited, though long-term disability is uncommon. (16) This is a common fracture in rugby, soccer, and football players. (19)
Figure 9-93 AVULSION FRACTURE OF THE ANTEROINFERIOR ILIAC SPINE. A. AP Hip. Note the normal anteroinferior iliac spine (AIIS) (arrow). B. AP Hip. Observe the avulsion fracture of the AIIS (arrow).
Figure 9-94 STRADDLE FRACTURE OF THE PELVIS. A. AP Pelvis. B. Diagram. Note the double vertical fractures involving both the superior pubic rami and the ischiopubic junctions bilaterally (arrows).
Pubis and Ischium
Straddle Fractures.
The straddle fracture, or comminuted fracture, of the pubic arches is the most common type of unstable fracture of the pelvis. (11,14) This double vertical fracture involves both superior pubic rami and ischiopubic junctions bilaterally. (Fig. 9-94) The central fracture fragment is usually displaced posterosuperiorly, placing pressure on the ventral surface of the
P.856

bladder. Bladder rupture and urethral tear, which may require diagnosis via urethrography and cystography, occurs in 20% of these patients. (20)
Figure 9-95 AVULSION FRACTURE OF THE ISCHIAL TUBEROSITY. A. Normal Ischial Growth Center. Note the normal secondary growth center for the ischial apophysis, seen as a thin curvilinear zone of ossification (arrow). B. Acute Avulsion. Note the displacement of the growth center away from the ischium (arrow). C. Partial Chronic Avulsion. Observe the fragmentation of the ischial apophysis (arrow). D. Old Avulsion. Note the large bony ossicle inferior to the ischial tuberosity, representing the residual avulsed and overgrown ischial apophysis (rider’s bone) (arrow). E. Old Avulsion Fused to the Ischium. Note that the entire ischial tuberosity is grossly enlarged due to a previous avulsion and subsequent overgrowth of the ischial apophysis (arrow). (Panel B courtesy of Lawrence A. Cooperstein, MD, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Panel E courtesy of John R. Kosbau, DC, Roseville, California.)
P.857

Figure 9-96 SPRUNG PELVIS. A. AP Pelvis. B. Diagram. Note severe separation of the pubic articulation and right sacroiliac joint (arrow), which characterizes the radiographic presentation of a sprung pelvis.
Avulsion Fractures
Symphysis Pubis.
Severe acute and recurrent chronic injuries of the major adductor muscles cause a tearing of bone from the superior or inferior pubic rami near the pubic articulation. This injury is common in soccer players. Radiographically there can be unilateral or bilateral irregularity of the symphysis joint surface, roughening of the pubic bone cortex, and localized admixture of sclerosis and lucency. The injury is usually active on isotopic bone scan (21), and it can appear identical to osteitis pubis.
Ischial Tuberosity (Rider’s Bone).
Fracture of the ischial tuberosity represents an avulsion of the secondary growth center (apophysis) as a result of a forceful contraction of the hamstring group of muscles. (22,16) (Fig. 9-95) These can be acute or chronic injuries and are frequently bilateral. (16) With healing, an unexplained overgrowth of the avulsed apophysis occurs, often leaving a wide radiolucent gap between the avulsed fragment and the parent ischium. This overgrowth may be the effect of hyperemia on the ischial apophysis. Occasionally, the avulsed ischial apophysis may assume a size larger than the parent ischium. (Fig. 9-95) This large overgrowth can be confused with an osteochondroma. Usually, the patient’s history of a previous severe hamstring injury and the fact that the lesion is asymptomatic secures the proper diagnosis. Reduction in hip mobility is common and surgical intervention has not been encouraging. (16) These fractures are seen most commonly in cheerleaders and hurdlers. Because chronic stress often produces this lesion in horseback riders, the residual bony fragment has been called rider’s bone.
Dislocations
Sprung Pelvis
The sprung pelvis is a severe injury, representing complete separation of the symphysis pubis and one or both of the sacroiliac joints. (Fig. 9-96) It is often stated that the pelvis is opened like a book, with one or both innominates displaced laterally. (7) Because of this analogy, this particular injury is sometimes known as an open book pelvis. (23) Severe pelvic basin visceral damage may occur, such as rupture of the urethra.
Pubic Diastasis
Pubic diastasis represents a shearing separation of the pubic articulation. (Fig. 9-97) The normal distance between the pubic bones should not exceed 8 mm in non-pregnant adults or 10 mm in children. (24) Often, associated unilateral dislocation of the sacro-iliac joint is overlooked.
Figure 9-97 PUBIC DIASTASIS. AP Pelvis. Note the marked separation of the symphysis pubis. The bladder is filled with contrast medium to evaluate urethral and bladder injury, which has not occurred in this case.
P.858

Associated Soft Tissue Injuries
All fractures of the pelvis may be serious injuries because of the often associated soft tissue injury. Common soft tissue complications of pelvic injury include the following.
Vascular Injuries.
Intrapelvic hemorrhage is the most common complication, owing to laceration of large blood vessels. Ecchymosis of the scrotum (or labia), inguinal area, and buttocks should make the clinician suspect hemorrhage.
Bladder and Urethral Injuries.
Injury to the bladder and urethra is usually the result of pubic bone fractures with subsequent widening of the pubic symphysis. (25) The incidence is between 10% and 40%, depending on whether the pubic bone fracture is unilateral or bilateral and if one or both pubic rami have been broken. One of the more common injuries is a laceration or complete rupture of the urethra, bladder, and ureters at the trigone, which leads to serosanguineous fluid accumulation within the lower peritoneal cavity. Bruising in the perineum, retention of urine, and especially fresh blood at the tip of the urethra are important signs of urinary tract injury in patients who have had pelvic trauma.
Bowel Injuries.
Laceration or obstruction at the rectum is the most frequent bowel complication with pelvic fracture.
Diaphragm Injuries.
The diaphragm is quite often traumatically ruptured in patients with pelvic injury. A radiograph of the chest is a must in all patients who have had pelvic trauma. The left diaphragm is most commonly ruptured, owing to the protective effect of the liver on the right side.
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE HIP
Fracture of the Proximal Femur
Fractures around the proximal femur are relatively uncommon in young to middle-aged patients, with a sharp increase in the geriatric patient. (1) Severe forces are necessary to fracture the proximal femur in the young and middle years, while only moderate to minimal trauma may induce a fracture in the osteoporotic bone of the elderly. Certain predisposing factors may allow fractures to occur, such as the presence of Paget’s disease, fibrous dysplasia, benign or malignant bone tumors, osteoporosis, osteomalacia, and radiation-induced osteonecrosis.
Figure 9-98 PROXIMAL FEMUR FRACTURE CLASSIFICATION. The various types of intracapsular and extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur are shown.
The overall incidence of all types of fractures of the proximal femur shows a 2:1 female to male ratio. (2) A 5:1 female predominance exists with intracapsular fractures. (2) The average age is about 70 years. (3) It has been estimated that 10% of white females and 5% of white males will sustain a fracture of the proximal femur by the age of 80 years. (4) The incidence by the age of 90 years increases to 20% for women and 10% for men. (4) Many elderly patients with fractures of the proximal femur die within 6 months of the original injury. This occurs secondary to pulmonary or cardiac complications. Therefore, fractures of the proximal femur and their attendant sinister complications are of such proportions that they represent a major health hazard to the elderly and constitute a significant public health issue because of their frequency, morbidity, and cost. (3)
The standard radiographic examination of the hip joint includes an AP full pelvis, AP hip spot (involved side), and an oblique or frog-leg projection. A specialized projection such as a groin lateral taken with a horizontal beam and grid cassette may be helpful, particularly with subtle dislocations. CT is especially useful in the detection of obscured fractures, intra-articular fragments, and adjacent soft tissue injury. (5,6) MRI is also proving to be useful in hip trauma, especially in the recognition of occult and stress fractures. (7,8) Isotopic bone scans have their major application in the detection of occult and stress injuries, though as high as 20% of acute fractures are not detected 24 hr after injury and 5-10% may not be visible after 72 hr. (9)
Types of Hip Fractures
The types of hip fractures are divided into intracapsular and extracapsular, as determined by the relationship of the fracture line to the joint capsule. (Fig. 9-98; Table 9-12) In general, intracapsular fractures have a high incidence of non-union and avascular necrosis owing to probable disruption of the tenuous blood supply.
P.859

Table 9-12 Classification of Fractures of the Proximal Femur

Intracapsular

Subcapital

Midcervical

Basocervical

Extracapsular

Intertrochanteric

Subtrochanteric

Trochanteric
Intracapsular Fracture
Any fracture involving the femoral head or neck proximal to the trochanters is classified as being intracapsular. These are then named according to the fracture location: subcapital (involving the junction of the femoral head and neck, midcervical (through the midportion of the femoral neck), and basocervical (traversing the base of the femoral neck and its junction with the trochanters). Most femoral neck fractures are subcapital; midcervical and basocervical fractures are uncommon. (10,11)
Subcapital fractures are either impacted or displaced. (Fig. 9-99) They are often classified by the Garden classification:
  • Stage 1. Impaction of the lateral cortex at the head-neck junction without angulation.
    Figure 9-99 SUBCAPITAL FRACTURES. A. AP Hip Angular Manifestation. Note the acute angle at the lateral margin of the femoral neck (arrow), which occurred secondary to a sub-capital fracture. Sharp attenuation of the medial cortex (arrowhead) signifies offset of the femoral head and neck. B. AP Hip Impaction Presentation. Observe the thin radiopacity extending medially from the lateral surface of the femoral neck (arrows), representing the zone of impaction in a subcapital fracture of the femur.
  • Stage 2. Impaction with no displacement across the width of the entire neck.
  • Stage 3. Complete fracture with partial displacement with the surfaces still in apposition.
  • Stage 4. Complete fracture with full displacement without contact between the fracture surfaces. (3,12)
The incidence of complications increases progressively with each stage.
Subcapital fractures are readily overlooked owing to the common absence of displacement. The fracture line may be difficult to visualize but is most common at the junction of the head and neck, superiorly, spiraling anteriorly and inferiorly to the anteromedial aspect of the femoral neck. The much less common midcervical and basocervical fractures are seen as complete transverse fractures involving both the medial and lateral cortices, with a variable degree of displacement. (3)
Pathologic fractures of the femoral neck are common and tend to occur in a basocervical location. (3) (Fig. 9-100) Non-union occurs in as high as 25% of displaced intracapsular fractures. (3) (Fig. 9-101)
The incidence of avascular necrosis as a complication to femoral neck fractures varies from 8% to as high as 30%, depending on early detection and degree of displacement. (13) MRI has not been able to predict the likelihood for post-traumatic avascular necrosis. (14) The major blood supply of the femoral head arises from branches of the medial and lateral femoral circumflex arteries, which form a vascular ring around the femoral neck. The branches pass under the capsule and are at risk
P.860

in intracapsular fractures. These are predisposing factors to the development of avascular necrosis. The radiographic changes may appear as early as 3-5 months and as late as 2-3 years after the fracture. (2,13) The average time of appearance of initial radiographic change is 1 year after the injury. (1)
Figure 9-100 BASOCERVICAL FRACTURE. A. AP Femurs. This was the only film initially obtained that, despite the angular deformity at the proximal femur (arrow), was interpreted as normal. B. AP Hip. Note that the basocervical fracture of the femur is now readily apparent. COMMENT: This 73-year-old female presented with thigh pain after a fall. This case demonstrates the need to adequately view the entire proximal femur in any case of hip trauma. The primary complaint of thigh pain misdirected the radiographic examination. (Courtesy Dan L. Satterburg, DC, Minneapolis, Minnesota.)
Figure 9-101 OLD SUBCAPITAL FRACTURE OF THE HIP WITH NON-UNION. AP Hip. Note the non-union of the fracture site, recognized by the sclerotic margins, the superior displacement of the femoral shaft, and the formation of a pseudo-arthrosis on the lateral surface of the ilium (arrow). (Courtesy of David J. Byrnes, DC, Coffs Harbor, New South Wales, Australia.)
Figure 9-102 INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE OF THE PROXIMAL FEMUR. AP Hip. Observe the oblique fracture line extending from the greater trochanter to the lesser trochanter. This fracture line is extracapsular in location. (Courtesy of Phillip S. Bolton, DC, PhD, Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia.)
P.861

Figure 9-103 COMMINUTED INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE OF THE PROXIMAL FEMUR. A. AP Hip. Note the fracture line from the greater trochanter extending inferiorly (arrow), with displacement of the femoral neck on the shaft. There is an associated avulsion fracture of the lesser trochanter (arrowhead). B. Surgical Pinning, AP Hip. Note the restitution of the normal angle by means of an orthopedic metallic fixation device. The lesser trochanter has not reunited to the femoral shaft.
Extracapsular Fracture
Extracapsular fractures occur outside of the joint capsule and include intertrochanteric, subtrochanteric, and avulsion fractures of the greater or lesser trochanters. Avascular necrosis and non-union are uncommon complications in extracapsular fractures.
The intertrochanteric fractures are usually comminuted, with the greater or lesser trochanter, or both, forming separate fragments. (Figs. 9-102 and 9-103) The oblique fracture line usually splits the trochanters, separating the femur into two components. The proximal component consists of the head and neck, and the distal component includes the shaft and the remainder of the trochanter.
The subtrochanteric fracture is found in the area 2 inches below the lesser trochanter. This is an uncommon type of fracture of the proximal femur. Mid-diaphyseal fractures follow severe trauma and are prone to malalignment unless treated appropriately. (Fig. 9-104) Pathologic fractures of the proximal femur often occur in the subtrochanteric region. Paget’s disease and metastatic lesions in the proximal femur may be predisposing factors to the development of a subtrochanteric fracture; thus the presence of a subtrochanteric fracture should be a signal to the observer to look closely for roentgen signs of adjacent bone disease.
Figure 9-104 MID-DIAPHYSEAL FRACTURE OF THE FEMUR WITH PLACEMENT OF AN INTRAMEDULLARY ROD. Note the good alignment of a previous mid-diaphyseal fracture of the femur has been obtained by the placement of an intramedullary rod.
P.862

Figure 9-105 POSTEROSUPERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP. A. AP Pelvis Unilateral Presentation. Observe the posterosuperior dislocation of the hip, which represents the most common form of hip dislocation. B. AP Pelvis Bilateral Presentation with Intra-Articular Fragment. Note that posterior dislocations are evident at both hip joints. Note the crescenteric bone fragment, which has originated from the femoral head (arrow). (Courtesy of Brian Howard, DC, MD, Charlotte, North Carolina.)
Avulsion fractures of the greater trochanters occur most often in the elderly as a result of a fall and may appear to be a simple injury during radiographic evaluation. MRI of these fractures often reveals evidence of the fracture extending into the intertrochanteric region or femoral neck. (15) Lesser trochanter avulsions usually occur in children or the adolescent athlete. Most adult lesser trochanter avulsions occur as pathologic fractures secondary to a metastatic lesion. (3,16)
Dislocations
Most dislocations of the hip are the result of severe trauma, usually in motor vehicle accidents. Hip dislocations represent 5% of all dislocations. (17) They are classified as anterior or posterior, with posterior being the most common type (85%).
Posterior Hip Dislocation
Posterior dislocations occur with the hip in flexion and usually follow a blow to the knee, such as that occurring in a dashboard injury. Abduction of the thigh at the time of impact not only induces a posterior dislocation but may result in a fracture of the posterior lip of the acetabulum. (18) This fracture should not be confused with the os acetabuli, a normal variant. Posterior hip dislocation is usually complete, with the entire femoral head out of the acetabulum. (Fig. 9-105) A small fracture from the anterior femoral head is found in up to 13% of cases, and an associated fracture of the posterior acetabulum will be found in almost 90% of cases. (19) (Fig. 9-105B) These fragments are rarely visible on plain films and require CT for identification. (5)
Anterior Hip Dislocation
Anterior dislocations are caused by forced abduction and extension of the femur. The femoral head usually lies caudal and medial to the acetabulum and near the obturator foramen. (Fig. 9-106)
Figure 9-106 ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP. AP Pelvis. Note that the femoral head lies caudal and medial to the acetabulum, the characteristic position in anterior dislocation of the hip.
Complications
The most common complication of posterior dislocation is sciatic nerve paralysis, usually the peroneal branch. (20) Nerve injuries occur in about 10% of cases affecting adults and 5% in children. (20,21) This paralysis occurs secondary to pressure by the femoral head or displaced acetabular fragments, which may lacerate, stretch, or compress the nerve. (20) Myositis ossificans and avascular necrosis of the femoral head occur in 10% of cases. (17,21) This hypertrophic ossification may also encase the sciatic nerve, contributing to a late onset of nerve paralysis. (20) Post-traumatic degenerative arthritis may occur as a sequela to the previous dislocation. (18)
P.863

Slipped Femoral Capital Epiphysis
Slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SFCE), also known as adolescent coxa vara, epiphyseal coxa vara, and epiphysiolisthesis, occurs during the adolescent rapid growth period (10-15 years) and is the result of a slipping of the neck on the femoral head as the head remains in the acetabulum. There is upward displacement, external rotation, and adduction of the neck on the head. The result is a varus deformity, adduction, and external rotation of the femur. Males are more commonly affected than females, with the peak incidence in males occurring at age 13 and in females at age 12. Blacks are more commonly affected than whites. The left hip is more often involved than the right, and both hips are involved in 20-30% of cases. (22,23) Bilateral involvement is more common in females. Simultaneous bilateral slips are rare, but in cases progressing to bilateral involvement, the second slip usually follows the first within 1 year. (22) (Fig. 9-107)
The diagnosis of SFCE requires clinical suspicion. It is the most common disorder of the adolescent hip. (24) The onset of a limp accompanied by hip pain referred to the knee in an obese adolescent describes the classic presentation. Pain in the thigh and knee is a more common initial presentation than pain in the hip and SFCE is, therefore, often overlooked if the hip is not carefully examined. Irritation of the genu branch of the obturator nerve may explain the knee pain before hip pain in slipped femoral capital epiphysis. Tenderness around the hip exists, with limitation of motion, particularly abduction and internal rotation.
The lower extremity gradually develops an adduction and external rotation deformity, with a shortening of leg length. When the slippage is extreme, the gluteus medius is rendered inadequate, and the Trendelenburg test is positive. Bilateral severe slippage results in a highly characteristic bilateral gluteus medius gait, termed a waddling gait, and is marked by listing of the trunk toward the affected side with each step. (12)
SFCE can be considered a special form of the type I Salter-Harris epiphyseal fracture, a displacement without visible fracture of either the epiphysis or the metaphysis. (25) Because of the anatomy of the proximal femur, the upper femoral epiphysis is subject to shearing stress, and this may be a predisposing factor to the development of SFCE. About 50% of patients have a history of significant injury before its discovery, representing fracture through the growth plate. (22) In some cases the exact cause of the slipped epiphysis is unknown. An obese body habitus (Fröhlich’s body type) is common. Fröhlich’s syndrome (adiposogenital dystrophy) is characterized by marked obesity and hypodevelopment of the gonads and is considered a form of hypopituitarism. SFCE is also associated with renal osteodystrophy, rickets, and radiotherapy.
Figure 9-107 BILATERAL SLIPPED FEMORAL CAPITAL EPIPHYSIS. AP Pelvis. Observe the lateral displacement of both femoral capital epiphyses. COMMENT: Slipped femoral capital epiphysis is bilateral in 20-30% of cases and affects males more commonly than females, the peak incidence in males occurring at age 13 and in females at age 12. When unilateral, the left hip is more often involved than the right.
Radiologic Features
Radiographic evaluation must include both AP and frog-leg (oblique) views bilaterally. Early or minimally slipped epiphysis on an AP view presents subtle findings; with many cases the slippage is demonstrable only on the frog-leg view. It is important to obtain films of the hips in any adolescent with unexplained knee pain.
Posterior medial slippage of the epiphysis is usually present. The slip may be predominantly posterior, which would be visible on the oblique (frog-leg) view, or may be predominantly medial, which would then best be visualized on the AP view. Usually, a combination of posteromedial slippage is present.
The radiographic alterations are usually clearly depicted when the correct signs are searched for in the proper locations. (Table 9-13) This includes apparent widening of the growth plate (metaphyseal radiolucency), reduced epiphyseal height, medial epiphyseal “beaking,” abnormal Klein’s line, widened teardrop space, and medial femoral neck periosteal buttressing. (Figs. 9-108 and 9-109)
Early radiographic changes on the AP view include a widened, ill-defined growth plate with slight metaphyseal deossification. The height of the epiphysis on the slipped side will be less than on the normal side.
Displacement of the epiphysis will be marked by extrusion laterally of the medial one third of the metaphysis from the acetabulum. As the femoral head is displaced medially and downward, the lower margin of the epiphysis becomes beak-shaped (parrot’s beak appearance). The frog-leg view will show the abnormal relationship of the femoral head to the femoral neck owing to the medial and downward displacement of the femoral head in relationship to the femoral neck. The metaphysis lies lateral to the margin of the posterior acetabulum (Capener’s sign). (26) Chronic forms exhibit reactive bone along the superolateral aspect of the femoral neck, creating a broad-based protuberance (Herndon’s hump) and a sweeping curvature of the femoral neck (pistol-grip appearance).
Table 9-13 Radiologic Features of Slipped Femoral Capital Epiphysis

Decreased vertical epiphyseal height

Wide, irregular growth plate

Frayed metaphyseal margin

Beaked inferior-medial epiphysis

Increased teardrop distance

Medial buttressing on the femoral neck

Lateral buttressing on the femoral neck (Herndon’s hump)

Klein’s line abnormal

Metaphysis lateral to acetabulum (Capener’s sign)

Curved contour of deformed proximal femur (pistol-grip deformity)
P.864

Figure 9-108 SLIPPED FEMORAL CAPITAL EPIPHYSIS: KLEIN’S LINE. A. Normal Klein’s line, AP Hip. B. Diagram. Note the abnormal Klein’s line associated with slipped femoral capital epiphysis. COMMENT: Klein’s line is used on the AP projection of the hip joint; the line is drawn along the superior lateral cortex of the femoral neck, which extends through a small portion of the lateral margin of the femoral epiphysis, normally. In slipped epiphysis, the femoral epiphysis on the affected side will align more medially to this line so that no intersection with the epiphysis occurs. It is helpful to compare this with the opposite, uninvolved side. In subtle cases, this alteration in Klein’s line may be the only sign of slipped femoral capital epiphysis on the AP radiograph.
Figure 9-109 SLIPPED FEMORAL CAPITAL EPIPHYSIS: MISSED DIAGNOSIS. A. Metaphyseal Radiolucency, AP Hips. Compare the proximal femurs bilaterally, noting carefully the asymmetrical appearance of the growth plate (arrow). No frog-leg projection was obtained. B. 2-Month Follow-Up, AP Hips. Note the progressive slip with a loss in vertical epiphyseal height and medial beaking of the epiphysis (arrowhead). The metaphysis lies lateral to the posterior acetabular margin (Capener’s sign), and there is now periosteal buttressing along the medial femoral neck (arrow). COMMENT: This case demonstrates how a slipped femoral capital epiphysis is easily overlooked unless a careful search for signs is systematically applied. Also, failure to obtain a frog-leg view greatly diminishes the probability of detection and may be grounds for malpractice. (Courtesy of Norman W. Kettner, DC, DACBR, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.865

A helpful way of detecting slipped capital femoral epiphysis is the use of Klein’s line. (27) (See Chapter 2.) This line is used on the AP projection and is drawn along the superior lateral cortex of the femoral neck. Normally the line extends through a small portion of the lateral margin of the femoral epiphysis. In SFCE, the femoral epiphysis on the affected side will lie medial to this line with no intersection (Trethowan’s sign). (26) Asymmetry in the appearance of Klein’s line is highly suggestive for SFCE. In subtle cases, the alteration in Klein’s line may be the only detectable sign of slipped femoral capital epiphysis on anteroposterior radiographs. (27) (Fig. 9-110)
Figure 9-110 SLIPPED FEMORAL CAPITAL EPIPHYSIS. A. AP Hip. Observe the significant posteromedial slip of the femoral capital epiphysis, with an alteration in Klein’s line. B. AP Hip. On the 2-year follow-up radiograph after an intramedullary metallic fixation device was placed within the slipped femoral epiphysis, note the premature fusion of the growth plate. Early osteophyllic formation is present at the anteromedial aspect of the femoral head (arrow). Cortical buttressing (arrowheads) is noted in the area of the femoral neck and the medial aspect of the proximal shaft of the femur. This is a stress response.
Figure 9-111 TREATMENT FOR SLIPPED FEMORAL CAPITAL EPIPHYSIS. A. AP Hip. B. Frog-Leg Hip. Note that the medial displacement of the femoral capital epiphysis alters the normal relationship of the lateral edge of the femoral epiphysis to Klein’s line. The oblique frog-leg projection augments the visualization of the posteromedial epiphyseal slip, and depicts the pistol-grip deformity and the lateral convexity of the Herndon’s hump. C. Postsurgical, AP Hip. Note that three threaded metallic pins have been passed through the femoral neck into the area of the epiphysis to prevent further slippage. The metallic fixation has precipitated premature fusion of the growth plate.
There is an occasional widening of the medial joint space owing to intra-articular effusion. In addition, cases that have had a chronic history with no therapy frequently exhibit a layer of
P.866

periosteal new bone along the medial surface of the femoral neck (buttressing).
Complications
The usual treatment for slipped femoral capital epiphysis is to prevent further slip by fixation of the femoral epiphysis in relationship to the femoral neck by mechanical means, usually some form of threaded pins. Multiple pins are used to obtain several points of fixation. The pins are usually removed after growth plate fusion has occurred. (Fig. 9-111) Union is marked radiographically by the disappearance of the metaphyseal zone of lucency. (28)
After surgical treatment, radiographic follow-up examinations are required until the epiphyseal plate has closed. The opposite and presumed normal hip should also be examined and radiographed because bilateral involvement occurs in 20-30% of patients in weeks to months after the initial slip.
Complications of slipped femoral capital epiphysis include coxa vara deformity, femoral neck broadening and shortening, avascular necrosis of the femoral head, acute cartilage necrosis (chondrolysis), and degenerative joint disease (osteoarthritis) of the hip. (29) Degenerative joint disease is the most frequent complication. Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is an uncommon complication but is more likely to follow if there is operative reduction (forceable manipulation) or if wedge osteotomies of the femoral neck are performed (35% of cases). (29) For these reasons, the displaced slipped femoral capital epiphysis is usually pinned in situ. Corrective operative procedures are carried out at a later date. With in situ fixation using pins, the incidence of avascular necrosis is as low as 1.5% in some studies. (13,14) In view of these complications, a more conservative approach of traction followed by treatment in a spica cast has been advocated. (28)
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE KNEE
Fractures
All bones contributing to the formation of the knee joint may be fractured. (Table 9-14)
Distal Femur
Supracondylar Fractures.
Supracondylar fractures occur distal to the femoral shaft and proximal to the condyles. They present as transverse or oblique fractures and are often comminuted and intra-articular. (1) The supracondylar fracture is occasionally associated with fractures or fracture-dislocations of the hip. (2) Supracondylar fractures occur after severe impaction forces on the femur and may also occur with fractures of the tibial shaft. When this occurs, the knee is left isolated from the remainder of the extremity and has been called the floating knee. (3)
Table 9-14 Sites of Fracture at the Knee

Femur

Patella

Tibia

Fibula

Supracondylar

Waist

Plateau

Styloid

Intercondylar

Condyle

Head

Condylar

Tuberosity

Eminences

Figure 9-112 FRACTURE OF THE FEMORAL CONDYLE. AP Knee. Note the complete fracture affecting the upper margin of the medial condyle of the distal femur (arrow). A large separation between the medial condyle and the remainder of the femur is also present.
Fractures of the Femoral Condyles.
Fractures of the femoral condyles are intra-articular and are confined to one or include both condyles. (2) These fractures may be T or Y shaped and, with separation, the joint frequently becomes deformed. Fractures confined to one condyle are usually obliquely oriented. (Fig. 9-112) A fracture of the condylar articular surface may displace a small osteochondral fragment, resulting in an intra-articular loose body.
Fractures of the Proximal Tibia
Fracture of the Tibial Plateau (Bumper or Fender Fracture).
A bumper fracture results from the impact of the femoral condyles being forced into the weaker tibial plateau. (Fig. 9-113) It is called a bumper or fender fracture because the tibial plateau is at the approximate height of a car bumper, though only 25% of lateral tibial plateau fractures are the result of vehicle-pedestrian accidents. (4,5)
Over half of the patients who sustain a fracture of the tibial plateau are 50 years of age or older. (4) Between 5% and 10% of tibial plateau fractures are confined to the medial tibial plateau, another 10-15% involve both plateaus, and the remaining 80% are limited to the lateral tibial plateau. (4)
The lateral tibial plateau fracture is quite common and is frequently found in elderly patients with osteoporosis. The radiographic appearance is that of depression of the lateral tibial joint surface, with or without a vertical radiolucent split of the joint margin.
P.867

The fracture line in undisplaced fractures may be obliquely oriented, and it is often difficult to visualize on the routine AP and lateral views of the knee. Oblique views are frequently necessary to demonstrate the fracture. (6) CT is useful to establish the size, number, and degree of depression of the fracture fragments. (6,7) (Fig. 9-114) MRI is a useful tool prior to surgical intervention. (8)
Figure 9-113 TIBIAL PLATEAU FRACTURE (BUMPER OR FENDER FRACTURE). AP Knee. Note that the lateral tibial plateau has been depressed, and a radiolucent fracture line is present (arrow). An oblique fracture through the metaphysis below the medial tibial plateau (arrowheads) has allowed caudal displacement of a portion of the medial surface of the tibial plateau.
Figure 9-114 BUMPER OR FENDER FRACTURE: CHARACTERISTIC FEATURES. A. AP Knee. Note the characteristic depression of the lateral tibial plateau. Impaction of the lateral tibial plateau is demonstrated by an area of radiopacity (arrow). B. AP Knee Tomogram. Observe that the tomographic evaluation of the tibia demonstrates significant caudal displacement of the lateral tibial plateau characteristic of the bumper or fender tibial plateau fracture. The impaction zone of increased radiopacity is demonstrated (arrow).
Ligamentous injuries occur in 10-12% of tibial plateau fractures and occur as a result of severe valgus stress. (4) The medial or lateral collateral ligaments or the anterior or posterior cruciate ligaments may be torn. Stress radiographs may be necessary to establish the diagnosis radiographically. MRI will demonstrate the ligamentous tears. After these fractures heal, follow-up radiographic evaluation will demonstrate degenerative osteoarthritis in 20% of cases. (4)
Avulsion Fracture of the Anterior Tibial Spine.
Avulsion fracture of the anterior tibial spine occurs at the site of origin of the anterior cruciate ligament. (9) The mechanism of injury is hyperextension of the knee, with internal rotation of the tibia. It is most often found in children, and over half of these injuries occur in a fall from a bicycle. (9) The radiographic appearance varies with the degree of displacement. An undisplaced fracture exhibits a horizontal fracture line at the base of the anterior portion of the tibial spine. Those associated with displacement may allow inversion of the fracture fragment and are usually easier to demonstrate radiographically. (4)
Trampoline Fracture.
Fractures of the proximal tibia occur in young children (2-10 years) who jump on a trampoline with another person. As the heavier person jumps, the trampoline mat recoils upward from its stretched downward position with the smaller child landing on the upward-moving mat, impacting
P.868

the descending child’s leg. The force applied at just the right time and angle may be sufficient to cause fractures through the proximal tibial metaphysis. (10)
Figure 9-115 AVULSION FRACTURE OF THE TIBIAL TUBEROSITY. A. Lateral Knee. Note the avulsion of the tibial tuberosity with cephalic displacement (arrow). A radiolucent defect is present in the normal location of the tibial tuberosity (arrowhead). B. Lateral Knee. Note that the tibial apophysis during its normal growth may appear to the inexperienced observer to represent an avulsion fracture. The radiolucent area below the tibial growth center represents the cartilaginous plate (arrow). This should not be confused with a fracture or Osgood-Schlatter disease.
Avulsion Fracture of the Tibial Tuberosity.
An avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity usually occurs in association with a comminuted or subcondylar fracture of the proximal end of the tibia. (11) It is most common in adolescent boys and may be predisposed by the presence of Osgood-Schlatter disease. (12) An isolated avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity allows for proximal displacement of the fractured fragment and, often, an associated rupture of the infrapatellar tendon. (11) (Fig. 9-115) This injury often takes place during athletic activities, when the knee is flexed and the quadriceps tendon contracted and firmly resisting further flexion. (11)
Segond’s Fracture.
A Segond’s fracture represents an avulsion fracture of the bony insertion of the tensor fascia lata (iliotibial band) at the margin of the lateral tibial condyle. (13) A small bony flake is seen adjacent to the lateral tibia. On MRI, evidence of avulsion is confirmed with a high signal intense zone at the site of lateral tibial insertion. (14) Up to 75-100% of cases are associated with tears of the anterior cruciate ligament and almost 70% with meniscal tears. (14,15) Most disrupt the lateral capsule. (15)
Fractures of the Proximal Fibula
Isolated fractures of the proximal fibula are rare and are usually found associated with ligamentous injuries of the knee or fractures of the lateral tibial plateau or ankle. (4) Injuries in these locations should be sought when a fracture of the proximal fibula is noted.
Proximal fibular fractures can present as an impacted, comminuted fracture of the head of the fibula or avulsion of the proximal pole or styloid process of the fibula. The avulsion injury occurs at the site of attachment of the biceps femoris muscle or lateral collateral ligament. (4) This type of injury may be associated with damage to the common peroneal nerve. (16) The association of ruptures of the lateral capsular and ligamentous structures and peroneal nerve injuries resulting from adduction stresses at the knee has been called the lateral compartment syndrome of the knee and ligamentous peroneal nerve syndrome. (17)
Lipohemarthrosis
Fractures that enter the joint often create a soft tissue radiologic sign of a fat-fluid level secondary to lipohemarthrosis. With an intra-articular fracture, marrow fat may extrude into the joint fluid, along with blood (hemarthrosis). (18) The fat floats on the superior surface of the blood and synovial joint fluid, creating a fat-fluid level in the suprapatellar bursa (FBI sign: fat, blood, interface). (19)
A horizontal-beam lateral radiograph of the knee is necessary to demonstrate the subtle fat-fluid level. (4) (Fig. 9-116) The presence of lipohemarthrosis is a helpful radiologic sign signifying the presence of fracture in virtually 100% of patients, even if one is not seen. (20) However, not allintra-articular fractures
P.869

have a lipohemarthrosis, so that the absence of an FBI sign does not exclude the presence of such a lesion. (20)
Figure 9-116 LIPOHEMARTHROSIS: AVULSION FRACTURE OF THE TIBIAL EMINENCE. A. Routine Lateral Knee. Observe the anterior displacement of the patella and significant suprapatellar effusion (arrows) in this patient after trauma. No evidence of a fat-blood interface (FBI sign) is noted. B. Cross-Table Lateral Knee. Note the FBI sign, with the radiolucent area (arrows) representing the fat and the radiopacity below it representing the sanguinous fluid. C. Oblique Knee. This view of same patient shown in panel B demonstrates a tibial eminence avulsion fracture (arrow). COMMENT: To demonstrate the FBI sign (fat, blood, interface), a cross-table lateral projection is necessary. The patient in panel A may well have an FBI sign; however, this is a routine lateral film and not a cross-table lateral. The presence of the FBI sign suggests that an intra-articular fracture has occurred, allowing marrow fat to extrude into the joint fluid, along with blood, creating a lipohemarthrosis.
The knee is the most common joint to be involved; the shoulder is the second most common site. The most likely site for an easily overlooked fracture in association with the presence of lipohemarthrosis is the lateral tibial plateau. (4,20)
Fractures of the Patella
The patella, because of its superficial position and location within the substance of the quadriceps tendon (which subjects it to the forces of the quadriceps muscle), is susceptible to fracture from both direct and indirect trauma. Fractures of the patella are described by the fracture line orientation. The most common fracture is transverse, or slightly oblique, and involves the midportion of the patella. (21) Transverse patellar fractures represent 60% of all types, with comminuted (stellate) accounting for 25% and vertical fracture for approximately 15%. (21)
Radiographically, the AP and lateral films will show most patellar fractures. The skyline or tangential view of the patella is the projection that best shows the vertical fracture. A transverse fracture is seen as a radiolucent line, usually through the midportion of the patella on the frontal projection. (Fig. 9-117) The stellate or comminuted fracture of the patella presents as a multidirectional radiolucency, leaving the patella in fragments. (Fig. 9-118)
The differential diagnosis of patellar fractures is primarily a developmental bipartite or tripartite patella. (See Chapter 3.) These separated ossicles always occur on the superolateral pole, a rare site for an isolated avulsion fracture. A bilateral presentation is common in bipartite patellae (80% of cases) and helps confirm the congenital origin. The radiographic appearance of the ossicles are well defined, an appearance uncommon with patellar fractures. (Fig. 9-119)
Dislocations
Patellar Dislocation
The patella may dislocate either laterally, horizontally, or on its vertical axis. (4) Lateral dislocation is by far the most common type. Lateral patellar dislocation may occur from trauma or torsional stress when direction is suddenly changed while running or even dancing. (22,23) Patellar dislocation is often transient and may be reduced immediately by an attendant or the patient; however, a high degree of instability may exist after reduction. Patellastabilization braces have been shown to effectively increase the stability of the patellofemoral joint in up to 73% of cases. (24)
There is a high incidence of osteochondral fractures associated with patellar dislocation (flake fractures). (25) (Fig. 9-120) These occur as the medial facet of the patella impacts the lateral
P.870

femoral condyle during the dislocation. The small bony fragments are best seen on the tangential view of the patella or CT and, if not removed, could be a predisposing factor to the development of degenerative joint disease.
Figure 9-117 TRANSVERSE PATELLA FRACTURE. A. AP Knee. Note the large transverse radiolucent fracture through the patella. This has created a significant radiolucent gap between the superior and inferior pole of the patella (arrows). B. Lateral Knee. Observe the transverse fracture of the patella.
Figure 9-118 COMMINUTED FRACTURE OF THE PATELLA. A. Oblique Knee. Observe the comminuted fracture of the patella, creating a stellate appearance with multiple fragments. B. Lateral Knee. Note that surgical fixation with a compression procedure is the treatment of choice in comminuted patellar fractures. (Courtesy of Kevin G. Schwager, BAppSc (Chiro), Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia.)
P.871

Figure 9-119 NORMAL VARIANT OF THE PATELLA SIMULATING FRACTURE. A. Bipartite Patella, AP Knee. Note that, occasionally, the patella will exhibit a bony ossicle, representing non-union of an ossification center (arrow). B. Tripartite Patella, AP Knee. Observe the two bony ossicles (arrows), which represent congenital non-union of the ossification centers. COMMENT: Bipartite and tripartite patellae always occur on the superolateral margins, a rare site for fracture. Most patellar fractures occur in a transverse fashion through the waist. (Courtesy of Kenneth E. Yochum, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 9-120 DISLOCATION OF THE PATELLA. A. AP Knee. Note the complete lateral displacement of the patella (P). B. Lateral Knee. Observe that the patella is superimposed on the distal femoral condyles as a result of gross lateral displacement (arrowheads). A fabella is noted in the posterior popliteal fossa (arrow) and should not be confused with an avulsion fragment. C. Tangential Knee. Observe the complete lateral displacement of the patella (P), with flake fractures adjacent to the lateral condyle of the distal femur (F) (arrows).
P.872

Figure 9-121 FEMOROTIBIAL LUXATION. Lateral Knee. Note the complete dislocation of the femorotibial articulation without fracture. This patient suffered permanent peroneal nerve damage from this injury. (Courtesy of Geoffrey G. Rymer, DC, Sydney, Australia.)
Figure 9-122 STRESS STUDIES OF THE KNEE: LIGAMENTOUS INSTABILITY. A. AP Knee. Note that the routine AP projection of the knee demonstrates no malalignment or instability. B. Valgus Stress Position, AP Knee. Observe that in the valgus position there is significant widening of the medial joint compartments (arrow), suggesting medial ligamentous instability. This was not appreciated on the original unstressed AP radiograph. C. Stress Radiograph, AP Knee. Note that there is no evidence of malalignment of the medial joint compartment under valgus stress. Observe the normal vacuum phenomenon (arrowhead) present in the medial joint compartment. This is a commonly observed, normal finding with joints under traction.
Femorotibial Joint Dislocation
A femorotibial joint dislocation is either anterior or posterior in presentation. (Fig. 9-121) It usually follows severe injury to the knee such as that found in a fall from a significant height or an automobile accident. In either the anterior or posterior dislocation, the cruciate ligaments are often torn, along with injuries to the popliteal artery and peroneal nerve. (26) Tears of the collateral ligaments can be demonstrated by stress radiography. (Fig. 9-122)
Proximal Tibiofibular Joint Dislocation
Dislocation of the proximal tibiofibular joint is classified as anterior, posterior, or superior and is based on the displacement of the head of the fibula. (27) This is an unusual injury, but the anterolateral dislocation is by far the most common. (27) The typical mechanisms of injury are either a fall (landing in the sitting position with the leg flexed beneath the body) or a twisting injury. (4) It is commonly found as a result of participation in various sports and is particularly frequent in parachutists.
P.873

The key radiographic appearance is anterior displacement of the head of the fibula. This is best seen on the lateral radiograph. On the frontal view the head of the fibula is seen almost in its entirety, with very little overlap of the lateral tibial condyle. (2) Normally, there is overlap of the tibial condyle at the head of the fibula in the anteroposterior projection.
Figure 9-123 SALTER-HARRIS FRACTURE OF THE KNEE: TYPE I. AP Knee. Note the complete medial displacement of the distal femur on its distal epiphysis.
Epiphyseal Injuries
Fractures in the area of the knee in children before epiphyseal closure may involve the distal femoral or the proximal tibial epiphyses. These lesions may present as any one of the five types of Salter-Harris epiphyseal injuries. (Fig. 9-123)
Soft Tissue Injuries
Lesions involving the ligaments, menisci, and osteochondral surfaces of the knee are far more common than fractures. Imaging
P.874

of these abnormalities goes beyond conventional plain film radiography, employing CT and primarily MRI. (28)
Figure 9-124 NORMAL POSTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT: T1-WEIGHTED MRI. Sagittal Knee. Note the posterior cruciate ligament is readily depicted on this sagittal image as a uniform low signal curvilinear density (arrow).
Figure 9-125 MENISCAL TEARS: GRADE III. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Knee. Note the linear hyperintense signal intensity traversing through the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (arrowheads). This is consistent with a horizontal cleavage tear. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Knee. Note the obliquely oriented, linear hyperintensity, which extends to the inferior articular surface of the posterior horn of the lateral meniscus (arrow).
Ligamentous Injuries.
Collateral ligaments can be assessed with varus-valgus stress views and noting the width of the stressed joint space. (Fig. 9-122) Previous avulsions from the medial collateral attachment at the distal femur may calcify and be visible on plain films (Pellegrini-Stieda disease). Coronal plane MRI is most useful for assessing collateral ligaments—grade 1 injuries show ligament thickening, grades 2 and 3 show variable degrees of focal discontinuity and, in the presence of avulsion from a bony attachment, features of osseous contusion may be seen. (28)
Cruciate ligament injuries are reliably imaged by MRI, with sensitivities and specificities > 90%. (28) Signs of abnormality include discontinuity and abnormal caliber, and edema is seen as increased signal on T2-weighted images. (28) Sagittal images are the optimum, though coronal images can also demonstrate the cruciates clearly. (Fig. 9-124) Tears of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) often co-exist with bone contusion on the anterior lateral femoral condyle and posterolateral tibia. (28)
Meniscal Injuries.
Internal derangements involving the menisci can be depicted by MRI in up to 97% of cases. (28) A tear is identified on MRI as a linear band of increased signal on T2-weighted images extending from one surface to the other. These tend to be vertical, whereas degenerative tears orient horizontally. (Fig. 9-125) MRI dramatically demonstrates meniscal cysts, which most commonly involve the lateral aspect of the joint, co-existing with a tear in the lateral meniscus. (29)
Osteochondral Injuries.
Fractures through cancellous bone appear on MRI as linear or serpiginous bands of low signal intensity surrounded by high signal intensity edema. (Fig. 9-126) Bone contusions (bone bruises) within the marrow show as decreased signal intensity on T1- and increased signal on T2-weighted images. There is a high association with ligamentous injuries, especially of the ACL. (28,30) Chondral lesions can be observed as defects in the cartilage surface.
Figure 9-126 MRI, OCCULT FRACTURE. T2-Weighted MRI, Coronal Knee. Note the numerous, linear, high signal intensity areas (arrowheads) extending from the proximal tibial cortex into the metaphysis. These findings are consistent with an occult tibial plateau fracture and surrounding marrow edema. The normal ACL is seen (arrow). (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Children’s Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE ANKLE
The routine radiographic evaluation of the ankle consists of three views: AP, lateral, and medial oblique. The medial oblique projection is taken with 35-45° of internal rotation of the foot. Special projections (e.g., CT and stress views) may be helpful in demonstrating subtle fractures, ligamentous instability, and even dislocations.
CT provides excellent bone detail and assessment of the complex articulations of the foot and ankle. It is the technique of choice for examination of the subtalar joint. (1,2) CT is also useful for imaging neoplasms of the foot and ankle. Acute skeletal trauma and post-traumatic arthropathy, especially of the hindfoot, including the calcaneus, are well demonstrated with CT. It is not helpful for soft tissue injury such as ligamentous tears. (3)
MRI provides superior soft tissue contrast, multiple image planes, and excellent spatial resolution and is non-invasive. It is particularly useful in the demonstration of ligament, tendon, cartilage, soft tissue, and even bony abnormalities. (4)
Fractures
A number of classifications of ankle fractures have been developed. The two most commonly used are the Lauge-Hansen and Danis-Weber systems. (5) The Lauge-Hansen classification is derived from the forces involved to produce the fracture but is cumbersome. The Danis-Weber classification is the simplest and most frequently used by orthopedic personnel. (6,7)
The Danis-Weber system is based on the position of the fibular fracture in relation to the tibiotalar joint space, with three types defined: A, B and C. Type A consists of fractures of the fibula below the tibiotalar joint and do not involve the syndesmosis. Type B fractures occur at the joint level, producing an oblique fibular fracture. Two categories of type C fractures are described. Type C1 is an oblique fibular fracture above the level of the distal tibiofibular ligaments. Type C2 lesions present with higher fibular fractures and therefore co-exist with more extensive rupture of the syndesmosis. Type A injuries can be treated by closed methods while types B and C usually require internal fixation. (7)
Medial Malleolus Fracture
The medial malleolus is the most distal portion of the tibia. (Fig. 9-127) Fractures are usually transverse or oblique in orientation, caused by angular forces generated by movement of the talus against the medial malleolus. Fractures of the medial malleolus distal to the ceiling of the tibiotalar joint line (plafond) are more
P.875

stable than those that arise proximal. (5) A fracture of the medial malleolus is best seen on the AP radiograph as a radiolucent line with adjacent soft tissue swelling.
Figure 9-127 MEDIAL MALLEOLUS FRACTURE AND ASSOCIATED DISTAL FIBULA FRACTURE. AP Ankle. Note the medial malleolus fracture (arrowhead) and an oblique fracture of the distal fibula, along with lateral displacement of the talus. The linear subchondral radiolucency in the talar dome (arrows) is a radiographic sign for an intact blood supply to the talus (Hawkin’s sign), which represents the unlikelihood of complicating avascular necrosis.
Lateral Malleolus Fracture
The most distal portion of the fibula is the lateral malleolus. The most common fracture of the lateral malleolus is an oblique or spiral fracture extending from the inferior and anterior margin upward and backward to the posterior margin of the shaft of the distal fibula. (5) (Fig. 9-128) This fracture occurs as a result of outward or external rotation of the foot and is best observed on the medial oblique projection as a radiolucent oblique line with adjacent soft tissue swelling (McKenzie’s sign). A variety of small avulsion fractures occur around the tip of the lateral malleolus mediated by the lateral collateral ligaments. Small talar dome osteochondral fractures on occasion accompany lateral malleolar fractures. (Fig. 9-129)
Bimalleolar Fracture
Bimalleolar fracture represents a fracture through both the medial and lateral malleoli. The fracture on one side is transverse because of tensile forces, and the opposite fracture is oblique or
P.876

spiral. (8) (Figs. 9-130 and 9-131) Diffuse soft tissue swelling over the malleoli is often present, alerting the observer to look closely for fracture.
Figure 9-128 DISTAL FIBULA FRACTURE. Medial Oblique Ankle. Note the most common fracture of the lateral malleolus is an oblique fracture extending upward (arrow). This fracture is best seen on the medial oblique projection.
Figure 9-129 DISTAL FIBULA FRACTURE WITH OSTEOCHONDRAL TALAR FRACTURE. Medial Oblique Ankle. Note the fracture of the lateral malleolus (arrow). At the medial talar dome, an isolated osteochondral fracture contiguous with the articular surface can be seen (arrowhead).
Trimalleolar Fracture
Trimalleolar fractures affect the posterior lip of the tibia (sometimes called the third malleolus) in addition to the medial and lateral malleoli. (9) A trimalleolar fracture has been referred to by some as a Cotton’s fracture, despite Henderson’s first description. (10,11)
Trimalleolar fractures are often found with tibiotalar dislocation. These fractures are the result of external rotation of the foot and are, therefore, laterally and posteriorly displaced. (9) Fracture of the third malleolus is best seen on the lateral radiograph, with the fracture fragment being displaced posteriorly and/or superiorly.
Pott’s Fracture
Pott’s fracture, as classically described, is a partial dislocation of the ankle, with fracture of the fibula within 6-7 cm above the lateral malleolus and rupture of the distal tibiofibular ligaments of the ankle. (12) (Fig. 9-132) Sir Percival Pott described this fracture in 1768 and ascribed the injury to “leaping or jumping.” The term Pott’s fracture has been used erroneously to describe a
P.877

number of fractures, such as the bimalleolar or trimalleolar fractures. The term Pott’s fracture should be avoided in describing any injury that includes a malleolar fracture.
Figure 9-130 BIMALLEOLAR FRACTURE. AP Ankle. Note the characteristic transverse fracture through the medial malleolus (arrow), along with a spiral fracture of the lateral malleolus (arrowhead).
Figure 9-131 BIMALLEOLAR FRACTURE-DISLOCATION. A. AP Ankle. Observe the gross lateral displacement of the talus, with bimalleolar fractures. B. Postsurgical Reduction, AP Ankle. Note that two surgical metallic screws have been placed through the bimalleolar fractures, with good alignment resulting. COMMENT: Fracture-dislocation of this magnitude is invariably associated with permanent ligamentous instability of the ankle mortise joint.
Figure 9-132 POTT’S FRACTURE OF THE ANKLE. This fracture is defined as a fracture through the distal fibula, 6-7 cm above the lateral malleolus, accompanied by rupture of the distal tibiofibular ligaments of the ankle. Disruption of the medial collateral ligament, while common, is not considered an integral part of this osteoligamentous injury.
Dupuytren’s Fracture
Dupuytren’s fracture was described by Dupuytren based on a single clinical case in 1816 in which a patient who had sustained a fracture of the distal fibula also presented with a widened ankle mortise and medial displacement of the tibia. (13) Dupuytren’s fracture, as classically described, is a fracture of the distal fibula (lateral malleolus) with rupture of the distal tibiofibular ligaments, diastasis of the syndesmosis, lateral dislocation of the talus, and displacement of the foot upward and outward. (13) Unfortunately, the term Dupuytren’s fracture is used to describe several varieties of bimalleolar fractures and, because of its similarity to Pott’s fracture, has created some confusion within the literature. The term should be used only as classically described by Dupuytren (13).
Maisonneuve’s Fracture
In 1840 Maisonneuve described a fracture of the proximal fibular shaft. (14) This fracture is caused by forceful inversion and external rotation of the ankle. This motion forces the talus laterally against the fibula, initially producing rupture of the inferior tibiofibular syndesmosis. As the force is maintained, the fibula, freed from the tibia, continues to be displaced laterally and posteriorly. The superior tibiofibular joint, remaining intact, secures the proximal fibula so that the long lever of the fibula produces a fracture of the fibula in its proximal third.
Maisonneuve’s fracture may be easily overlooked because patients rarely complain of pain in the region of the proximal fibula when more painful injuries at the ankle exist. A full view of the entire tibia and fibula should be considered in patients when the mechanism of injury to the ankle is as Maisonneuve described. (14) (Fig. 9-133) These fractures generally heal well with appropriate surgical intervention. (15)
Figure 9-133 MAISONNEUVE’S FRACTURE: PROXIMAL FIBULA. Note the oblique fracture of the proximal fibula (arrow) secondary to a forceful inversion and external rotation of the ankle. COMMENT: These fractures are often overlooked, owing to the severity of the ankle injury. Close inspection of the proximal fibula should be performed in all instances of ankle trauma.
Tillaux’s Fracture
A Tillaux’s fracture is through the medial malleolus with diastasis of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis. This creates an avulsion of the anterior tubercle of the tibia and a fracture of the lateral malleolus 6-7 cm proximal to the distal end of the fibula. (16) There are three residual fractures: medial malleolus, anterior tibia, and distal fibular shaft. This fracture is best seen on AP radiographs of the ankle.
Toddler’s Fracture
Toddler’s fracture, an undisplaced spiral fracture of the tibia, occurs in children from 9 months to 3 years of age. It is caused by a fall or by the child getting a foot caught between the slats of the crib and then rolling over. The baby, often too young to verbalize its complaints, may evidence only a mysterious refusal to bear weight on the extremity.
Radiographic examination reveals an undisplaced spiral fracture of the tibia, which is usually seen only on one projection—either the AP or lateral view. (5) (Fig. 9-134) Most toddler’s fractures are seen on the AP view and are not demonstrated on the lateral projection. Rarely, the fibula may be fractured as well. (5)
P.878

The adult form, where the tibial fracture occurs adjacent to the top of high-top boots, is called a boot-top fracture. (Fig. 9-135) If both the tibia and fibula are fractured, these can also be referred to as BB, or both bones, fractures.
Figure 9-134 TODDLER’S FRACTURE. A. AP Tibia and Fibula. Note that no fracture line is evident. B. Lateral Tibia and Fibula. Observe that a spiral fracture line is visualized in the distal third of the diaphysis of the tibia. COMMENT: This case demonstrates the need for a minimum of AP and lateral radiographs in traumatized patients. The toddler’s fracture is often seen in only one of the projections.
Dislocations
Because subluxations and dislocations of the ankle joint associated with malleolar fractures have already been discussed, it remains only to consider the displacements that follow extensive ligamentous and capsular damage without fracture.
The talus may be dislocated at one, two, or all three of its articulations; however, we will consider only those that involve the ankle joint. Dislocation of the talus occurs as an isolated event, in association with fracture of the neck of the talus, or as an element in total extrusion of the talus. (17)
Anterior Dislocation
Isolated dislocation of the ankle may occur in either an anterior or posterior direction. Medial or lateral dislocation is commonly associated with a fracture of the tibia or fibula. Anterior dislocation follows a force that results in posterior displacement of the tibia on the fixed foot. All ligamentous and capsular attachments from the tibia and fibula to the talus are torn, with the exception, occasionally, of the posterior talofibular ligament. Clinically, the foot is usually slightly dorsiflexed and appears elongated anteriorly. The depressions on either side of the Achilles tendon are obliterated. The talus is prominent anteriorly, and the dorsalis pedis pulse may be absent. (17)
Figure 9-135 BOOT-TOP FRACTURE. Note the comminuted fractures of the distal tibia and fibula, seen at the level of a skier’s boot top. COMMENT: Fractures of this type may be referred to as BB (both bones). The BB fracture can be found in the radius and ulna or in the tibia and fibula.
Posterior Dislocation
Posterior dislocation occurs more often than anterior displacement. Both are rare, and both involve fracture of the corresponding tibial margin. Posterior dislocation of the talus most often follows a blow to the posterior aspect of the tibia and results in plantar flexion of the ankle with apparent shortening of the foot. Reduction is carried out by exerting traction in the long axis of the limb and lifting the heel forward. Subsequent operative repair of the ligaments is an individual decision. (17)
Complications of Ankle Fracture
Non-Union
Non-union is most frequent in fracture of the medial malleolus; it occurs in 10-15% of patients treated by closed methods. (17) Non-union of the lateral or posterior malleolus is rare. (17) Nonunion at the level of the plafond is more commonly symptomatic than that below the plafond. (18)
P.879

Traumatic Degenerative Arthritis
Traumatic degenerative arthritis occurs in 20-40% of ankle fractures, regardless of the method of treatment. (18,19) Predisposing factors are inaccurate reduction of the mortise, comminution of the plafond, and advanced age. (17)
Ligamentous Instability
Often, fractures and dislocations of the ankle are found with complete or incomplete tears of the supporting ligaments. Ligamentous damage unassociated with fracture often goes ignored and is especially dangerous because it may go unrecognized and untreated, leading to permanent disability of the ankle. The important ligaments of the ankle joint are the lateral collateral ligament, the medial (deltoid) collateral, and the tibiofibular ligament (tibiofibular syndesmosis). (20) A variety of tears to these ligaments occurs with the numerous types of injuries, which can affect the ankle joint. The most frequent injury is disruption of the lateral ligaments of the ankle.
Routine imaging is not effective in determining ligamentous injury. (21) Signs of soft tissue swelling consist of displacement of the skin line, blurring of the fascial plane lines, infiltration of the pre-Achilles fat, and the presence of a teardrop-shaped soft tissue density anterior to the ankle mortise on the lateral view. (22) Myositis ossificans is unusual in the foot and ankle but can be observed in the Achilles tendon, interosseous membrane, and intermetatarsals. In the absence of fracture or obvious dislocation, considerable soft tissue swelling is an indication for stress studies to evaluate for ligamentous damage. (23)
Stress views in both the AP and lateral positions are useful examinations. (23,24,25,26) Up to 25% of ankles with verified ligament disruption will have normal stress radiographs. (27) On valgus and varus positions normal talar tilt ranges from 5° to 23°. (28,29) Comparison with the normal side is essential with > 10° greater tilt significant of ligamentous disruption. (29,30) If there is > 6° tilt in the neutral position and or 3 mm difference in joint space, this is also indicative of probable ligament damage. (27,31,32,33)
AP (drawer) stress views are done in the lateral projection to indicate anterior talofibular ligament injury (positive drawer sign). A difference of 2 mm or more in comparison with the normal side suggests significant injury. (28)
MRI can produce diagnostic accuracy in close to 95% of all ligament tears. (23,28)
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE FOOT
Fractures
Trauma to the foot with fractures is frequent, and fractures of the feet account for approximately 10% of all fractures. (1,2) Direct trauma can be from objects falling on the foot or from movement of the foot against a variety of objects. (1) Indirect trauma occurs from torsion of the joints or avulsion at tendon or capsule attachments. (1) The stress of overuse or unaccustomed activity may result in fatigue fractures. (1) Diabetic neutropic arthropathy often leads to tarsal fractures and fracture-dislocation of the tarsometatarsal joints. (3)
The routine views of the foot are the dorsoplantar, 35° medial oblique, and lateral. (3) An axial projection is necessary when calcaneal fracture is a major concern. Occasionally, varying oblique projections and CT may be needed to demonstrate the fracture or dislocation. (4,5) MRI is more suited to the depiction of effusions and bone bruises, as well as tendon and ligament injuries. (6,7)
Calcaneal Fractures
The calcaneus is the largest tarsal bone and the one most often fractured. (3,8) It has two major functions: to bear weight and to serve as a springboard for locomotion. (1) Approximately 25% of calcaneal fractures involve the various processes of the bone and spare the subtalar joint; 75% involve the subtalar joint and body of the calcaneus. (9)
There are two basic types of calcaneal fractures: the compressive and the non-compressive (avulsive).
Compression Fracture.
The compression fracture is the result of compression forces generated in crushing injuries as encountered by falling from a height and landing on the feet. (10) Approximately 10% of these fractures are bilateral, and 10% are associated with vertebral body compression or neural arch fracture of the thoracolumbar spine. (11) (Fig. 9-136) The weight of the body is transmitted through the tibia and talus onto the calcaneus. (1) The resultant fracture is comminuted, and the degree of displacement and comminution is directly related to the magnitude of the forces involved. (1) The fracture usually involves the subtalar joint, with some degree of depression of the posterior facet. Occasionally, a radiolucent fracture line will be seen; however, most cases do not demonstrate such a line.
Boehler’s angle is crucial in the detection of these fractures in the absence of fracture lines and offers a reliable prognostic indicator of the treatment outcome. (12,13) Boehler’s angle is formed by a line drawn from the superior posterior margin of the tuberosity through the tip of the posterior facet. (13) A second line is drawn from the tip of the posterior facet through the superior margin of the anterior process of the calcaneus. The normal angle is 28-40°. (1,13) A Boehler’s angle of < 28° indicates depression and probable fracture. (Fig. 9-137) Correlation exists between a poorer prognosis and the degree of variation the angle is from normal. (12)
Avulsion Fracture.
Those fractures that spare the subtalar joint are usually of the avulsion type. They involve the anterior process, the sustentaculum tali, the superior portion of the tuberosity, and the medial or lateral surface of the tuberosity. (1) Fractures of the anterior process are the most common form of avulsion fracture of the calcaneus. (14)
A fracture of the superior portion of the tuberosity of the calcaneus is known as a beak fracture. (15) The posterior margin of the tuberosity represents the site of insertion of the Achilles tendon, and the beak fracture may be the result of avulsion by the Achilles tendon.
P.880

Figure 9-136 COMPRESSION FRACTURES: SUICIDE ATTEMPT. A and B. Right and Left Calcaneus. Note that both calcanei demonstrate comminution fractures secondary to severe forces occurring upon impact with the ground after a suicide jump from a second-story window. C. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the associated compression fractures of the superior endplate of the L1 vertebra with a characteristic step defect (arrow).
P.881

Figure 9-137 BOEHLER’S ANGLE. A reduction in Boehler’s angle to < 28° is frequently indicative of a calcaneal compression fracture.
Fractures of the Talus
The talus is the second most common tarsal bone to be fractured, following the calcaneus. The most frequent type of fracture is an avulsion, usually on the anterior surface of the talar neck at the capsular insertion. Fractures are classified according to anatomic site—body, neck, or head. (16)
Talar Body Fractures.
Body fractures may be oriented in a transverse or oblique plane. Osteochondral chip fractures of the talar dome occur either at the medial or lateral margins following forceful inversion or eversion injuries, when there is direct contact between the talus and opposing malleolus. (Fig. 9-138)
Figure 9-138 OSTEOCHONDRAL FRACTURE OF THE MEDIAL TALAR DOME. AP Ankle. Note the radiolucent defect with a central bone flake in the medial talar dome (arrow). This represents an osteochondral fracture of the articular surface.
Figure 9-139 AVIATOR’S FRACTURE: NECK OF TALUS. Note that a vertical fracture line extends through the talar neck (arrow). COMMENT: This type of talar fracture can predispose the patient to avascular necrosis of the body of the talus.
Talar Neck Fractures.
