Avulsions of the anterior surface of the talar neck are the most frequent, followed by vertical fractures. The mechanism of injury in vertical neck fractures is the impact of the anterior lip of the tibia as it is forced downward into the talar neck, which is being forced upward. Vertical neck fractures are most frequently the result of an automobile accident where the driver has the foot firmly applied to the brake pedal at the time of impact. They were first described in World War I when pilots involved in crash landings had the rudder pedal forced into the sole of the foot (aviator’s fracture). (17) (Fig. 9-139) These are the fractures most commonly complicated by avascular necrosis of the talus and should be treated surgically. (18)
Talar Head Fractures.
Talar head fractures are infrequent and are characterized by the fracture line being well forward of the talar neck.
Complications of Talus Fractures
The main concern with talus fractures is the development of avascular necrosis, which usually involves the body and may occur after a talar neck fracture. (19) This complication is more prevalent in children when compared to adults and occurs in approximately 16% of childhood cases. (20) This may also complicate talar dislocation. The pattern of vascular perfusion to the talar body is such that a neck fracture can significantly compromise its blood supply. Little to no collateral supply exists because > 60% of its external surface is covered by articular cartilage. The main source of blood enters by way of the foramina in the sinus tarsi and tarsal canal. Generally, the more anterior the neck fracture, the greater the likelihood for developing avascular necrosis.
Following a talar fracture, the early formation of a zone of linear lucency beneath the cortex of the dome is a reliable indicator of an intact blood supply with a diminished probability for developing avascular necrosis (Hawkin’s sign). (21)
P.882

Other Tarsal Fractures
Occasionally, other tarsal bones may fracture.
Navicular Fractures.
Avulsion of its dorsal surface is the most frequent type of tarsal navicular fracture. (22) Acute eversion may also avulse the medial tuberosity because of traction exerted by the tibialis posterior tendon. This infrequent injury must not be confused with the commonly seen accessory ossicle, os tibiale externum. Other navicular fractures are uncommon. (Fig. 9-140)
Cuneiform Fractures.
Isolated cuneiform fractures are rare. More frequently, fractures of the distal aspects of the cuneiforms are associated with tarsometatarsal dislocation (Lisfranc’s injury).
Cuboid Fractures.
Isolated cuboid fractures are unusual. (23) The most common site is at the most lateral margin. In children a bone scan may be required to accurately identify the fracture. (23) Care must be taken to not confuse the accessory ossicles seen adjacent to the cuboid (os peroneum, os versalium) as fractures.
Fractures of the Metatarsals
A dropped heavy object is a frequent cause of metatarsal fracture. The majority involve the shaft or neck. The fracture line may be oblique, spiral, or transverse and requires multiple views for visualization. The second and third metatarsals are the most common skeletal sites for stress fractures to occur.
Figure 9-140 TARSAL NAVICULAR FRACTURE. Medial Oblique Foot. Note the fracture through the midportion of the navicular (arrow). COMMENT: Fractures of the tarsal navicular are relatively uncommon.
Figure 9-141 JONES FRACTURE (DANCER’S FRACTURE): BASE OF FIFTH METATARSAL. A. AP Ankle. B. Lateral Ankle. Note the transverse fracture line at the base of the fifth metatarsal (arrows). COMMENT: The Jones or “dancer’s” fracture is precipitated by an avulsive force exerted from the peroneus brevis tendon and lateral cord of the plantar aponeurosis when the foot is forcefully inverted and plantar flexed. These fractures are frequently overlooked because this type of injury causes more noticeable symptoms in the area of the ankle mortise. This is one of the most frequent injuries of the foot.
Jones Fracture (Dancer’s Fracture).
Fractures of the base of the fifth metatarsal are among the most common of all bony injuries of the foot. (24,25) The synonyms are derived from Jones description, in 1902, of an injury he suffered while dancing. (21) This is a transverse fracture at the proximal end of the fifth metatarsal 15-20 mm from its base. The implicated
P.883

mechanism is traction exerted from the peroneus brevis tendon or lateral cord of the plantar aponeurosis when the foot is forcefully inverted and plantar flexed. (24) (Fig. 9-141) In children there is a longitudinally oriented apophysis adjacent to the fracture region that should not be confused with a fracture. (Fig. 9-142)
Figure 9-142 JONES FRACTURE VERSUS NORMAL VARIANT. A. Fracture, Medial Oblique Foot. Note the characteristic transverse orientation of the fracture line of the base of the fifth metatarsal (arrow). B. Normal Variation, Oblique Foot. Note the apophysis for the base of the fifth metatarsal is separated by a longitudinally oriented lucent cleft (arrowhead). With skeletal maturation, this radiolucent cleft will eventually ossify and become united to the base of the fifth metatarsal. COMMENT: In the foot of a traumatized young patient recognition of the orientation of the radiolucent cleft will distinguish between transverse fractures of the base of the fifth metatarsal and a normal vertically oriented apophyseal growth.
Clinically and radiographically, these fractures are frequently overlooked because pain and swelling from the traumatized lateral tendon sheaths and ankle ligaments misdirect the attention to the ankle mortise. The farther away the fracture is from the base, the slower it is to heal and the more it is prone to non-union owing to the intrinsically deficient blood supply. (26)
Fractures of the Phalanges
In the absence of a clinical history and multiple views of the phalanges, these are easily passed over.
Crush Injuries.
Dropping a heavy object on the toe frequently results in a comminuted phalanx, especially the distal phalanx. (Fig. 9-143)
Bedroom Fracture.
A direct blow to the toe such as when striking an object with a bare foot, may produce a fracture of any phalanx, especially those of the first and fifth digits. (Fig. 9-144)
Figure 9-143 CRUSH FRACTURE: DISTAL PHALANX. PA Foot. Note comminution of the distal phalanx (arrow), which occurred following a blow from a heavy object. (Courtesy of Robert S. Rowe, Swansea, Australia.)
P.884

Figure 9-144 BEDROOM FRACTURE. Dorsoplantar Toes. Note the oblique fracture of the shaft of the proximal phalanx of the fifth toe (arrow), which occurred after striking a hard object. (Courtesy of Gaylord H. Hanssen, DC, Doniphan, Nebraska.)
Chip Fracture.
Small fractures of the phalangeal articular margins may follow digital hyperextension or, less frequently, hyperflexion forces.
Hallux Rigidus.
A fracture of the hallux phalanx may produce a stiffened, painful first metatarsophalangeal joint. (Fig. 9-145) Initially the joint may show no alteration but later signs of degenerative arthritis can occur.
Sesamoid Fracture.
Acute fracture may complicate jumping, dancing, and running, especially if done with bare feet. Stress fractures and secondary avascular necrosis can also be found. The medial hallux sesamoid is more frequently involved than the lateral side. Localized pain and swelling over the plantar surface of the forefoot are the usual findings. The sesamoid may exhibit a single fracture line or consist of multiple fragments. A specialized axial submetatarsal view is the best method of depiction. Bone scan will show increased activity. There should be clear differentiation from the variant bipartite sesamoid, which is present in one third of the population and is bilateral in 85% of these. (27)
Dislocations
Talus Dislocation
The talus is the most common bone in the foot to dislocate. It may dislocate at three joints: the talotibial, talocalcaneal (subtalar), and talonavicular joints. These may occur singularly or together and also can precipitate avascular necrosis of the talus as a complication.
Other Tarsal Dislocations
Midtarsal Dislocation (Chopart’s Dislocation).
The midtarsal dislocation is a rare injury that separates the foot at the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. (1)
Figure 9-145 FRACTURE OF THE PROXIMAL PHALANX: GREAT TOE. PA Foot. Observe the comminuted fracture through the shaft of the proximal phalanx of the great toe, extending immediately distal to the proximal articular surface of the phalanx. COMMENT: This type of fracture may develop into a stiff, painful first metatarsal phalangeal joint (hallux rigidus).
Tarsometatarsal Fracture-Dislocation (Lisfranc’s Dislocation).
The tarsometatarsal fracture-dislocation has been named after a surgeon in Napoleon’s army—not for his description of the injury but because of his method of foot amputation through the same region. (28) The site of separation is at the tarsometatarsal junction. The components consist of dorsal dislocation of the metatarsal bases in relation to the opposing tarsals, in combination with fractures at various locations along the site of joint separation. (Fig. 9-146) In addition, there may be associated lateral displacement of the metatarsals. (29)
CT is especially useful in the accurate depiction of the injury. (30) The most common accompanying fractures are at the base of the second metatarsal and lateral cuboid surface. Lisfranc’s dislocation may predispose the tarsometatarsal joints to the development of osteoarthritis. (31) Surgical reduction with fixation appears to have a better prognostic outcome when compared to conservative methods of treatment. (32)
Lisfranc injuries, once most common with equestrian accidents, now occur most often in motor vehicle and industrial accidents. The injury usually results from a fall with longitudinal compression or a twisting force through the forefoot.
Phalangeal Dislocations
Phalangeal dislocations in the foot are not as frequent as in the hand and are readily recognizable.
P.885

Medicolegal Implications
INJURIES TO THE PELVIS AND LOWER LIMBS
  • Injuries to the pelvis may be associated with bladder and urethral injuries. Subtle fractures of the pubis and ischium are readily overlooked and frequently require oblique views for demonstration.
  • Fractures of the sacrum and coccyx are difficult to identify owing to angulation and overlying soft tissue. Special views should be employed if fracture is suspected.
  • Fractures of the femoral neck and slipped femoral capital epiphysis are common injuries in elderly and adolescent patients respectively, and carry significant morbidity if not detected. These injuries require high-quality radiographs with AP and frog-leg projections for detection.
  • Injuries to the knee most commonly produce ligamentous and meniscal lesions that have few plain film changes. MRI is often required in such circumstances. However, AP tunnel, lateral, and skyline views should always be obtained initially.
  • Ankle injuries require routine use of AP, AP medial oblique, and lateral views to detect bony lesions. Accessory ossicles at the malleolar tips and the os trigonum can be readily confused variants.
  • Growth plate injuries in the developing skeleton should be monitored beyond the healing time to assess for growth deformity. Periodic x-ray examination at 3-, 6-, and 12-month intervals should be considered as clinically indicated.
  • Foot injuries can lead to considerable disability if unrecognized. Minimum views of dorsoplantar, medial oblique dorsoplantar, and lateral projections must be performed.
Figure 9-146 TARSOMETATARSAL FRACTURE-DISLOCATION (LISFRANC’S DISLOCATION). PA Foot. Note that displacement of the second through the fifth metatarsal bases has occurred, with associated fractures in the area of diastasis (arrow) between the bases of the first and second metatarsals. The injury usually results from a fall with longitudinal compression or a twisting force through the forefoot. (Courtesy of Gary M. Fieber, DC, Minneapolis, Minnesota.)
FRACTURES OF THE THORAX
General Considerations
Significant force is usually required to produce a fractured rib. They are uncommon injuries of childhood, but with advancing age the incidence gradually increases, especially after the 3rd decade, as the bones become more rigid and brittle. (1) It is estimated that 10% of all traumatic injuries will have an associated rib fracture. (2)
Of all fractures, those involving the ribs are the most difficult to observe owing to the curvilinear shape of the rib. They usually require multiple oblique views to orient the fracture line to a plane where the x-ray beam can pass directly through the separation. It is to be expected that up to 50% of rib fractures will go undetected on the initial screening x-rays, (2) only becoming visible later when enough callus is present.
In general, a single AP radiograph is insufficient for the accurate diagnosis of rib fracture and must be supplemented by multiple oblique projections. Ultrasonography is superior to plain film images in identifying suspected fractures. (3) In a clinical study, sonography revealed approximately 78% of fractures compared with 12% identified on plain film during the initial examination. (3) Bone scan will demonstrate singular or multiple rib fractures. (Fig. 9-147) Occasionally, the bone scan may assist in the evaluation of the traumatized patient, for medicolegal purposes.
Radiologic Features of Rib Fractures
A number of features should be searched for to aid in locating a rib fracture. (Fig. 9-148) (Table 9-15)
Fracture Line.
When present, the fracture line will usually cross the rib transversely or obliquely and will be radiolucent. Care
P.886

must be taken to not misinterpret overlying bronchial air shadows as fracture lines, as evidenced by the lung markings continuing beyond the bony rib margin.
Figure 9-147 RIB FRACTURES: BONE SCAN FEATURES. Note that multiple focal areas of increased radioisotopic uptake are present in the anterior ribs. These areas correspond to the sites of rib fractures that were not clearly identifiable on the plain film examination. COMMENT: In view of the difficulty in locating rib fractures, this procedure is particularly useful in medicolegal and equivocal clinical circumstances. (Courtesy of Lawrence A. Cooperstein, MD, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.)
Figure 9-148 GENERAL FEATURES OF RIB FRACTURES. Observe the multiple fracture sites (arrows). Rib fractures can be identified by searching for a fracture line, cortical offset, or altered rib angulation and, when multiple, following along the line of injury, looking for additional lesions.
Table 9-15 Radiologic Features of Rib Fractures

Radiolucent fracture line

Cortical offset

Altered rib orientation

Pleural deflection

Callus formation

Pleural fluid

Pneumothorax

Subcutaneous emphysema

Diaphragmatic elevation
Cortical Offset.
Cortical offset is a most important feature that is frequently seen without visualizing the fracture line. The superior and inferior cortices will be acutely offset at the fracture site, as evidenced by a sharp step effect.
Rib Orientation.
A sharp deviation in the contour of a single rib may occur at the fracture site. If the distal end of the fractured rib appears hook-like (costal hook sign), this may indicate a flail segment.
Callus Formation.
If callus has begun to form, there will be a localized increase in density and a bulbous expansion at the fracture site. (Fig. 9-149)
Figure 9-149 HEALING RIB FRACTURES. Two sites of healing rib fractures are identified (arrows). Radiographic features consist of a localized region of increased density, bony expansion of the rib at the fracture site, and visualization of the fracture line. COMMENT: These rib fractures were not apparent on the initial radiographic examination after a chronic episode of coughing. Follow-up radiographs revealed callus formation, which now localizes the previously unrecognized fracture sites.
P.887

Pleural Deflection.
A localized hematoma adjacent to the fracture site may displace the pleura inward, indenting into the lung. When the x-ray beam is tangential to the accumulated blood, this will be seen as a radiopaque density that is sharply demarcated, convex toward the lung, gradually blending beyond the fracture site into its normal position (extrapleural sign).
Other Fractures
Multiple rib fractures are usually aligned in a linear fashion along the vector of trauma. The ipsilateral costophrenic recess may be blunted owing to sanguineous pleural fluid. Other associations include pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema, diaphragmatic elevation, and splenic laceration.
Upper Rib Fractures
The upper three ribs (ribs one to three) rarely fracture owing to their inherent strength and supporting musculature. (4) The presence of such upper rib fractures suggests the likelihood of severe trauma with possible injuries to the trachea, aorta, great vessels, brachial plexus, or spine. (Fig. 9-150) Weightlifters may incur fracture of the second rib during heavy bench pressing. (4) Stress fractures of the first rib can occur in throwing athletes. (5)
Middle Rib Fractures
Ribs four to nine are the most commonly fractured. The fracture site depends on the mechanism of injury but frequently is found at the lateral aspect of the rib, where it is easily overlooked. (Fig. 9-151) Fractures of these ribs therefore require multiple views for adequate depiction. An extrapleural collection of hematoma may be represented by an inward deflection of the pleura at the site of fracture. (6) Fractures of the middle to lower anterior ribs should stimulate close scrutiny of the spleen and liver for associated injury.
Figure 9-150 FIRST RIB FRACTURE. Note the single fracture line traversing the first rib, just distal to the costotransverse joint (arrow). COMMENT: Fractures of the upper ribs are frequently associated with severe trauma and additional injuries to the trachea, aorta, great vessels, brachial plexus, or spine.
Flail Chest.
The term flail chest is used to describe the occurrence of two fractures involving the same rib, isolating a section of the rib. Usually, multiple adjacent ribs are affected, which allows these isolated rib fragments (flail segment) to move during respiration in an opposite direction (paradoxical motion). This reduces ventilation of the underlying lung to interfere with pulmonary gaseous exchange, potentially creating a life-threatening situation. A radiologic clue to a flail chest is that the isolated rib section rotates and exhibits a hook-like distal end on the frontal radiograph (costal hook sign).
Golfer’s Fracture.
On occasion a golfer may inadvertently strike the ground rather than the ball. This abrupt termination of the swing is sometimes forceful enough to precipitate a fracture of a rib at its lateral margin.
Passion (Bear Hug) Fracture.
Fracture of a rib can occasionally be precipitated when one is the recipient of an over-enthusiastic hug. The presence of osteopenia may predispose the elderly to these fractures.
Figure 9-151 MULTIPLE RIB FRACTURES WITH SUBCUTANEOUS EMPHYSEMA. Note the multiple rib fractures affecting the posterolateral surface (arrows). COMMENT: These are associated with subcutaneous emphysema in the over-lying soft tissues. Subcutaneous emphysema is a sign of severe pulmonary injury, allowing direct communication between the bronchial tree and the extrathoracic soft tissues.
P.888

Figure 9-152 LOWER RIB FRACTURES. Note the fracture lines through both the eleventh and twelfth ribs (arrows), with minimal displacement. COMMENT: The presence of fractures of the lower ribs warrants careful examination of the urinary system, especially renal function and structure. This should include an intravenous pyelogram and/or CT.
Lower Rib Fractures
Ribs ten to twelve are uncommonly fractured because they are relatively mobile and yielding; however, if a fracture is observed, associated kidney damage should be evaluated. (Fig. 9-152)
Cough (Post-Tussive) Fracture.
In any condition in which persistent and/or violent coughing is experienced, stress fractures of the lower anterior ribs may occur. (7) (Fig. 9-149) The sixth to seventh anterior ribs are the most common sites. (8)
Costal Cartilage Injuries
Costal cartilage injuries on plain films generally cannot be discerned. If calcified, fractures can be identified as a disruption. Nuclear bone scanning and CT will assist in their evaluation.
Fractures of the Sternum.
Blunt compressive impacts to the chest, such as from the steering wheel or seat belt in motor vehicle accidents, are the major causes of sternal injury. (9) The most common sites of fracture involve the body or manubriosternal junction and are usually transverse in nature. Compared with plain film imaging, ultrasonography is more sensitive in the identification of sternal fractures but radiographic examination remains the imaging modality of choice in clinical situations. (10,11,12) Radiographic examination will allow the examiner to better grade the degree of displacement, and the best projection is the lateral view. (11,13) On this projection a fracture line, displacement, and associated hematoma may be observed. (12) (Fig. 9-153) CT may be required for optimal visualization of the sternum. All sternal injuries should point to careful evaluation of the thoracolumbar spine for associated abnormalities. (14) Cardiac complications may also result from these injuries. (15)
Figure 9-153 STERNAL FRACTURE WITH DISPLACEMENT. Note the complete fracture through the body of the sternum, with displacement and overlap (arrows) across the fracture site. COMMENT: Sternal injuries are uncommon and usually follow severe blunt trauma to the anterior thorax.
Complications
Various tissues and organs may suffer damage in association with injuries of the thorax. (14)
Pleural Complications
Traumatic Pneumothorax.
Intrapleural negative pressure functions to maintain lung inflation. When the pleura is torn, this pressure is lost, allowing the lung to collapse.
Hemothorax Complications.
Blood may accumulate in the pleural space from ruptured blood vessels. This can be identified by observing blunt costophrenic sulci, widening of the paraspinal space, and apical “capping.” (14)
Chylothorax Complications.
Lymphatic fluid may accumulate in the same manner as does blood.
Lung Complications
Contusion.
Intrapulmonary hemorrhage can produce an irregular, localized lung opacity. This appears shortly after the injury and then gradually resorbs within 3-10 days.
P.889

Pneumonia.
Pneumonia may complicate the immobility of the chest following a rib fracture, owing to the inactivation of the normal lung fluid-clearing mechanisms.
Other Tissue Complications
Various associated injuries have been reported, including rupture of the spleen, diaphragm, tracheobronchial tree, esophagus, kidney, and heart as well as formation of aortic aneurysms and lung cysts. (14) Thoracic spine lesions are also common. Elderly patients tend to have a higher morbidity from rib fractures owing to these complications. (16)
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE SHOULDER GIRDLE
The shoulder girdle is vulnerable to damage, but the specific site of injury varies with age. Fracture of the clavicle is the most common skeletal injury during birth and childhood. (Fig. 9-154) Between 20 and 40 years of age, dislocation of the shoulder, acromioclavicular joint separation, and clavicle fractures predominate. In the elderly, shoulder dislocations and surgical neck fractures of the humerus become increasingly more common.
Figure 9-154 BIRTH FRACTURE OF THE CLAVICLE. Note that a midclavicular fracture (arrow) has occurred during the birth process. COMMENT: Fracture of the clavicle is the most common birth fracture.
Figure 9-155 CLAVICLE FRACTURE EVALUATION: ANGULATED VERSUS NON-ANGULATED PROJECTIONS. A. Non-angulated AP Clavicle. Note that no fracture line is visible on this view. B. Angulated Clavicle. Observe that with 15° cephalad tube angulation, the fracture line is clearly evident (arrow). COMMENT: In evaluation of clavicular trauma, specific clavicle projections must be obtained to demonstrate fractures, particularly through the midportion of the clavicle. (Courtesy of Kenneth E. Yochum, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Technologically, the shoulder girdle requires specific projections for proper evaluation. A minimum general survey of the shoulder should include AP views with internal rotation, external rotation, and abduction (baby arm). At least one view should include the upper thoracic cage and lung to the spine. Additional specific projections for the acromioclavicular joint, clavicle, and scapula must be performed, as clinically indicated, for optimum evaluation. A hot light should be routinely used to view the shoulder structures, owing to inherent overexposure of thinner body areas such as the distal clavicle and acromioclavicular joint.
Fractures of the Clavicle
Technologic Features
The S shape and normal overlap with the upper rib cage renders the clavicle a difficult structure to evaluate on straight AP projections. (Fig. 9-155) The optimal view is an AP projection with
P.890

15° cephalad tube angulation. Weights (10 -15 lb) may be held to aid in detecting undisplaced fractures. The exposure factors should be approximately half of that used in standard shoulder projections to prevent overexposure.
Radiologic Features
Clavicular fractures account for up to 15% of all fractures (1) and approximately 44% of shoulder girdle fractures. (2) The clavicle is generally the bone most commonly fractured during birth. In children and adolescence, sporting and traffic accidents are the most common cause of clavicular fractures. (2,3) Studies have shown the incidence of these fractures decreases progressively with age. (2- 4) Direct trauma to the shoulder is the usual mechanism of injury. Males account for approximately two thirds of the individuals that sustain clavicular fractures. (2)
Medial Clavicle Fractures.
The medial clavicle is the least common site of fracture, representing only about 5% of all clavicle fractures. (5,6) These are difficult to observe and usually require CT.
Middle Clavicle Fractures.
The middle clavicle is the most common site of fracture, representing 75-80% of all clavicle fractures. (4,7) A force applied to the distal end of the S-shaped clavicle creates a shearing effect at the middle third, producing the fracture. (8) The fracture is usually complete, with displacement occurring in about 50% of cases. (2) Comminuted fractures will occur in approximately 19% of injuries. (2) With displacement, the medial fragment is elevated by the action of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and the lateral fragment depressed by the weight of the shoulder and upper extremity. (Fig. 9-156) In addition to malalignment, an overlap at the fracture site is common, with the distal fragment usually lying below the medial fragment. Healing is often associated with extensive callus formation and few patients require surgical repair. (9) (Fig. 9-157)
Lateral Clavicle Fractures.
Lateral clavicle fractures account for 15 -25% of all clavicle fractures. (4,7) There are three varieties: undisplaced; displaced, in which the distal fragment moves anterior and inferior; and articular surface extension. (Fig. 9-158)
Whenever a fracture of the lateral third is identified, weight-bearing stress views should be obtained to clarify the status of the coracoclavicular ligaments. (10) Notably, fractures that extend into the joint frequently precipitate the onset of degenerative arthritis irrespective of treatment. (11) Displaced fractures generally benefit from early surgical intervention. (12)
Complications of Clavicle Injuries
Childhood and adolescent clavicular fractures heal without sequelae in up to 95% of cases. (4) In adults the incidence of complications increases.
Neurovascular Damage.
Associated injury to the underlying neurovascular structures most frequently involves the subclavian artery; less commonly, the vein; and, occasionally, the brachial
P.891

plexus and sympathetic chain. (13) Compressive effects from the hypertrophic callus can also precipitate pressure-related neurovascular disturbances. (7,14)
Figure 9-156 MIDCLAVICULAR FRACTURE. AP Clavicle. Note that a fracture through the midportion of the clavicle has resulted in superior displacement of the medial portion and inferior displacement of the lateral portion.
Figure 9-157 HEALING CLAVICULAR FRACTURE. Observe the exuberant callus formation (arrow) adjacent to a midclavicular fracture. This degree of callus formation is a frequent finding in the healing phase of these injuries. COMMENT: Callus formation of this extent may lead to significant cosmetic disfiguration and compromise of the thoracic outlet.
Figure 9-158 FRACTURE OF THE DISTAL CLAVICLE. Note the fracture line through the distal surface of the clavicle (arrow). COMMENT: Fractures in this location are frequently overlooked owing to technical overexposure. Bright light illumination is required for clear identification. These fractures frequently predispose the patient to degenerative arthritis of the acromioclavicular articulation.
Figure 9-159 POST-TRAUMATIC OSTEOLYSIS OF THE CLAVICLE. A. AP Acromioclavicular Joint. Note that 2 months after trauma to the shoulder, a cystic rarefaction (arrow) is present at the inferior aspect of the distal articular surface of the clavicle. B. AP Acromioclavicular Joint. Note that there has been extension of the area of rarefaction in the distal clavicle involving the entire distal surface (arrow). Observe the smooth and regular articular margins of the acromial surface, differentiating it from inflammatory joint diseases (rheumatoid arthritis and septic arthritis). COMMENT: This disorder follows a self-limiting course and resolves with varying degrees of reconstitution of the resorbed bone. (Courtesy of Leo J. Bronston, DC, DABCO, Sparta, Wisconsin.)
Non-Union.
Non-union occurs in approximately 5% of cases. (4) Failure of the fracture to unite requires surgical fixation. The key signs of non-union are located at the fracture margins, where sclerosis, rounding, and a smooth contour will be visible. Shortening of the fracture margins of > 1.5 cm and lack of callus formation within 6 weeks of injury is a sign of non-union requiring surgical intervention. (1,15) The site of the fracture appears to be unrelated to the likelihood for non-union to occur. (4)
Malunion.
In the presence of fragment overlap and massive callus formation, a cosmetic deformity and functional impairment may result. (16) Correction requires osteotomy, realignment, and fixation. (17)
Degenerative Arthritis.
Painful degenerative arthritis frequently follows intra-articular fractures of the clavicle. This is evidenced by loss of joint space, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation.
Post-Traumatic Osteolysis.
An injury response peculiar to the clavicle is bone resorption of the distal segment, usually 1-3 mm, and never more than 2-3 cm. (18) This is a commonly overlooked shoulder condition requiring properly exposed radiographs depicting the acromioclavicular joint adequately. (18)
The initiating injury may be relatively minor, often lacking the severity of that required to cause a fracture or dislocation. It first becomes radiologically visible 2-3 months after injury. The precise mechanism is uncertain, although synovial hypertrophy suggests inflammatory osteoclastic activity. (19) Pain is mild to moderate, whereas the disorder takes a self-limiting course over a number of months. It is common in weightlifters.
The earliest radiographic sign in the development of osteolysis is a cystic rarefaction of the clavicular subarticular cortex, followed by cortical dissolution. (19,20) The joint appears wide and the clavicular surface is frayed and irregular or cup shaped. (18) (Fig. 9-159) With healing, there are varying degrees of bony reconstitution from complete restoration of structure to a permanently tapered distal clavicle and increased joint space.
Fractures of the Scapula
Severe trauma is usually needed to fracture the scapula. Isolated scapular fractures are infrequent, with approximately 80% demonstrating other injuries. (21,22) Occasionally exercises such as push-ups may cause a fracture. (23) Routine shoulder views usually adequately demonstrate the scapula; however, special projections may be required for a more thorough examination. (24)
Coracoid View (Axillary or Scapular Y View).
The coracoid view is performed AP, with 25-40° of cephalad tube tilt.
Lateral View.
The lateral view is performed PA, with the patient rotated 35°. It produces a tangential depiction of the scapula body and acromion.
Axillary View.
The axillary view is performed superior-inferior, with the cassette in the axilla and the arm abducted. It demonstrates the glenoid, acromion, and coracoid process.
Radiologic Features of Scapular Fractures
The majority of fractures involve the scapular body and neck (80%). (21) (Fig. 9-160) When the coracoid or acromion fractures,
P.892

it is usually in the midportion at the narrowest dimension. An avulsion corresponding to the triceps insertion is often seen at the inferior glenoid rim in association with anterior humeral dislocations (Bankart lesion). (25)
Figure 9-160 SCAPULAR FRACTURE. AP Shoulder. Observe the oblique fracture line in the subglenoid axillary border of the scapula. An associated rib fracture (arrow) is also seen. COMMENT: The body and neck are the most common sites of scapular fractures. (Courtesy of Gail J. Keilman, DC, Minneapolis, Minnesota.)
Fractures of the Humerus
Most humeral fractures can be identified on standard AP views in internal and external rotation.
Radiologic Features
Fractures of the proximal humerus are often described by the Neer classification. (26) There are four categories based on the fracture location: anatomic neck, greater tuberosity, lesser tuberosity, and surgical neck. Fractures of the proximal shaft are not included. The number of these fractures are then added to each other—one part, two parts, three parts, or four parts. Up to 80% of cases are one-part fractures; 10% are two-part, 3% are three-part, and 4% are four-part fractures. (26,27) CT is useful in identifying fragments and articular involvement. Surgical fixation is the treatment of choice, and the procedures used vary depending on the fracture pattern. (28)
Fractures Proximal to the Anatomic Neck.
Isolated fractures through the anatomic neck are uncommon and usually occur in combination with other humeral fractures. There is a high incidence of developing avascular necrosis of the humeral head. (10) Comminuted fractures of the humeral head are referred to as head-splitting fractures. (26)
An impaction fracture on the posterolateral surface of the humeral head is commonly associated with anterior shoulder dislocation. The mechanism is related to the effect of the inferior glenoid rim being forcefully pushed into the articular surface of the humeral head (Hill-Sachs defect, hatchet defect). (29) The optimal projection to demonstrate the defect is internal rotation.
Figure 9-161 FLAP FRACTURE: GREATER TUBEROSITY. AP Shoulder. Note the displaced fracture of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, which is recognized by the presence of a radiolucent line (arrow). COMMENT: This fracture is best identified in the external rotation view because the greater tuberosity is brought into profile in this projection.
Fractures of the Greater Tuberosity (Flap Fracture).
The greater tuberosity may be avulsed by the connecting tendons or fractured by direct trauma. (Fig. 9-161) It is frequently fractured during anterior humeral dislocation. (Fig. 9-162) Generally, older patients show a smaller separated fragment than younger individuals.
This fracture is best depicted on the external rotation view. Displacement of > 1 cm indicates significant rotator cuff disruption. This necessitates open reduction and repair. (14)
Fractures of the Lesser Tuberosity.
The lesser tuberosity is not vulnerable to isolated trauma. (30) More commonly it occurs in conjunction with other proximal humeral fractures.
Fractures of the Surgical Neck.
The surgical neck is the most common site of proximal humerus fractures. (Figs. 9-163 and 9-164) The site of the fracture is immediately distal to the tuberosities, at the narrowest point of humeral width. These fractures tend to be comminuted, involving the adjacent tuberosities. Anteromedial displacement of the shaft distal to the fracture frequently occurs because of the pull of the pectoralis major muscle. On occasion, injury to the adjacent axillary nerve and artery may complicate the fracture, warranting a detailed examination. (31)
Fractures of the Proximal Shaft.
Direct trauma is the most common cause for shaft fractures. The relative location of the fracture in relation to muscle insertions determines the type of deformity produced. (14) If the fracture occurs proximal to the pectoralis major attachment, the humeral head will abduct and rotate. Between the pectoralis major and the deltoid, the proximal fragment will adduct. Distal to the deltoid, the proximal fragment will abduct.
P.893

Figure 9-162 FLAP FRACTURE ASSOCIATED WITH ANTERIOR GLENOHUMERAL DISLOCATION. Note the humeral head is dislocated anteriorly and inferiorly to a subcoracoid position. This is associated with an avulsion fracture of the greater tuberosity of the humerus (flap fracture) (arrow).
Figure 9-163 SURGICAL NECK FRACTURE: SHOULDER. Observe that a transverse comminuted fracture has occurred through the surgical neck of the humerus. There has been extension of the fracture line to involve the greater tuberosity (flap fracture) (arrow).
Figure 9-164 TORUS FRACTURE OF THE PROXIMAL HUMERUS. A. External Rotation, AP Shoulder. Observe the localized bulging of the cortical surface of the medial metaphysis of the proximal humerus (arrow). B. Internal Rotation, AP Shoulder. Note the cortical bulging, which involves both the medial and the lateral aspects of the proximal humerus (arrows). This is a characteristic finding of a torus fracture. COMMENT: In young patients, the normal cartilaginous growth center (arrowheads) should not be misinterpreted as a fracture line. (Courtesy of Gerald A. Fitzgerald, MD, Sydney, Australia.)
P.894

Complications of Humeral Fractures
Complications of humeral fractures include residual joint stiffness, non-union, malunion, degenerative joint disease, head avascular necrosis, post-traumatic myositis ossificans, and neurovascular damage. (31)
Dislocations
The shoulder joint is by far the most common joint in the body to dislocate, accounting for > 50% of all joint dislocations. (14) Of the four joint complexes that make up the shoulder girdle, dislocations at the glenohumeral joint are the most frequent, being involved in 85% of cases. The acromioclavicular joint makes up 12%, the sternoclavicular joint 2%, and the scapulothoracic joint only 1%. (32)
Glenohumeral Joint Dislocations
Dislocations of the glenohumeral joint are classified further into the direction in which the humeral head has been displaced: anterior, posterior, inferior, and superior.
Anterior Dislocation.
Anterior dislocation is the most frequent dislocation of the shoulder, (33) making up approximately 95% of glenohumeral displacements. (34) (Fig. 9-165) The mechanism of injury is forceful abduction and external rotation. (34) Commonly,
P.895

associated fractures include impaction of the humeral head in 60% of cases (Hill-Sachs defect), fracture of the greater tuberosity in 15% of cases, humeral avulsion of the glenohumeral ligament (HAGL lesion) (35) and, less frequently, avulsion of the inferior glenoid rim (Bankart lesion). (14) (Figs. 9-166 and 9-167) The complications resulting from shoulder dislocations are numerous. (36) The presence of fracture often complicates the reduction of anterior dislocations, requiring some to be performed under general anesthesia. (37) In younger populations, the most common complication is reoccurrence (33); in individuals > 40 years of age, the reoccurrence rate is only about 4%. (38) A 10- to 20-fold increase for the development of arthritis within the shoulder has been noted in patients with dislocation. (39) Degenerative changes of the rotator cuff can prolong the morbidity of these injuries, especially in older individuals. (38) In patients with an associated HAGL lesion, up to 9% will experience anterior instability of the glenohumeral joint. (35)
Figure 9-165 SUBCORACOID ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE SHOULDER. Note that the humeral head has been dislocated anteriorly in a subcoracoid position. COMMENT: This is the most common form of shoulder dislocation.
Figure 9-166 HILL-SACHS DEFORMITY ASSOCIATED WITH ANTERIOR HUMERAL DISLOCATION. A. AP Shoulder. Note that an anteroinferior dislocation of the humerus has resulted in an impaction between the inferior glenoid rim and the opposing humeral head (arrow). The impaction by the angular surface of the inferior glenoid rim produces the articular defect that has been referred to as the hatchet deformity (Hill-Sachs defect). B. Postreduction, AP Shoulder. Note that after repositioning of the humeral head within the glenoid fossa, the residual effect of compression of the articular surface is clearly identified (arrow). COMMENT: The identification of this Hill-Sachs lesion is a telltale sign of recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.
Figure 9-167 BANKART’S LESION: SCAPULA. AP Shoulder. An avulsion fracture of the inferior glenoid rim (arrow) at the insertion of the triceps muscle frequently accompanies anterior shoulder dislocations.
Figure 9-168 POSTERIOR SHOULDER DISLOCATION. A. AP Shoulder. Note the double cortical surface located on the medial aspect of the humeral head (arrows). This is called the trough line sign and represents impaction of the humeral head on the posterior glenoid surface. B. AP Shoulder. Note the curvilinear radiopacity spanning across the metaphysis of the proximal humerus (arrow) owing to severe internal rotation of the humerus (tennis racquet appearance). COMMENT: Posterior shoulder dislocations are uncommon, accounting for 2-4% of glenohumeral dislocations. They most commonly follow either an epileptic convulsion, an electric shock (accidental or therapeutic), or direct trauma.
According to where the humeral head comes to rest, positional terms are applied—subglenoid, subcoracoid (most common), subclavicular, and (if trapped between two ribs) intrathoracic. Radiologic signs include inferior and medial humeral displacement, altered humeral head shape, and the Hill-Sachs and Bankart’s lesions. (5) MRI is extremely sensitive and specific in localizing a Hill-Sachs defect. (40)
Posterior Dislocation.
Posterior dislocations are uncommon displacements, making up 2-4% of glenohumeral dislocations. They follow epileptic convulsion, electric shock (accidental or therapeutic), or extreme trauma, giving posterior dislocations the term triple E syndrome. (41,42,43) Rarely do these injuries occur bilaterally. When a bilateral presentation exists in the absence of trauma, it is almost pathognomonic of seizure-induced dislocations. (43) These are difficult lesions to identify radiographically.
The key radiographic signs are widening of the joint space > 6 mm (rim sign), double articular surface line (trough line sign), lack of humeral head-glenoid fossa overlap, lack of close contact at the anterior joint margin (vacant glenoid sign), cystic appearance of the head (tennis racquet appearance), and superior displacement. (14,44,45,46) (Fig. 9-168) Inherent in the displacement
P.896

is the fact that it is fixed into internal rotation such that no difference in the appearance of the head in the external rotation view is seen. Rarely, avulsion injuries of the posterior labrum accompany posterior dislocations. (47)
Inferior Dislocation (Luxatio Erecta).
Inferior dislocation follows severe hyperabduction trauma in such a way that the humeral neck contacts the acromion, which acts as a fulcrum to lever the humeral head out and displace it inferiorly. The humerus then locks into this hyperabduction position, with the humeral head displaced into a subglenoid position.
Occasionally, the humerus may be only partially subluxed inferiorly (drooping shoulder, hanging shoulder). This is seen in hemarthrosis, joint effusion, stroke, and brachial plexus lesions. (48)
Superior Dislocation.
Superior dislocation is a rare type of dislocation requiring considerable force, usually with the elbow flexed and the arm adducted. More commonly experienced is the superior displacement of the humeral head after a tear of the rotator cuff tendon. This reduces the downward holding power of the infraspinatus tendon, allowing the relatively unopposed action of the deltoid to elevate the humerus, which, in long-standing cases, may form a pseudo-joint with the undersurface of the clavicle and acromion. If the acromiohumeral distance measures < 7 mm, this is an indicator of rotator cuff tear. (49,50)
Rotator Cuff Tears.
Traumatic and degenerative lesions of the rotator cuff are common injuries. Generally, the incidence of rotator cuff injuries increases with age and the diagnosis and treatment becomes progressively delayed. Clinical assessment with palpation for the defect may be as high as 95% accurate. (51) Plain film signs are few and consist of an elevated humeral head in relation to the glenoid fossa (unopposed action of the deltoid), narrowing of the acromiohumeral joint space, erosion with sclerosis on the undersurface of the acromion, and non-specific roughening with cysts at the greater tuberosity. Arthrography shows extravasation of contrast beyond the capsule, with up to 85% sensitivity. (51,52) Ultrasound, despite being operator and equipment dependent and impaired by tendon calcification mimicking tears, is 60-85% sensitive in locating tears. (51,53) MRI is useful in locating and quantifying tears of the rotator cuff while ruling out differential diagnoses. (54,55) MRI is up to 100% sensitive for depicting tears > 2 cm. (51,56) In cases of traumatic rotator cuff injuries, occult greater tuberosity fractures and subscapularis tears are frequently associated injuries and are identified with MRI. (57)
Glenoid Labral Tears (SLAP Lesions).
Glenoid labral tears involve the superior portion of the glenoid labrum and are associated with shoulder instability. SLAP is an acronym used to summarize the location of the tear (superior labrum anterior to posterior). MRI is the imaging modality of choice, demonstrating labral avulsion, absence, or a cleft. (58)
Acromioclavicular Joint Separations
The optimal radiographic views are AP projections with 15° of cephalad tilt and with and without 10-15 lb of weight. These should be done bilaterally, for comparison purposes. An AP view with internal rotation performed without weights may show grade III tears owing to scapular motion. (59)
Radiologic Features.
Three landmarks are assessed on weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing views to evaluate displacement at the acromioclavicular joint.
  • Acromioclavicular joint space. Normally, the space is bilaterally symmetrical, within 2-3 mm of each other, and averages between 2 and 4 mm in absolute width. (60)
  • Acromioclavicular joint alignment. The inferior and superior margins of the clavicle and opposing acromion should be in smooth horizontal alignment.
  • Coracoclavicular distance. The distance between the inferior margin of the clavicle and the closest surface of the coracoid is normally 11-13 mm. There should be no more than 5 mm difference in the measurement from right to left. (14,61)
Classification of Acromioclavicular Injuries.
(14,26). Acromioclavicular injuries are usually classed based on the degree of injury to the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments. (Fig. 9-169) (Table 9-16)
Type I (Mild Sprain).
In type I sprains, the acromioclavicular ligament is stretched but not disrupted, and the coracoclavicular ligament is intact. (Fig. 9-170, A and B) Even on weight-bearing views, no discernible increase in the joint space or altered alignment is visible. These are treated conservatively.
Figure 9-169 LIGAMENTS OF THE ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT. Note the locations of the acromioclavicular ligaments (1) and the coracoclavicular ligaments (2).
Table 9-16 Classification of Acromioclavicular Joint Lesions

Ligament Integrity

Type

Severity

Acromioclavicular

Coracoclavicular

X-Ray Findings

I

Mild

Stretched

Normal

None

II

Moderate

Disrupted

Stretched

Wide joint space; slight clavicle elevation

III

Severe

Disrupted

Disrupted

Wide joint space; severe clavicle elevation
P.897

Figure 9-170 CLASSIFICATION OF ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT INJURIES. A and B. Type I (Mild Sprain), AP. Note that the acromioclavicular ligament is stretched but not disrupted, and the coracoclavicular ligament is intact. No discernible increase in the joint space or altered alignment is visible. C and D. Type II (Moderate Sprain), AP. Observe that the acromioclavicular ligament is torn and the coracoclavicular ligament is stretched but intact (arrow). The joint space is widened, and slight elevation of the clavicular head has occurred. E and F. Type III (Severe Sprain), AP. Note the complete disruption of the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments (arrow). There is widening of the joint space, distinct elevation of the clavicle, and widening of the coracoclavicular space (C).
P.898

Type II (Moderate Sprain).
The acromioclavicular ligament is torn and the coracoclavicular ligaments are stretched but intact in a type II injury. (Fig. 9-170, C and D) Radiographically, the joint space is widened and slight elevation of the clavicle has occurred. These are initially treated conservatively, with a brace, but may require surgery. Old injuries to the coracoclavicular ligament may manifest as ligamentous ossifications.
Type III (Severe Sprain).
In type III sprains, both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments are completely disrupted. (Fig. 9-170, E and F) Radiographic signs include widened joint space, distinctive elevation of the distal clavicle above the acromion, and a coracoclavicular space that is widened > 5 mm more than its contralateral counterpart. The separation can be shown on an AP non-weight-bearing view with internal rotation. (59) These may require joint repair and open fixation, although conservative treatment has been shown to be beneficial. (62)
Sternoclavicular Joint Dislocation
Sir Astley Cooper first described the dislocation of the sternoclavicular joint in 1824; but dislocations of this joint are exceedingly rare, with only about 100 cases being documented. (63,64) The infrequency of injury to this joint has led to decreased knowledge about the joint and under-recognition of related injuries. (65) The mechanism of injury is usually severe trauma. Anterior displacements of the clavicle are more frequent than posterior dislocation and the latter is considered a potentially life-threatening injury. (63) CT is the technique of choice to demonstrate a sternoclavicular lesion. (63,64)
Scapulothoracic Joint Dislocation
Severe trauma or thoracoplasty to the upper posterior ribs is required to produce the rare scapulothoracic joint dislocation. Synonyms include locked scapula and scapulothoracic dissociation. (66)
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE ELBOW AND FOREARM
Approximately 6% of all fractures and dislocations involve the elbow. (1) The frequency of injury at various sites around the elbow differ between adults and children. (2) (Table 9-17) In adults, approximately 50% of elbow fractures involve the radial head or neck; 20%, the olecranon; 10%, the supracondylar region of the humerus; and 15%, combinations of fracture-dislocations. Unusual sites of fracture involve the humeral condyles, proximal ulna, capitellum, and coronoid process. In children, the most common fracture site is the supracondylar region of the humerus, accounting for about 60% of all childhood elbow injuries. The lateral condyle accounts for 15%, and separation of the medial epicondyle ossification center accounts for 10%. The remaining childhood elbow lesions include the olecranon, proximal ulna, radial epiphysis, and dislocations.
Table 9-17 Incidence and Location of Elbow Injuries

Adults

Children

Location

Incidence (%)

Location

Incidence (%)

Radial head and neck

50

Supracondylar

60

Olecranon

20

Lateral condyle

15

Supracondylar

10

Medial epicondyle

10

Fracture-dislocations

15

Unrecognized elbow fractures frequently produce residual loss of joint mobility and, at times, superimposed degenerative arthritis. The joint and osseous anatomy is complex and requires specific projections for adequate demonstration. (3) A minimum elbow study should include the following views: (a) AP in full extension, (b) medial oblique, (c) lateral, and (d) axial olecranon projections. In children, confusing growth variations may occasionally be clarified by obtaining similar views of the uninvolved articulation.
Fractures and dislocations of the forearm usually follow significant trauma and are normally readily observable. Standard AP and lateral projections usually suffice to provide the necessary information required.
Fractures of the Elbow
Distal Humerus Fractures
Distal humerus fractures are normally easily recognized. Notably, up to 95% of these fractures extend to disrupt the articular surface. Fractures are classified according to their relationship with the condyles and the shape of the fracture line.
Supracondylar Fractures.
In supracondylar fractures, the fracture line extends transversely or obliquely through the distal humerus above the condyles. (Fig. 9-171) This is the most common
P.899

fracture to occur around the elbow in children (60%). Usually, the distal fracture fragment displaces posteriorly. Conservative care using functional bracing is the treatment of choice. (4)
Figure 9-171 SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE OF THE HUMERUS. Note the complete comminuted fracture through the supracondylar region of the humerus. Significant posterior displacement of the distal fragment has also occurred. COMMENT: This is the most common fracture of the elbow in children.
Intercondylar Fracture.
In intercondylar fractures, the fracture line extends between the medial and lateral condyles and communicates with the supracondylar region. The resultant fracture line may take on a T or Y configuration. This type of fracture in adults accounts for at least 50% of distal humerus fractures. (5)
Figure 9-172 MEDIAL EPICONDYLE FRACTURE. AP Elbow. Note that an avulsion fracture of the medial epicondyle has occurred (arrow). COMMENT: A similar injury in a developing child or adolescent has been called Little Leaguer’s elbow and is usually associated with sports requiring strong throwing motions.
Figure 9-173 OLECRANON FRACTURE WITH REPAIR. A. Lateral Elbow. Note the two fracture lines through the olecranon process. The proximal fragment has retracted owing to the pull of the triceps muscle. B. Lateral Elbow. A surgical pin has been placed longitudinally through the proximal ulna to realign the fracture fragments. Good appositional realignment has been obtained. COMMENT: The olecranon represents the second most common site for elbow fractures in the adult. The radial head is the most common site.
The transverse fracture line that passes through both humeral condyles is called a transcondylar fracture. A comminuted fracture of the distal humerus, usually with associated ulnar and radial fractures, may occur if an object is struck with the elbow protruding from a car window (sideswipe or baby car fracture). (1)
Condylar Fracture.
A single condyle may be sheared off owing to an angular force through the elbow. Fractures may occur along the articular surfaces of the capitellum and trochlea. The convex surface of the capitellum is particularly susceptible to compression and breakage from forces transmitted from the radial head; the radial head and capitellum are occasionally fractured simultaneously. A small osteochondral fragment may also be sheared off the convex surface of the capitellum, producing an intraarticular loose body (Kocher’s fracture, osteochondral fracture, osteochondritis dissecans). (1)
Epicondylar Fracture.
Epicondylar fractures are usually avulsive injuries from traction of the respective common flexor or extensor tendons and collateral ligaments on the medial or lateral epicondyles. Separation of the medial epicondyle is a common injury in sports in which strong throwing actions are performed, such as baseball, especially in adolescents before the apophysis unites to the humerus at between 18 and 19 years of age (Little Leaguer’s elbow). (6) (Fig. 9-172)
Fractures of the Proximal Ulna
The two most common sites for fracture of the proximal ulna are the olecranon and coronoid process.
Olecranon Fracture.
Fractures of the olecranon account for approximately 20% of adult elbow fractures, ranking second in frequency to radial neck or head fractures. (2) They may follow direct trauma or an acute flexion avulsion from the triceps insertion. The fracture line is usually best seen on the lateral projection adjacent to the inferior convex surface of the trochlea but may be proximal or distal to this site. Distraction of the separated fragment may be considerable and requires surgical fixation. (Fig. 9-173) Swelling in the adjacent olecranon bursa is a common associated finding.
P.900

Figure 9-174 CORONOID PROCESS FRACTURE. Lateral Elbow. Observe the clearly visible fracture line through the tip of the coronoid process (arrow). COMMENT: This fracture was incurred following acute hyperextension of the elbow as part of an exercise conducted for training for manual spinal adjusting (toggle recoil). It healed with no residual functional impairment. (Courtesy of Sandra M. O’Connor, DC, DACBR, Toronto, Canada.)
Coronoid Process Fracture.
The coronoid process may be avulsed by the brachialis muscle or by impaction into the trochlea fossa. (Fig. 9-174) As an isolated fracture, this type of fracture is uncommon. It is fractured frequently in combination with posterior elbow dislocation and usually entails a small fracture fragment that is difficult to identify. The optimal projection for visualizing this fracture is the oblique view.
Fractures of the Proximal Radius
Fractures of the radial neck and head are the most common fractures of the adult elbow, accounting for approximately 50% of all injuries to this region. (2) In children and adolescents, the incidence is significantly lower, with a frequency of approximately 15%. (7) The majority of proximal radius fractures are caused by a fall on an outstretched hand, transmitting a longitudinal axis of force to create impaction of the radial head into the capitellum. An incomplete fracture of the radial head that extends from the center of the articular surface for about 10 mm is called a chisel fracture. (8) (Fig. 9-175) In the presence of a positive fat-pad sign, if a fracture is not identified, specific radial head views may demonstrate a fracture of the radial head. (9)
Radial Head Fracture.
The fracture line may be subtle and easily overlooked with a radial head fracture, so the observer must search for the various signs that indicate an occult fracture. (Fig. 9-176)
Figure 9-175 CHISEL FRACTURE: RADIAL HEAD. AP Elbow. Note the vertical fracture line extending through the articular surface of the radial head, with minimal offset of the articular contour (arrow).
  • Fracture line. A radiolucent line is seen usually oriented vertically and penetrating the articular cortex toward the lateral side of the head. (Fig. 9-177)
  • Cortical disruption. At the fracture site, the cortex will be broken.
  • Cortical deformity. At the fracture site, a sharp step-off or angulation is common, owing to fragment displacement. Depression of the fracture’s fragment may produce a double cortical sign, which is seen as a linear opacity paralleling the normal articular cortex of the radial head. (10) (Fig. 9-178)
  • Altered supinator fat line. On a normal lateral film, a linear radiolucent line representing the outer fascial plane of the supinator muscle, 1 cm above the anterior radial surface, will be observed. In fractures of the radial head or neck the fat line may be obliterated, blurred, or ventrally displaced by more than 1-2 cm. (11)
  • Fat-pad sign. A useful sign of an intra-articular fracture of the elbow is the clear depiction of displaced humeral capsular fat pads. (12) In the normal elbow a layer of fat (fat pad) lies between the synovial and fibrous layers of both the anterior and posterior joint capsule. In the lateral projection of the normal elbow, the anterior fat pad is seen as an obliquely oriented radiolucency. When acute intracapsular swelling is present from any origin (hemorrhagic, inflammatory, or traumatic), the anterior fat pad is elevated to be oriented horizontally, and the posterior fat pad
    P.901

    becomes visible (fat-pad sign). (13) In joint distensions the elevated fat pads, especially anteriorly, may be obliterated owing to hemorrhage or edema; therefore, the posterior fat pad, when visible, is the most reliable sign of intra-articular effusion. In children and adolescents, 90% of posterior fat-pad signs will have an associated fracture. (12) In adults, the sign is less frequently seen, and its absence does not exclude the presence of a fracture. (13) (Fig. 9-179)
Figure 9-176 OCCULT RADIAL HEAD FRACTURE. A. AP Elbow. Note there is no evidence of fracture in the radial head. B. 2-Month Follow-Up, AP Elbow. Note that a vertical fracture line is now apparent (chisel fracture) (arrow). COMMENT: This 17-year-old baseball pitcher developed elbow pain after throwing a fastball. Radial head fractures can be difficult to identify initially because the fracture line may be but a mere crack. This is one of the most common fractures of the elbow and may require specific radial head views for depiction.
Figure 9-177 DISPLACED RADIAL HEAD FRACTURE. AP Elbow. A fracture through the lateral portion of the radial head has occurred, with minimal depression of the articular cortex and lateral displacement of the isolated fragments.
Figure 9-178 RADIAL HEAD FRACTURE: DOUBLE CORTICAL SIGN. Observe the increased density of the articular cortex of the radial head, with projection of the opacity below the articular surface (arrow). Posteriorly, a fracture line is identified as a linear radiolucency. COMMENT: This double cortical sign is the result of an impaction fracture from the capitellum into the radial head, which displaces the cortex distally. Frequently, this is the only sign of a radial head fracture.
P.902

Figure 9-179 FAT-PAD SIGN: SUBTLE RADIAL NECK FRACTURE. Lateral Elbow. Note two triangular areas of radiolucency projecting away from the distal humeral shaft at the anterior and posterior aspects (arrows). A subtle fracture of the radial neck is also identified (arrowhead). COMMENT: Whenever both the anterior and posterior fat-pads are visible in this projection, a careful search must be performed to rule out a subtle intra-articular fracture. The most common fracture associated with a fat-pad sign is a radial head or neck fracture. The posterior fat pad is a more reliable indicator of fracture because the anterior fat pad may be poorly visualized or present in normal patients.
Figure 9-180 RADIAL NECK FRACTURE. Observe the thin fracture line disrupting the lateral aspect of the radial cortex (arrow).
Radial Neck Fracture.
The most common radial neck fracture is an impaction at the junction of the head and neck. The only sign may be a sharpened angle on the anterior surface, best depicted on the lateral projection. (Figs. 9-179 and 9-180) Complete fractures will be readily seen as a transverse lucent line with varying degrees of displacement. A comminuted fracture of the radial head in combination with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint is called an Essex-Lopresti fracture. (14)
Fractures of the Forearm
Forearm fractures may involve the radius or ulna singularly, but, more commonly, they are both affected.
Fractures of Both the Radius and Ulna
As in any bony ring structure, such as the pelvis, a fracture in one location is frequently associated with a disruption or another fracture or dislocation somewhere else in the ring. Approximately 60% of all forearm fractures will involve both bones (BB fractures), most commonly in the middle third of the shaft. (15) (Figs. 9-181 and 9-182) Almost all fractures of these bones have associated displacement with angulation and rotation. These almost always require open surgery and fixation.
Figure 9-181 RADIUS AND ULNA SHAFT FRACTURES. Note that oblique comminuted fractures have occurred through the mid-diaphyseal portions of the radius and ulna, with significant angulation and rotational deformity. COMMENT: These are unique fractures that usually follow significant direct trauma to the forearm.
P.903

Figure 9-182 SURGICAL FIXATION: RADIUS AND ULNA FRACTURES. Metallic plates have been placed across the fracture sites of the radius and ulna to realign the fracture fragments and reduce the amount of residual deformity.
Figure 9-183 NIGHTSTICK FRACTURE: ULNAR FRACTURE. Note the fracture of the distal ulna. COMMENT: This type of ulnar fracture can be associated with an attempt at self-protection of the head during an assault with a handheld object. Because assaults often occur at night and a stick may be used as the attack weapon, this fracture has been called a nightstick fracture.
Figure 9-184 MONTEGGIA’S FRACTURE OF THE FOREARM. A fracture through the proximal one-third of the ulna is present, with associated anterior angulation of the proximal fracture fragment. The radial head has also been displaced anteriorly, with dislocation at the elbow (arrow).
Isolated Fractures of the Ulna
Two types of fractures of the ulnar shaft have been described: distal and proximal.
Distal Ulnar Shaft Fracture (Nightstick or Parry Fracture).
Distal ulnar shaft fractures occur from direct trauma to the forearm, which is raised to protect the head during an assault with a club or hard object. (16) (Fig. 9-183)
Proximal Ulnar Shaft (Monteggia’s) Fracture.
In 1814 Monteggia first described fractures of the proximal ulna with associated anterior dislocation of the proximal radius. (Fig. 9-184) This definition has been widened to include all fractures of the ulnar shaft associated with displacement of the radius in any direction. (17) In children, the ulnar component of this lesion is often a greenstick fracture.
Isolated Fractures of the Radius
The most frequent isolated fracture site of the radius is toward the distal shaft. Other sites are rare. Distal radial shaft fractures are also called Galeazzi’s, Piedmont’s, or reversed Monteggia’s fracture. This is a rare but serious traumatic injury of the forearm. It is defined as a fracture of the radius at the junction of the middle and distal thirds, with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. (18,19) (Fig. 9-185) Despite treatment, this fracture is frequently complicated by non-union and has a tendency to redislocate. Early recognition and treatment of these complications have been shown to increase the prognostic outcome. (20)
Dislocations of the Elbow
The elbow is the third most common site of dislocation in adults, the shoulder and interphalangeal joints of the fingers being first and second, respectively. In children, it is the most common dislocation. (21,22) It is classified according to the displacement of the radius and ulna relative to the humerus: posterior, posterolateral, anterior, medial, and anteromedial.
P.904

Figure 9-185 GALEAZZI’S FRACTURE. Note that a comminuted fracture of the radius is present at the junction of the middle and distal thirds, with an associated dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. There has been an overall shortening of the distal radius, which is a common finding in this fracture-dislocation.
Posterior and Posterolateral Dislocations
Posterior and posterolateral dislocations are the most common dislocations of the elbow, making up to 85-90% of all such lesions. (21) In practically all elbow dislocations both the radius and ulna will be displaced. More than 50% of elbow dislocations will have associated fractures, most commonly of the medial epicondyle and radial head or neck. (23) In children, an avulsed medial epicondyle may become entrapped in the joint. A small percentage of posterior dislocations will develop post-traumatic myositis ossificans at the anterior aspect of the joint, usually in the brachialis muscle.
Pulled Elbow
Children between 2 and 5 years of age are vulnerable to the pulled elbow, a unique, transient injury. It occurs when the hand of the child is tractioned, such as in lifting the child from the floor. The child begins to cry immediately, holds the forearm in midpronation, and does not allow it to be moved. The lesion is caused by the radial head slipping out from under the annular ligament, trapping the ligament in the radiohumeral articulation. (24) No radiographic signs of the displacement will be evident. The ligament is easily replaced, often inadvertently or during the radiographic examination, by supinating the hand, producing immediate relief of symptoms. Recurrence is common in the ensuing weeks.
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE WRIST
The wrist is one of the most frequent sites for fractures. Dislocations are less common. Many eponyms have been applied to various fractures and their related deformities to honor those who either first described or most accurately defined the entity.
The bone and joint anatomy of the wrist is complex and requires adequate examination techniques for proper evaluation. (1) Point tenderness over the distal radius and a decrease in grip strength > 20% are good physical indicators of wrist fractures. (2) A minimum radiographic study of the wrist should include PA neutral, PA with ulnar flexion, oblique, and lateral projections. More precise definition of the individual carpal bones and their related soft tissue components requires specialized projections. CT of the wrist is especially useful in identifying occult and complex fractures. (3,4)
Fractures
Distal Radius Fractures
The distal radius is one of the most common sites of fracture in the wrist. Care must be taken to search all projections for these fractures, many of which are often subtle and obscure. In the absence of an obvious fracture, close observation of the lateral projection for displacement of the pronator quadratus fat line is a useful indicator for the presence or absence of fracture. (Fig. 9-186) Normally, this fat line appears as a well-defined linear
P.905

lucency oriented parallel with the plane of the radius, 2-5 mm from its anterior surface. In almost all cases of distal radius fractures the pronator quadratus fat line will be altered. (5) These alterations include anterior displacement, blurring, irregularity, and obliteration of the line. With accurate diagnosis and a proper treatment plan distal radius fractures should have a favorable outcome. (6)
Figure 9-186 NORMAL QUADRATUS FAT LINE. Lateral Wrist. Observe the clearly defined linear radiolucency (arrow) on the anterior aspect of the forearm in relatively close apposition to the distal radius. This fat line represents the outer surface of the pronator quadratus muscle. COMMENT: In the presence of distal radius fractures this fat line may become obliterated, blurred, or displaced away from the radial surface.
Colles’ Fracture.
In 1814 Abraham Colles wrote the definitive description of the fracture that bears his name. (7) The injury is defined as a fracture of the distal radius 20-35 mm proximal to the articular surface, with posterior angulation of the distal fragment. (Fig. 9-187) More than 60% will have an accompanying fracture of the ulnar styloid process. (7) The usual mechanism is a fall on an outstretched, extended hand. The physical appearance of the fractured distal forearm and wrist has led to its being called the dinner fork deformity. The incidence of the fracture increases with age, and this increase is so rapid in women that by age 65 the lesion is six times more common in women than in men. (8) Osteoporosis appears to be the underlying influencing factor. Functional outcomes are good with appropriate treatment, but complications are common and may be severe. (9,10)
The radiologic features are distinctive and relatively consistent.
  • Fracture line. Usually transverse and comminuted, it is normally readily visible. A variable degree of impaction is apparent on the dorsal surface at the fracture site.
  • Radial contour. A sharp cortical overlap is seen at the fracture site, especially visible on the frontal projection owing to the proximal migration of the distal fragment.
  • Radial length. The overall length of the radius is decreased owing to the proximal migration of the distal fragment.
  • Angulation. The distal fragment is tilted dorsally, as evidenced by the altered angle of the articular surface, which is seen on the lateral projection. Normally, there is 5-15° palmar angulation of the articular surface.
  • Soft tissue. The distorted skin contour is apparent. The pronator quadratus fat plane will usually be altered.
Figure 9-187 COLLES’ FRACTURE: DISTAL RADIUS, WITH POSTERIOR ANGULATION. A. PA Wrist. Note that the fracture line is obscured by a zone of impaction, seen as a transverse linear opacity. However, cortical offset is apparent at the lateral radial margin. B. Lateral Wrist. Observe that this view demonstrates the comminuted fracture of the distal radius with impaction on the posterior surface (arrow). The distal articular surface of the radius is angulated dorsally. The external skin contour displays the typical dinner fork deformity.
Smith’s Fracture (Reversed Colles’ Fracture).
In 1854 Smith described a fracture of the distal radius with anterior angulation of the distal fragment. (11) The usual mechanism of injury is a direct blow or fall with the wrist being forced into hyperflexion. This mechanism and resultant angular deformity is the direct opposite of a Colles’ fracture, hence the synonym reversed Colles’ fracture. Smith’s fracture is far less common than Colles’ fracture.
Radiologically, the same signs as the Colles’ fracture will be visible to varying degrees, except there will be anterior angulation of the distal fragment. (Fig. 9-188)
P.906

Figure 9-188 SMITH’S FRACTURE. A. PA Wrist. Note the transverse fracture line through the distal radius, with an associated linear density at the fracture site. B. Lateral Wrist. Observe the clearly identified fracture line through the distal radius, with impaction at the fracture site on the anterior surface (arrow). Associated anterior angulation of the distal fragment has altered the articular plane in this same direction. C. Diagram. The combination of a distal radius fracture with anterior angulation of the articular surface characterizes this fracture deformity.
Figure 9-189 RIM FRACTURES OF THE DISTAL RADIUS. A. Barton’s Fracture. A fracture of the posterior rim of the distal radial articular surface with associated posterior and proximal migration of the entire carpus is referred to as a Barton’s fracture. B. Reversed Barton’s Fracture. The fracture line extends through the anterior rim of the articular cortex with anterior displacement of the carpus.
P.907

Barton’s (Rim) Fracture.
In 1838 Barton described a posterior rim fracture of the distal radial articulating surface with associated proximal dislocation of the carpus (12). The usual mechanism is forceful hyperextension of the wrist to produce the posterior rim fracture. A fracture of the anterior rim has been called a reversed Barton’s fracture.
Radiologically, on the frontal projection the proximal carpal row overlaps the articulating surface of the radius. On the lateral view the posterior rim fracture will be visible, along with the posterior and proximal displacement of the carpals. (Fig. 9-189)
Chauffeur’s (Backfire, Hutchinson’s) Fracture.
Chauffeur’s fractures were formerly encountered as a result of a backfire that occurred when attempting to start a car engine with a hand crank, with the crank striking the dorsal surface of the wrist. (13) The fracture involves the radial styloid process as an avulsion or radial impaction by the adjacent scaphoid. The fracture line is either transverse or oblique, and, usually there is no displacement. (Fig. 9-190)
Moore’s Fracture.
In 1880 Moore described, in association with Colles’ fracture, a fracture of the ulnar styloid process and dislocation of the distal ulna. (14)
Torus Fracture (Fig. 9-191).
The torus fracture is the most common fracture of the wrist in children between 6 and 10 years of age. Typically, the fracture is located 2-4 cm from the distal growth plate. A torus fracture can occur in any long bone and is the term applied to a buckled cortex after trauma. As such, the key radiologic sign is a localized cortical bulge or bump.
P.908

The treatment of torus fractures has traditionally been with plaster casting but Futura-type braces have been shown to provide the same outcome with reduced cost and doctor visits to the patient. (15)
Figure 9-190 CHAUFFEUR’S FRACTURE (HUTCHINSON’S FRACTURE): FRACTURE OF THE RADIAL STYLOID. PA Wrist. Note the small fracture through the distal radial styloid process (arrow). COMMENT: This fracture may be the result of an avulsion or impaction by the adjacent scaphoid.
Figure 9-191 TORUS FRACTURE: DISTAL RADIUS AND ULNA. A. PA Wrist. Note the discrete area of cortical bulging at the lateral margins of the radius and ulna (arrows). B. Lateral Wrist. Observe the cortical bulges as acute angulations in the posterior cortical contours (arrows). COMMENT: This is the most common fracture of the wrist between the ages of 6 and 10. The bulging of the cortex is the result of a buckling of the bone and is the key radiologic sign of this injury.
Figure 9-192 SLIPPED RADIAL EPIPHYSIS. A. PA Wrist. Note the subtle separation of the radial growth plate, with ulnar displacement of the distal epiphysis. B. Lateral Wrist. Note that the posterior epiphyseal displacement is clearly demonstrated. A small displaced metaphyseal fragment from the radius (corner sign) (arrow) is also noted. COMMENT: Diagnosis of slipped radial epiphysis requires a minimum of two projections. This injury is the childhood equivalent of the adult Colles’ fracture.
Slipped Radial Epiphysis.
A slipped radial epiphysis is the childhood equivalent of the Colles’ fracture. (Fig. 9-192) The mechanism involved is a shearing force across the growth plate following a forceful hyperextension injury. The radial epiphysis is usually displaced posteriorly and will almost always have a small, displaced metaphyseal fragment (corner sign), classifying it as a Salter-Harris type II epiphyseal injury. Practically all of these epiphyseal separations are treated successfully by closed reduction, with no effects on growth.
Distal Ulnar Fractures
Ulnar Styloid Process Fracture.
As an isolated fracture, the ulnar styloid process fracture is an uncommon injury and is usually an avulsion through the ulnar collateral ligament. (Fig. 9-193) More frequently, it is found in combination with other fractures and dislocations of the wrist.
Distal Ulnar Shaft (Nightstick) Fracture.
See “Fractures of the Forearm.”
Scaphoid Fractures
