The scaphoid is the most common carpal bone to fracture. (16) The usual age of occurrence is between 15 and 40 years. Scaphoid
P.909

fractures are distinctly rare in children. The mechanism of injury is complex, but it essentially consists of various degrees of hyperextension and radial flexion, such as falling on an outstretched hand. The complaint of radial wrist pain in athletes should prompt the clinician to evaluate the scaphoid for fracture. (17) These fractures are frequently overlooked and exhibit a significant incidence of complications. The scaphoid is the most common site for occult fracture. (18)
Figure 9-193 ULNAR STYLOID FRACTURE. PA Wrist. Observe that an avulsion fracture of the ulnar styloid process is clearly visible. The radiolucent line through the distal ulna (arrow) should not be confused with a fracture line; this represents an unfused epiphyseal growth plate. There is an associated fracture through the distal radius. COMMENT: Isolated ulnar styloid fractures are infrequent. These lesions are usually associated with other fractures of the wrist, especially the distal radius, as is the case here.
Figure 9-194 OCCULT SCAPHOID FRACTURE. A. Initial Radiograph, PA Wrist. Note the subtle fracture line through the distal waist region of the scaphoid (arrow). Observe the absence of the navicular fat stripe adjacent to the fracture site. B. 3 Weeks Postinjury, PA Wrist. Observe that a fracture line is now clearly evident, owing to bony resorption of the fracture margins (arrow). COMMENT: The scaphoid is the most common site for occult fracture. Follow-up radiographs, normally within 7-10 days of the injury, will usually demonstrate the fracture line as resorption occurs.
Fracture Classification and Incidence.
The scaphoid is divided into three regions: distal pole, waist, and proximal pole. Some add a fourth segment, the tuberosity, which is part of the distal pole. Approximately 70% of fractures involve the waist; 20%, the proximal pole; and 10%, the distal pole. (18)
Radiologic Features.
The optimum routine view is the ulnar flexion projection because it eliminates foreshortening of the scaphoid and may distract the fracture fragments and widen the fracture line. The major radiologic sign is the fracture line, which is often difficult to identify. (Fig. 9-194) If no fracture is seen initially yet the clinical picture is suspicious, then precautionary immobilization should be applied and the wrist x-rayed in 7-10 days. A fracture, if present, will be visible by 20 days postinjury. (19)
Although radiographic follow-up is currently the standard of care for suspected occult fractures, research has suggested the loss of productivity from erroneously placing patients in casts may be far greater than the financial costs of using limited MRI screening procedures to make a definitive diagnosis. (20) Furthermore, individuals experienced in radiographic interpretation may reveal up to 70% of scaphoid fractures that were initially deemed occult by the treating clinician. (21) It is estimated that only 30% of scaphoid fractures initially considered occult are truly of this nature. (21) Bone scans in equivocal circumstances within 24-72 hr after injury can show a false-positive rate of 6-16% but no false-negatives. (19) After this time period, the fracture line widens, owing to resorption along the fracture margins (occult fracture). The fracture line is usually transverse or, less commonly, oblique in relation to the long axis of the scaphoid. (Fig. 9-195)
Figure 9-195 PROXIMAL SCAPHOID FRACTURE. PA Wrist. Note the oblique fracture line through the proximal portion of the scaphoid. There are associated fractures of the ulnar and radial styloid processes. COMMENT: Fractures of the proximal pole are more likely to result in major complications, such as avascular necrosis, non-union, and radiocarpal degenerative arthritis.
A soft tissue sign of a subtle scaphoid fracture can often be found in alterations to the adjacent scaphoid fat stripe. The normal fat stripe is a linear collection of fat between the radial collateral ligament and tendon sheaths of the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. Indecision exists in the reliability of this sign. One study revealed that in almost 90% of fractures involving the radial compartment of the wrist, the fat strip will be displaced laterally or totally obliterated (navicular fat stripe sign). (22) Another study concluded the fat-pad sign is unreliable and false-positive results are seen in up to 23% of cases. (23)
P.910

Figure 9-196 SCAPHOID FRACTURE AND BLOOD SUPPLY DISTRIBUTION. A. Distal Pole Fracture. B. Distal Waist Fracture. C. Proximal Waist Fracture. D. Proximal Pole Fracture. COMMENT: Fractures distal to the entrance of the main supplying artery have a significantly reduced incidence of avascular necrosis and non-union. Those fractures proximal to this artery are frequently complicated by these abnormalities. The shaded regions indicate the location for complicating avascular necrosis.
Healing occurs without periosteal callus, the fracture line just gradually disappearing. Healing time varies according to the fracture site. The more distal the fracture, the faster the healing and the less likely the development of complications. The converse applies to those fractures occurring proximally. (Fig. 9-195) The actual time required for healing ranges between 6 and 20 weeks and will vary with the individual. (10)
Complications.
The major complications consist of avascular necrosis, non-union, carpal instability, and radiocarpal degenerative arthritis. (24,25)
Avascular Necrosis.
Avascular necrosis is encountered in 1-15% of scaphoid fractures. (26) The scaphoid is anatomically predisposed to avascular necrosis after fracture owing to the patterns of nutrient blood supply.
The scaphoid receives a dual blood supply. A small artery enters and perfuses the distal pole and tuberosity. A larger vessel, with an entry site that may be proximal or distal to the scaphoid waist, is responsible for perfusing the remaining areas of the bone. (Fig. 9-196)
In the development of complicating avascular necrosis, the position of the fracture relative to the principal artery is the most crucial factor. If the fracture is distal to the major vessel, then avascular necrosis is unlikely; if proximal, then the probability for avascular necrosis increases significantly. In general, the more proximal the fracture line, the greater the probability for avascular necrosis.
Radiologic signs of the avascular segment include increased density and fragmentation. The fracture line will appear wider and is often cystic in appearance. (Fig. 9-197) All of the signs will take a variable time after the fracture incident to appear, ranging from months to years.
Non-Union.
Non-union occurs in approximately 30% of fractures involving the waist of the scaphoid. (27) As with avascular necrosis, the major variable that determines the development of non-union, or even delayed union, is the relationship of the fracture line to the principal artery. Delayed diagnosis or inappropriate treatment of the initial fracture predisposes the patient to this complication. (28,29) Non-union is associated with the progressive development of radiocarpal degenerative joint disease. (19,30) Internal fixation of the scaphoid fragments using the Herbert screw technique has showed positive clinical results in the reduction of non-union and allowing patients an earlier return to activity. (31,32)
Figure 9-197 SCAPHOID FRACTURE WITH COMPLICATING AVASCULAR NECROSIS. PA Wrist. Note the wide fracture line passing through the waist of the scaphoid. The proximal pole is homogeneously sclerotic, with no evidence of fragmentation. COMMENT: These findings are consistent with an ununited scaphoid fracture with associated avascular necrosis of the proximal pole.
Radiologic features of non-union include widening of the fracture line, cyst formation, and development of opposing sclerotic surfaces along the fracture line. (Fig. 9-198)
Carpal Instability.
Carpal instability is manifested by changes in alignment of the capitate, lunate, radius, and scaphoid. These may occur in concert with fractures, dislocations, isolated ligament rupture, repetitive stress injury, and degenerative and rheumatoid arthritis. (27,33) A number of instabilities have been described—dorsal intercalated segmental instability (DISI), ventral (volar) intercalated segmental instability (VISI), scapholunate dissociation, ulnar translocation, dorsal or palmar carpal subluxation, capitolunate instability, and midcarpal instability. (27) The three most common instabilities are scapholunate dissociation, DISI, and VISI.
  • Scapholunate dissociation (rotary subluxation of the scaphoid). This is the most common instability of the
    P.911

    wrist, usually following an acute dorsiflexion injury of the wrist. (27) Pain, crepitus, and weakened grip strength are typical. The fundamental defect is disruption of the scapholunate ligament, (34) though other ligaments are commonly incompetent, including other interosseous ligaments (capitate, lunate, scaphoid) and the dorsal radiocarpal ligament. The radiographic features consist of a wide scapholunate joint space (Terry Thomas’ sign), foreshortening of the scaphoid owing to rotation (ring sign), and loss of parallel joint surfaces. (27,35) A scapholunate space of 2 mm is suspicious, with > 4 mm definitely abnormal. (27) (See “Scaphoid Dislocation.”) A wide scapholunate space occurs as a normal variant in almost 50% of lunotriquetral coalitions. (36) These changes are often best depicted on PA ulnar deviation and clenched-fist views because routine views may not show evidence of instability. Surgery may be indicated only in symptomatic cases, though there is a link with the development of radiocarpal arthritis. (37)
  • DISI. The lunate tilts dorsally and the capitate displaces slightly dorsally to lie posterior to the longitudinal axis of the radius. This is best appreciated on the lateral view of the wrist so that the lunate tilts at an angle > 80° to the radius. (27) DISI is more common than VISI. (38)
  • VISI. The lunate tilts ventrally with the capitate extended or tilted dorsally. This is best appreciated on the lateral view of the wrist.
Figure 9-198 SCAPHOID FRACTURE WITH NON-UNION. PA Wrist. A smooth fracture line traverses the waist of the scaphoid. The opposing margins of the fracture line are sclerotic and well defined. These findings are distinctive for fracture non-union.
Figure 9-199 SCAPHOID FRACTURE WITH RADIOCARPAL DEGENERATIVE ARTHRITIS. PA Wrist. Note the severe loss of radiocarpal joint space, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and associated cyst formation throughout the carpal and distal radius articulations. Careful scrutiny of the proximal pole of the scaphoid demonstrates its resorption, most likely secondary to mechanical deformation and avascular necrosis. COMMENT: This is a severe form of post-traumatic radiocarpal degenerative arthritis in a retired professional boxer. His opposite hand appeared similar. (Courtesy of Stephen W. Hayman, DC, DeLand, Florida.)
Radiocarpal Degenerative Arthritis.
Degenerative arthritis may follow a healed scaphoid fracture, non-union or avascular necrosis of the scaphoid, and radius fracture. A decreased radiocarpal joint space, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts characterize this complication. (Fig. 9-199) Overgrowth of the Lister tubercle on the dorsum of the distal radius as seen on CT may cause atrophy and/or rupture of the extensor pollicis longus tendon. (39) In the absence of trauma, the presence of these radiocarpal changes should suggest the diagnosis of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition disease (CPPD). Scapholunate advanced collapse (SLAC) may follow, in which there is severe loss of the radiocarpal joint and scapholunate dissociation with proximal migration of the capitate. (Fig. 9-200)
Fractures of the Triquetrum
The triquetrum is the second most common carpal bone to fracture. (10) The most common type of fracture is an avulsion from the dorsal surface at the site of attachment of the radiocarpal ligament. (Fig. 9-201) This has been called a Fischer’s fracture. (40,41) These fractures usually follow hyperflexion injuries and present with swelling and localized pain on the dorsum of the
P.912

wrist. Radiologically, they are best identified on the lateral projection as a small, displaced flake of bone.
Figure 9-200 SCAPHOLUNATE ADVANCED COLLAPSE. PA Wrist. Note that severe loss of radiocarpal joint space with erosion of the radius by the scaphoid is apparent (arrow). There is scapholunate dissociation as evidenced by the widened interosseous space (arrowhead). Note the proximity of the capitate (c) to the distal radius. COMMENT: This is a marked complication of previous wrist trauma. (Courtesy of Ian Chen, MD, Denver, Colorado.)
Figure 9-201 AVULSION FRACTURE OF THE TRIQUETRUM (FISCHER’S FRACTURE). Lateral Wrist. Note the small avulsed fragment displaced posteriorly from the surface of the triquetrum (arrow). Some minimal overlying soft tissue swelling is also appreciated. COMMENT: This fracture is the second most common fracture of the wrist, with the scaphoid being the most common.
Fractures of Other Carpal Bones
Fractures of the remaining carpals are unusual and are typically related to a specific type of injury.
Pisiform Fracture.
A direct, impacting blow, such as a fall on an outstretched hand, is the usual mechanism of fracture of the pisiform. (Fig. 9-202) The most common fracture is a vertical fracture dividing the bone into approximate halves. Radiographically, they are best identified on a reverse oblique wrist projection. This view is obtained by reversing the position of the wrist from a pronated position to a supinated position. (42)
Trapezium Fracture.
Trapezium fractures most commonly follow hyperabduction thumb trauma and typically fracture the radial portion of the bone. (Fig. 9-203)
Trapezoid Fracture.
The least commonly fractured carpal bone is the trapezoid.
Capitate Fracture.
The capitate is an uncommon carpal to fracture, and, when it occurs, it is usually associated with scaphoid or perilunate dislocations. (10) The most frequent fracture is transverse, through the waist.
Hamate Fracture.
The hamate may fracture in various areas. The hook is a common site of fracture, which occurs as a result of a direct blow such as may occur in club or racquet sports where the butt end strikes directly over the protuberance. (43,44) On the frontal view, the circular contour of the hamate may not be seen. (45) Fracture of its dorsal surface often accompanies posterior dislocation or subluxation of the fourth or fifth metacarpal and is seen as an oblong-shaped bone fragment near the articulation. (46) A special tangential view with the wrist in hyperextension or a 30° tilted lateral projection with palmar abduction of the thumb is usually needed for diagnosis on plain film imaging. (47) The same reverse oblique view used to aid in the diagnosis of pisiform
P.913

fractures has also been shown to be useful with these fractures. (42) CT examination is perhaps the most accurate method for the diagnosis. (48)
Figure 9-202 PISIFORM FRACTURE. Lateral Wrist. Observe the oblique fracture line through the midportion of the pisiform (arrow). These fractures usually are the result of a direct blow to the pisiform from falling on a hyperextended hand, which typically divides the pisiform in half. (Courtesy of Klaus W. Weber, MD, Fort Wayne, Indiana.)
Figure 9-203 TRAPEZIUM FRACTURE. PA Oblique Wrist. Note that a comminuted fracture of the lateral portion of the trapezium has occurred. Significant widening of the first metacarpal trapezium articulation is also identified, owing to severe ligamentous injury.
Non-union of the fractured fragments is a common sequela and can be identified by chronic unresolved pain over the ulnar aspect of the wrist. Non-union or partial union of the hook of the hamate should be treated with surgical removal of the hook of the hamate. (49)
Lunate Fracture.
The lunate fracture is uncommon because it tends to dislocate before it fractures. If a fracture is seen in the lunate, the diagnosis of Kienböck’s disease (avascular necrosis) is likely.
Dislocations
Dislocations of the wrist are relatively uncommon but involve predictable locations. The classification of these injuries identifies two patterns: a single bone that dislocates relative to the remaining carpals, and a single bone that remains in normal position but with the surrounding bones dislocating.
A useful guideline in evaluating the carpal relationship on the PA projection is to visually inspect the three carpal arcs. (50) (Fig. 9-204) Arc 1 is formed by connecting the proximal articular surfaces of the proximal carpal row, arc 2 connects the distal articular surfaces of the proximal row, and arc 3 connects the proximal surfaces of the distal carpals (capitate, hamate). These arcs should be smooth and demonstrate proper intercarpal alignment. Disruptions of these arcs indicate a carpal displacement.
Figure 9-204 THE THREE ARCS OF CARPAL ALIGNMENT. PA Wrist. Note the three curvilinear lines constructed along the articular margins at the midcarpal and radiocarpal joints. In a normal PA view of the wrist, these lines should be smooth and continuous across the connecting joint spaces. COMMENT: Visual inspection of these three arcs is a useful method for detecting carpal displacements.
Single Carpal Dislocations
Lunate Dislocation.
The lunate is the most common carpal to dislocate, usually following a hyperextension injury. (Fig. 9-205) When the lunate dislocates, it tilts forward and anterior, disrupting its articulation with the capitate but maintaining close approximation with the anterior rim of the distal radius. This is best seen on the lateral view. On the PA view the lunate is altered in shape to appear triangular, with the apex pointing distally (pie sign). Inspection of the three carpal arcs will demonstrate disruption of arcs 2 and 3 at the midcarpal joint.
Scaphoid Dislocation.
The scaphoid is the second most common carpal to be displaced. Complete dislocation is infrequent, with lesser degrees of subluxation being more common. As the scaphoid displaces, it moves laterally and rotates anteriorly (rotary subluxation). On the PA view this will be seen as a small, foreshortened scaphoid that appears circular in shape (ring or signet ring sign). (35) In addition, there will be an increase in the space between the scaphoid and lunate of > 4 mm (Terry Thomas’ sign). (35,51) (Fig. 9-206)
Other Carpal Dislocations.
Other carpal dislocations are distinctively unusual and require the occurrence of severe trauma. (Fig. 9-207)
P.914

Figure 9-205 LUNATE DISLOCATION. A. PA Wrist. Note the overlap of the distal lunate with the capitate. The triangular shape (pie sign) (arrows) is characteristic of anterior dislocation of the lunate. B. Lateral Wrist. Note that the lunate can be seen displaced anteriorly and tilted forward at its superior aspect (arrow). COMMENT: Anterior lunate dislocation is the most common carpal displacement. The characteristic findings are well demonstrated with the triangular appearance on the PA film and the anterior forward displacement on the lateral projection.
Figure 9-206 SCAPHOLUNATE DISSOCIATION (ROTARY SCAPHOID SUBLUXATION). A. Terry Thomas. Thomas’ dental diastema (front incisor gap) provides the basis for the analogy of the widened scapholunate space as a manifestation of instability. (Courtesy of the Bettmann Archive.) B. Clenched Fist PA Wrist. Note that the scaphoid is considerably shortened in its longitudinal dimension, with the formation of a rounded cortical contour at its distal margin (ring sign) (arrows). A widening of the scapholunate space (Terry Thomas’ sign) has occurred owing to disruption of the interconnecting ligament. COMMENT: The scaphoid is the second most common bone to be displaced in the wrist. The combination of the ring and Terry Thomas signs renders the diagnosis.
P.915

Figure 9-207 PISIFORM DISLOCATION. Oblique Wrist. Observe the displacement of the pisiform away from the triquetrum (arrow). COMMENT: This is an uncommon site for carpal dislocation.
Figure 9-208 TRANS-SCAPHOID FRACTURE AND PERILUNATE DISLOCATION. A. PA Wrist. Note the transverse fracture through the waist of the scaphoid (arrow), which has occurred in association with posterior dislocation of the distal fragment and distal carpal bones. The superimposed densities of the hamate and capitate (arrowheads) signify this posterior dislocation and proximal migration. B. Lateral Wrist. Note the posterior displacement of the distal carpal row, especially the capitate (arrow). COMMENT: Trans-scaphoid fracture and perilunate dislocation follows severe traumatic injury to the wrist. Characteristically, the fracture is through the midwaist of the scaphoid, with associated posterior displacement of the distal fragment and distal carpal row.
Multiple Carpal Dislocations
Perilunate Dislocation.
Perilunate dislocation usually is made up of dorsal displacements of all the carpal bones except the lunate, which maintains its normal position with the radius. This is best seen on the lateral projection. On the PA projection, the capitate will be seen to overlie the lunate. Numerous complications may occur from this injury regardless of the treatment used; however, early intervention with open or closed realignment is necessary to optimize results. (52) In one study using open reduction and internal fixation procedures, 73% of patients were able to return to work, with 100% of the patients reporting long-term loss of function. (53) Common complications include chondrolysis, carpal instability, and traumatic arthritis. (52)
Trans-Scaphoid Perilunate Dislocation.
The trans-scaphoid perilunate dislocation is virtually the same injury as the perilunate dislocation, except there is an associated fracture through the waist of the scaphoid. (Figs. 9-208 and 9-209) The proximal fragment stays in its normal position with the lunate, while the distal portion displaces with other carpal bones dorsally.
de Quervain’s Fracture-Dislocation.
Described in 1907 by de Quervain, the injury bearing his name consists of anterior dislocation of the lunate, along with the proximal fragment of a fractured scaphoid. (54)
P.916

Figure 9-209 LUNATE AND PERILUNATE DISLOCATIONS—ALIGNMENT OF THE CAPITATE, LUNATE, AND DISTAL RADIUS FROM A LATERAL (SAGITTAL) PERSPECTIVE. A. Normal Alignment. B. Perilunate Dislocation. Note the dorsal displacement of the capitate (C) relative to the normally aligned lunate (L) and distal radius (R). C. Lunate Dislocation. Note the volar dislocation of the lunate bone (L) relative to the normally aligned capitate (C) and distal radius (R).
FRACTURES AND DISLOCATIONS OF THE HAND
The phalanges and metacarpals are the most common sites of skeletal injury in the entire skeleton. (1) Phalangeal fractures are more common than metacarpal fractures. In the majority of cases only a single bone or joint will be affected. Most can be treated conservatively, with only a few requiring open reduction and soft tissue repair or pin fixation.
Figure 9-210 BAR ROOM FRACTURE (FIFTH METACARPAL NECK FRACTURE). A. PA Hand. Note that a transverse fracture is seen at the junction of the fifth metacarpal head and shaft (arrow). Some slight radial displacement of the head is also present. B. PA Oblique Hand. Note that this view reveals the significant anterior displacement of the metacarpal head, common in these injuries. COMMENT: These metacarpal head fractures are common after a direct blow to the metacarpal phalangeal joints, particularly on the ulnar side of the hand.
Radiologic examination routinely should have no less than three projections, including PA, oblique, and lateral views. If a single digit is involved, collimated views in these positions should be done to enhance detail. Examination of the thumb requires specialized projections. Knowledge of the locations and appearances of the many sesamoid bones and nutrient canals will reduce the probability of misdiagnosis.
Fractures
Second to Fifth Metacarpal Fractures
Of all the metacarpals, the fifth is the most commonly fractured, the majority of which occur in the distal half.
Boxer’s Fracture.
The boxer’s fracture is a transverse fracture of the neck of the second or third metacarpal, the result of a straight, jabbing type of blow with the fist. (2)
Bar Room Fracture.
The bar room fracture is also transverse in nature, involving the neck of the fourth or fifth metacarpals and is the result of a “roundhouse” type of blow characteristic of the inexperienced fighter. (2,3) (Fig. 9-210) This exposes the fourth and fifth metacarpal heads to absorption of the force of the delivered blow.
In most metacarpal neck fractures, there will be anterior angulation of the metacarpal head, with variable degrees of shortening and rotation of the fracture fragment.
Shaft Fracture.
Shaft fractures usually involve the third and fourth metacarpals, often simultaneously. Dorsal angulation and displacement across the fracture site quite commonly occurs. (Fig. 9-211)
Base Fracture.
Base fractures are rarely seen.
P.917

Figure 9-211 METACARPAL SHAFT FRACTURES. A. PA Hand. Note the transverse fractures through the first, second, and third metacarpal shafts. There has been a considerable degree of displacement and overlap, particularly at the second and third metacarpals. B. PA Oblique Hand. Observe multiple oblique fractures extending through the shafts of the third and fourth metacarpals, as well as the proximal phalanx of the fifth digit. (Courtesy of James R. Brandt, DC, DABCO, Coon Rapids, Minnesota.)
Figure 9-212 BENNETT’S FRACTURE. A. PA Oblique Wrist. B. Diagram. Note the oblique intra-articular fracture (arrow) extending through the base of the first metacarpal, with associated posterior and radial displacement of the adjacent shaft.
P.918

First Metacarpal Fractures
Most thumb metacarpal fractures occur at or near the base. Four distinct patterns are found: Bennett’s, Rolando’s, transverse, and a Salter-Harris type II that occurs in adolescents.
Bennett’s Fracture.
Bennett’s fracture actually is a fracture-dislocation that was first described by Bennett in 1882. (4,5) It commonly follows an injury in which there is a grip applied to an object such as a ski pole or handle bar. (5) This type of fracture is defined as an intra-articular fracture through the base of the first metacarpal, with dorsal and radial displacement of the shaft. A small medial fragment remains closely aligned to the trapezium. (Fig. 9-212)
Figure 9-213 ROLANDO’S FRACTURE (COMMINUTED BENNETT’S FRACTURE). A. PA Thumb. B. Diagram. Note the comminuted intra-articular fracture (arrows) at the base of the first metacarpal, which is associated with posterior and radial displacement of the distal metacarpal shaft.
Rolando’s Fracture (Comminuted Bennett’s Fracture).
In 1910 Rolando (6) described a comminuted intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal. (Fig. 9-213) This is a difficult fracture to treat and is the least common of all first metacarpal fractures. (1,7)
Transverse Fracture.
A transverse fracture is the most common fracture of the first metacarpal. (8) (Fig. 9-211A) On occasion, the fracture line may be oblique, but it remains articular.
Figure 9-214 DISTAL PHALANX FRACTURE. A. PA Distal Phalanx. Note the transverse fracture through the base of the distal phalanx. B. Lateral Distal Phalanx. Observe that there is little displacement across the fracture line.
Figure 9-215 POSTERIOR CHIP FRACTURE OF THE DISTAL PHALANX (MALLET FINGER OR BASEBALL FINGER). A. Lateral Finger. B. Diagram. Note the posterior chip fracture at the base of the distal phalanx. Also observe the inability to extend the distal interphalangeal joint. COMMENT: These posterior chip fractures are usually secondary to sudden forced flexion of the articulation, with resultant avulsion of the attachment of the extensor tendon.
P.919

Phalangeal Fractures
Fractures of the phalanges are collectively more common than metacarpal fractures. Distal phalangeal fractures are the most common, making up 50% of all phalangeal fractures; 15% affect the proximal phalanges, and 10% affect the middle phalanges. (9)
Fractures of the Distal Phalanges.
The middle finger is the most common site of fracture. (9) Four types of fracture occur: transverse, longitudinal, comminuted, and chip. Transverse fractures occur toward the base (Fig. 9-214). Longitudinal fractures may split the phalanx in half and extend all the way to the joint. Comminuted fractures are the most common and are usually limited to the distal tuft. Chip fractures involve the posterior or anterior corners at the phalangeal base. A posterior chip fracture inactivates extension of the distal interphalangeal joint and produces a flexion deformity (mallet or baseball finger). (Fig. 9-215)
Figure 9-216 VOLAR PLATE FRACTURE. Lateral Finger. Note the small chip fracture at the anterior aspect of the distal phalanx (arrow). Because of the small fragment, these fractures are frequently overlooked and may require specific oblique films for identification.
Figure 9-217 PROXIMAL PHALANGEAL FRACTURE. PA Hand. Observe the spiral fracture in the proximal phalanx of the fifth digit. No significant displacement or intra-articular extension is seen.
Fractures of the Middle Phalanges.
Most fractures of the middle phalanges occur in the distal shaft. Another common fracture is one that occurs on the anterior surface, at the base of the phalanx, and is called a volar plate fracture. (Fig. 9-216)
Fractures of the Proximal Phalanges.
Most fractures of the proximal phalanges involve the middle and proximal shafts. (Fig. 9-217) These infrequently continue into the adjacent joint.
Turret Exostosis.
Turret exostosis is a bony protuberance, usually on the ulnar and dorsal aspects of the base of the proximal or middle phalanx. (10) The exostosis represents organization of a traumatic subperiosteal hemorrhage. The hematoma first appears as a soft tissue mass and then ossifies. It produces a painful lump on the dorsal aspect of the fingers and may interfere with flexion. Often, a healed scar of a previous laceration may be identified in the overlying skin. Recurrence rate after surgical removal is high. It may radiographically simulate a sessile osteochondroma, with the clinical history being the key to the differential diagnosis.
Dislocations
Metacarpophalangeal Joint Dislocation
Dislocations of the metacarpophalangeal joints are usually readily apparent. (Fig. 9-218) The index and little fingers are most commonly dislocated. This type of dislocation is classified by two subgroups: simple and complex. Simple dislocations are easily reducible; complex dislocations have an entrapped, avulsed volar plate within the joint and require open reduction. A diagnostic sign of a complex dislocation is the presence of a sesamoid bone within a widened joint space. (11)
Figure 9-218 METACARPOPHALANGEAL JOINT DISLOCATION. PA Oblique Hand. Note the complete dislocation of the fifth metacarpal phalangeal joint, with posterior displacement of the proximal phalanx.
P.920

At the first metacarpophalangeal joint, a tear or complete rupture of the ulnar collateral ligament results in an instability that has been called gamekeeper’s thumb. (Fig. 9-219) In 1955, Campbell (12) noted the common occurrence of the injury in English gamekeepers who killed rabbits by breaking their necks between their thumb and forefinger. The term has subsequently lingered in the literature to describe any injury associated with ulnar collateral ligament instability. A more modern mechanism of injury occurs from incorrect placement of a ski pole, producing abduction and extension of the thumb as the skier’s momentum carries him or her downhill. This association has led this injury to also be referred to as the skier’s thumb. (13)
Radiographic examinations are usually negative, unless an abduction stress view is taken, on which a widening of the ulnar joint compartment and radial shaft of the proximal phalanx will be apparent. (1) Occasionally, a small fragment from the radial margin of the base of the proximal phalanx will be avulsed. MRI may demonstrate tears of the ulnar collateral ligament. (14) Partial tears and sprains are treated with immobilization, complete tears with open repair, and avulsion fractures by pinning.
Interphalangeal Dislocations
The majority of interphalangeal dislocations follow acute hyperextension and result in posterior displacement of the phalanx. (Fig. 9-220) Anterior dislocations are rare. Usually, only one joint of the same digit will be dislocated and, infrequently, two joints. (Fig. 9-221) In association with the dislocation there frequently is a small volar plate fracture that may become entrapped in the joint and prevent closed reduction.
Figure 9-219 GAMEKEEPER’S THUMB. A. PA Thumb. Observe the small avulsed triangular fragment at the ulnar side at the base of the proximal phalanx. B. Diagram. The avulsion of the phalangeal base is secondary to severe abduction at the first metacarpal phalangeal joint. COMMENT: Gamekeeper’s thumb does not always have an associated fractured phalangeal base. Frequently, on plain films no abnormality will be seen. Specific abduction stress views will, however, demonstrate ligamentous instability.
Figure 9-220 INTERPHALANGEAL JOINT DISLOCATION. Lateral Finger. Note the characteristic posterior displacement of the middle phalanx, with an associated volar plate fracture (arrow). COMMENT: These interphalangeal joint dislocations are the most common encountered.
Figure 9-221 DOUBLE INTERPHALANGEAL JOINT DISLOCATION. Lateral Finger. Note that posterior dislocation has occurred at both the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints. There is an associated small volar plate fracture, with the fragment adjacent to the anterior aspect of the metacarpal head (arrow). COMMENT: Double interphalangeal joint dislocations are exceedingly rare. (Courtesy of Gerald A. Fitzgerald, MD, Sydney, Australia.)
P.921

Medicolegal Implications
SHOULDER GIRDLE AND UPPER LIMB INJURIES
  • Any radiographed region should have a minimum of frontal and lateral views. It is preferable that additional projections be obtained to extend this basic examination to detect more subtle lesions. In the shoulder, external rotation places the greater tuberosity into profile, revealing an otherwise obscured fracture line (flap fracture); in the elbow, the oblique film renders another surface of the radial head visible to identify fracture; in the wrist, an ulnar deviation position may show an otherwise invisible fracture through the scaphoid.
  • Follow-up radiographs at appropriate intervals are important if the injury is prone to instability or is compound in nature or if symptoms persist or worsen. If a fever occurs, the presence of osteomyelitis must be assumed and treated promptly with an antibiotic.
  • In cases in which the radiologic appearances are normal or equivocal but the clinical suspicion is high, the site should be treated as if it had a fracture and appropriately immobilized.
  • Periodic radiographic examination in patients with recurrence of symptoms may be indicated, especially in sites where there is known to be a high incidence for complications, such as the shoulder (post-traumatic osteolysis of the clavicle, degenerative joint disease), radial head (degenerative joint disease), and scaphoid (avascular necrosis, non-union).
Figure 9-222 METATARSAL STRESS FRACTURES. A. Dorsoplantar Foot. Note the thin layer of periosteal bone formation adjacent to the midshaft of the second metatarsal (arrows). This is frequently the first radiographic manifestation of stress fracture in this location. B. Dorsoplantar Foot. Note the thick layer of solid periosteal new bone adjacent to the distal metatarsal shaft (arrows). This represents a long-standing stress fracture with significant callus formation. C. Dorsoplantar Foot. Observe the cloudy, veil-like density adjacent to the distal third metatarsal (arrows). This represents periosteal callus formation owing to the presence of a stress fracture. COMMENT: The earliest manifestations of stress fractures are often subtle and consist primarily of periosteal callus formation at the fracture site. It is unusual to see the fracture line in these injuries in the earliest phases.
STRESS FRACTURES
General Considerations
The term stress fracture is applied to a bone injury incurred as the result of repetitive stress of lower magnitude than that required for an acute traumatic fracture. (1) These can occur in normal or abnormal bone. The diagnosis frequently requires the treating clinician to have a high index of suspicion because radiographs can be relatively insensitive in the early course of the disorder. (2) Bone scans are the modality of choice. MRI is particularly useful in the differential diagnosis between neoplasm and stress fracture. (3)
Definitions
Fatigue Fracture.
Fatigue fractures occur secondary to an abnormal amount of stress or torque applied to a bone with normal integrity. Classically, these are found in military recruits, runners, and dancers. It is suggested that individuals who inadequately prepare for higher levels of training are more prone to stress fractures than individuals who gradually increase their performance. (4)
Insufficiency Fracture.
Insufficiency fractures occur with normal stress placed on a bone that has an underlying weakness or pathologic process present. The causes of insufficiency fractures are diverse and include Paget’s disease, osteoporosis, osteomalacia or rickets, osteopetrosis, fibrous dysplasia, and osteogenesis imperfecta. (5)
P.922

Causes
The major cause of stress fracture is an abnormal degree of repetitive trauma. This often is related to increased physical exertion, as is found in sports activities. (1) Stress fractures may occur owing to muscular imbalances placed on the skeletal structures (6) and altered biomechanics from rigid supination of the foot, varus deformities of the foot, and leg length inequality. (7) Stress fractures may also follow certain surgical procedures. Bunionectomies have been associated with stress fractures in the metatarsals (8) while stress fractures of the pubic rami have followed hip replacement surgery, (9) knee surgery, (10) and fusion of the lumbosacral junction. (11) Deformity from arthritis, especially at the knee, can precipitate a stress fracture. (12) It has been suggested menstrual irregularities may predispose women to stress fractures. (7)
Common Sites
The metatarsals are the most common lower extremity site, with the middle and distal portions of the shaft of the second and third metatarsals being most frequently affected. (10) (Figs. 9-222 and 9-223) These are frequent in military recruits (march fracture, Deutschländer’s disease) and believed to be due to fatigue of the peroneus longus muscle leading to instability of the foot. (13) Stress fractures of the second and third metatarsals may complicate Morton’s syndrome, a congenitally shortened first metatarsal. (14)
Figure 9-223 METATARSAL STRESS FRACTURES: SERIAL PROGRESSION. A. Initial Film, Dorsoplantar Foot. Note the oblique radiolucent fracture through the second metatarsal shaft. This is surrounded by extensive proliferative callus formation. B. 2-Month Follow-Up, Dorsoplantar Foot. Observe a second stress fracture in the shaft of the third metatarsal adjacent to the original fracture site. Residual callus formation is noted surrounding the initial stress fracture (arrows). C. 6-Month Follow-Up, Dorsoplantar Foot. Observe the third stress fracture of the shaft of the fourth metatarsal. COMMENT: The serial progression of stress fractures in this case is somewhat unique because the patient was a 60-year-old energetic gardener who refused to quit the extensive stooping involved in her gardening. The stress related to that position created the serial stress fractures over a period of 6 months. (Courtesy of Donald B. Tomkins, DC, DACBR, Canistota, South Dakota. Special thanks to James F. Winterstein, DC, DACBR, Chicago, Illinois, for his help in obtaining these films.)
The proximal tibia is also a common location, with a high incidence in joggers, marchers, and ballet dancers. (15) (Figs. 9-224, 9-225, 9-226 and 9-227) Stress fractures of the calcaneus are found in military recruits and long-distance runners. (13,16) (Fig. 9-228) The proximal or distal metaphyses of the fibula are not uncommon sites for stress fractures, usually being found in runners and ballet dancers. (17) The distal portion is affected more often than the proximal aspect. (Fig. 9-229) Up to 12% of rowers experience stress fractures of the ribs. (18)
The pars interarticularis of the lower lumbar spine (L4, L5) is the most common site for stress fracture of the entire skeleton. It may be found with or without spondylolisthesis. (19) (Fig. 9-230) Other common sites and their associated activities are outlined. (Figs. 9-231 and 9-232; Table 9-18) Less commonly, stress fractures may occur in the femoral neck, hook of the hamate, lamina of the lumbar spine, sternum, and sacrum. (20,21,22,23,24) Sacral stress fractures most commonly occur in elderly woman secondary to osteoporosis and are associated with neurological compromise with an incidence of about 2%. (25,26,27) The symptomology of lower extremity paraesthesias and sphincter dysfunction is often accredited to other conditions and the diagnosis missed. (27) Owing to the inherent difficulty in identifying sacral stress fractures on conventional x-ray, MRI is advocated in cases with a high index of suspicion. (28)
P.923

Figure 9-224 STRESS FRACTURE: PROXIMAL TIBIA. A. AP Knee. Observe the exuberant callus formation surrounding the proximal diaphysis of the tibia (arrows). B. Lateral Knee. Note the horizontal radiolucent fracture line through the area of stress fracture (arrows). Extensive callus formation is noted on the posterior surface of the tibia adjacent to the fracture line (arrowhead). COMMENT: The proximal tibia is a common location for stress fractures, which are found in joggers, marchers, and ballet dancers.
Figure 9-225 STRESS FRACTURE: PROXIMAL TIBIA. A. Lateral Upper Tibia. Note the marked callus formation, sclerosis, and a fracture line (arrows) in the proximal tibial metaphysis. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Upper Tibia. Observe the horizontal area of low signal intensity coursing through the tibial metaphysis (arrowhead), representing bone marrow edema associated with a stress fracture. COMMENT: Marrow changes are identified much earlier with MRI than with plain film radiographs, often assisting in identifying the exact location of the lesion. (Courtesy of James Shorten, DC, Tucson, Arizona.)
P.924

Figure 9-226 BILATERAL TIBIAL STRESS FRACTURES. A. AP Tibia. Note the diffuse periosteal new bone in the upper tibia (arrows). No fracture line is visible. B. Lateral Tibia. Observe the similar periosteal response present (arrow). C. Delayed Bone Scan, AP View. Note the focal regions of increased uptake bilaterally, corresponding to the sites of fracture (arrows). COMMENT: This aerobics instructor demonstrates the characteristic findings of stress fractures. They are minimal plain film changes with an impressive bone scan. Bone scan is the modality of choice in the diagnosis of stress fractures. (Courtesy of Richard L. Green, DC, Boston, Massachusetts.)
Figure 9-227 STRESS FRACTURE OF THE INFERIOR PUBIC RAMUS. Note the localized callus (arrow); a lucent fracture zone can also be seen (arrowhead). (Courtesy of Richard M. Nuzzi, DC, Boulder, Colorado.)
Figure 9-228 STRESS FRACTURE: CALCANEUS. Observe the dense radiopaque band in the posterosuperior portion of the calcaneus (arrow). COMMENT: This is a typical location for stress fracture affecting the calcaneus. Of incidental note is a vascular calcification in the posterior tibial artery (arrowheads).
P.925

Figure 9-229 STRESS FRACTURE: DISTAL FIBULA. AP Ankle. Note the periosteal new bone formation, along with a radiolucent fracture line, in the distal diaphysis of the fibula (arrow). COMMENT: Stress fractures of the fibula are most commonly found in ballet dancers and joggers. (Courtesy of Phillip C. Huyler, DC, Nassau, Bahamas.)
Figure 9-230 STRESS FRACTURE: LUMBAR PARS INTERARTICULARIS. Note the spondylolysis of the pars interarticularis of L5 (arrows). COMMENT: The majority of pars interarticularis defects seen in the lumbar spine are the result of stress fractures.
Figure 9-231 STRESS FRACTURE: PROXIMAL FEMUR. A. AP Hip. Note that the stress fracture can be appreciated by the radiopaque transverse band, which is present in the area of the femoral neck (arrow). B. Bone Scan, Hip. Observe the focal area of increased radionuclide uptake in the area of the stress fracture of the femoral neck (arrow). COMMENT: Stress fractures of the femoral neck are a frequent complication of osteoporosis and are also found in marathon runners.
P.926

Figure 9-232 STRESS FRACTURE: SESAMOID BONE OF THE GREAT TOE. A. Dorsoplantar Great Toe. Note the fragmentation and radiopacity within the lateral sesamoid bone on the plantar surface of the great toe (arrow). B. Axial Metatarsal Head. Observe the stress fracture with radiopacity and fragmentation of the sesamoid bone (arrow). COMMENT: This stress fracture occurred in a female marathon runner who experienced severe plantar foot pain while training. (Courtesy of Gary M. Guebert, DC, DACBR, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Table 9-18 Activity-Related Sites for Stress Fractures

Bone

Area

Activity

Calcaneus

Posterior, plantar portion

Jumping, parachuting, marching, prolonged standing

Clavicle

Outer third

Persistent tic, radical neck surgery

Femur

Shaft

Distal third

Ballet, long-distance running

Neck

Midcervical, subcapital

Ballet, marching, long-distance running, gymnastics

Fibula

Distal shaft

Long-distance running

Proximal shaft

Jumping, parachuting

Hamate

Hook

Equipment holding (tennis, golf, baseball)

Humerus

Distal shaft

Throwing sports

Metatarsals

First

Base

Marching, ground stomping

Second

Distal and midshaft

Marching, ground stomping, ballet

Third

Distal metaphysis

Morton’s syndrome

Fifth

Shaft, base

Running on banked track fields

Navicular (tarsal)

Distal half

Ground stomping, marching, long-distance running

Patella

Proximal pole

Hurdling

Pelvis

Obturator ring

Stooping, bowling, gymnastics

Phalanx

Tuft

Guitar playing

Ribs

First

Posterior

Pack carrier, chronic dyspnea

Seven to nine

Posterolateral

Coughing, golfing, rowing

Scapula

Coracoid process

Trap shooting

Inferior glenoid tip

Baseball

Sesamoids

First metatarsal

Standing, jumping, running

Spine

Lower cervical

Spinous process

Clay shoveling

Upper thoracic

Spinous process

Clay shoveling

Lower lumbar

Pars interarticularis

Ballet, gymnastics, pole-vaulting, footballers, cricket bowlers, weightlifting, diving

Tibial shaft

Middle and distal

Long-distance running, ballet

Proximal

Jumping, parachuting, basketball

Ulna

Coronoid process

Throwing sports

Olecranon

Throwing sports

Shaft

Pitchfork work, wheelchair
P.927

Clinical Features
Stress fractures are reportedly more common in women than in men. (29) The clinical findings related to stress injuries are characteristic. Pain, which is related to activity (30) and is relieved by rest, is typical. (31) Soft tissue swelling with localized tenderness over the area of stress fracture is observed. Almost any bone can be affected, with the bones of the lower extremity being most frequently involved. More than one site can be present, with serial radiographs showing fractures at various stages. (Fig. 9-223)
Radiologic Features
The initial radiographic examination may fail to reveal the fracture line. (30) This is influenced by the location of the fracture and the interval between the time of injury and that of the radiographic examination. The minimum radiographic latent period is 10-21 days. CT may be helpful in demonstrating the fracture line.
Bone scan is the modality of choice for demonstration. (5,32,33) Focal uptake at the site of fracture on delayed images is characteristic but not specific. The scan may remain active for up to 12 months after healing. (34,35) Combination bone scan with tomography (SPECT) is especially useful in the demonstration of an active stress fracture of the pars interarticularis. (36) By demonstrating a fracture line, CT is a useful tool when the diagnosis is in doubt. MRI similarly can detect subtle fractures and aid in the differential diagnosis by revealing increased diagnostic details. (33,37,38) Occult fracture lines may show as a low signal on T1- and high signal on T2-weighted sequences if local hemorrhage is present or, in its absence, remain low in signal on both T1- and T2-weighted studies. (32,38)
Roentgen Signs
Periosteal Response.
The most frequently seen and reliable roentgen sign of stress fracture is periosteal and endosteal cortical thickening. (Table 9-19) The degree of new bone formation can be extreme and usually assumes a solid pattern of periosteal response. This cortical thickening is localized to the area of stress fracture, creating an eccentric protuberance of the cortex.
Fracture Line.
Frequently, the exuberant periosteal new bone will obscure the radiolucent fracture line within the cortex. At other times, the fracture is too thin to be depicted on the radiograph. Oblique fractures are most common, though transverse and rare longitudinal varieties do occur. CT often will demonstrate the fracture line through the dense sclerosis, when plain films do not.
Table 9-19 Radiologic Features of Stress Fractures

Localized solid periosteal or endosteal new bone

Subtle or absent fracture line

Narrow, poorly defined, opaque band

Positive bone scan
Transverse Opaque Bands.
When the stress fracture is viewed en face, the periosteal callus forms a linear, transverse, radiopaque band. The margins of this density are hazy and poorly defined, which differentiates it from a growth arrest line. The calcaneus is a characteristic site to visualize such a dense radiopaque line traversing vertically through the bone. (Fig. 9-228)
Differential Diagnosis
Osteomyelitis.
Because osteomyelitis may create a significant periosteal response, an early infectious focus can resemble a stress fracture. In the presence of lytic bone destruction adjacent to the periosteal callus an infectious lesion should be considered.
Osteosarcoma.
Early lesions of osteosarcoma may be confused with stress fractures. Both produce periosteal response, with stress fracture assuming a solid pattern and osteosarcoma creating a spiculated pattern. Bone destruction will be seen with osteosarcoma, a roentgen sign not present with stress fractures. Often, CT will demonstrate a linear radiolucent fracture line, securing the diagnosis of stress fracture.
Osteoid Osteoma.
The radiographic appearance of osteoid osteoma and stress fracture is similar. The key roentgen sign that allows differential diagnosis is usually seen on CT and overpenetrated plain films. This sign is the oval radiolucent nidus of osteoid osteoma versus the linear radiolucent fracture line in stress fractures.
Growth Arrest Lines.
Growth arrest lines present as discrete radiopaque lines through the metaphysis of the bone. The radiopaque line of stress fracture is broader, with a hazy, ill-defined margin to its edge. In addition, growth arrest lines are usually found in other bones as bilateral, symmetrical, well-defined radiopaque bands.
NON-ACCIDENTAL TRAUMA OF CHILDHOOD
A number of terms have been applied to encompass the controversial topic of childhood injuries from abuse. Caffey (1), in 1946, was the first to describe multiple fractures in the long bones of patients who were suffering from subdural hematomas, and he coined the phrase parent-infant traumatic stress syndrome, while Guthkelch, a British neurosurgeon, was first to attribute the subdural hematomas as the result of the shaking. (2) The term battered child syndrome was offered by Kempe et al. (3) in 1962 and stimulated public debate. In 1974 Caffey again contributed the name whiplash shaken infant syndrome. (2) Other descriptions include infant abuse syndrome, shaken infant syndrome, and, more recently, non-accidental trauma (NAT) of children. Usually, those who inflict the injuries are parents or guardians.
The hallmark of this syndrome is clinical and radiologic evidence of repeated injury. (4) Clinically, multiple bruises or burns of varying degrees of severity are the usual findings. The history is often incompatible with the observed injuries. In infants between the age of 1 month and 1 year, NAT is currently the leading cause of death. (5) Unsuspected fractures are uncommon over the age of 2, while children older than 5 rarely sustain a fracture
P.928

from abuse. (6) Up to 80% of fractures in abused children occur under the age of 18 months. (7) This contrasts with non-abused children, in whom 85% of fractures occur over the age of 5.
A number of imaging findings have been described. The shaken infant syndrome (whiplash shaking syndrome) includes injuries incurred as sequelae to vigorous shaking while clutching the chest. (8) In most instances the child’s head is turned, causing a rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. (9) The average age of presentation is about 6 months. (9) Injuries include retinal hemorrhages, subdural hemorrhages, cerebral edema, and skull fractures. (10) Subdural blood from hemorrhaging is most commonly located in the subtemporal area, which warrants careful CT and MRI inspection. (9) Abused children often reveal a high incidence of disability, including cognitive and motor abilities. (10,11,12,13)
A spectrum of skeletal injuries may be observed. (14,15) In long bones the key findings are fractures in varying stages of healing, multiple closely approximated fractures, metaphyseal corner fractures, epiphyseal displacements, and exuberant periosteal new bone. (16) (Table 9-20) The key to the radiographic diagnosis is the demonstration of multiple fractures at varying stages of healing. (1,4) Quite often, a fresh fracture may be seen next to a callused, deformed bone.
Table 9-20 Radiologic Features of Non-Accidental Trauma in Children

Fractures in different stages of healing

Multiple closely approximated fractures

Metaphyseal corner fractures

Epiphyseal displacements

Exuberant periosteal new bone
Figure 9-233 NON-ACCIDENTAL TRAUMA OF CHILDHOOD: MULTIPLE FRACTURES OF THE SHOULDER. Note the recent fracture of the mid-diaphysis of the humerus. A fracture of older origin is present in the distal aspect of the clavicle, with exuberant callus formation (arrow). COMMENT: The key to the radiographic diagnosis of battered child syndrome is the demonstration of multiple fractures at varying stages of healing, as is seen in this case. The classic radiographic signs are fractures in the corners of the metaphyses, with or without associated epiphyseal displacement, and exuberant periosteal new bone formation along the diaphyses and metadiaphysis of the long bones.
Figure 9-234 NON-ACCIDENTAL TRAUMA OF CHILDHOOD: THIGH. Observe that extensive hemorrhage has lifted the periosteum, creating large, wavy periosteal new bone formation. Note the corner fracture identified on this femoral radiograph (arrow).
Figure 9-235 NON-ACCIDENTAL TRAUMA OF CHILDHOOD: CORNER FRACTURE. A. AP Knee. Observe the characteristic corner fracture affecting the medial aspect of the metaphysis of the distal femur (arrow). B. Lateral Knee. Note multiple fracture fragments of the distal metaphysis of the femur (arrows).
P.929

Other common sites involved with NAT are the ribs, skull, clavicle, and scapula. (17,18) Spinal fractures are uncommon. Because many of these children are severely shaken while held by their arms, bilateral humeral fractures are also common. (Fig. 9-233)
The classic radiographic sign is fractures of the corners of the metaphyses with or without associated epiphyseal displacement (corner fractures). (4,19) (Fig. 9-234) Corner fractures usually are observed around the knee, especially at the medial aspect of the metaphysis of the distal femur. (Fig. 9-235) These lesions represent avulsion microfractures from the immature metaphysis from traction of the periosteum. (8,19) Separation of the metaphysis in a circumferential manner is called a bucket-handle fracture. Such metaphyseal lesions often provide the initial clue to suspicion of abuse. The cluster of radiologic findings that has a high degree of specificity in child abuse includes these metaphyseal lesions (corner fractures), posterior rib, scapular, spine, and sternal fractures. (8,20) Spinal fractures include vertebral body compression, spinous process avulsions, hangman’s, and odontoid synchondrosis fractures. (8,21)
Other conditions such as infantile cortical hyperostosis, congenital syphilis, scurvy, and osteogenesis imperfecta may be considered in the differential diagnosis. (22,23) In general, they are readily excluded by clinical and radiographic signs.
Imaging of suspected child abuse requires meticulous technique and detail. A skeletal survey should include AP and lateral chest, AP humerii and forearms, PA hands, AP pelvis, lateral lumbar spine, AP femora, tibiae, feet, and AP and lateral skull. (8,21,24) All positive sites should be viewed by at least two projections. Repeat imaging in 7-10 days may provide evidence for fracture healing not apparent on the initial study. Bone scan may be useful in difficult cases. CT and MRI of the head and spine in children with neurological abnormality should be performed. (25,26,27)
Figure 9-236 POST-TRAUMATIC MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: ELBOWS. A and B. Bilateral Lateral Elbows. Note the large ossified masses anterior to the distal humerus, which represent post-traumatic ossificans (arrows). COMMENT: The brachialis anterior is the most common muscle involved in the area of the elbow.
POST-TRAUMATIC MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS
Post-traumatic myositis ossificans (myositis ossificans post-traumatica, ossifying hematoma, traumatic ossifying myositis, or heterotopic posttraumatic bone formation) is a condition characterized by heterotopic bone formation in the soft tissues following trauma. The process occurs most often in muscle but may also occur in fascia, tendons, joint capsules, and ligaments. Most occur after any local injury sufficient to cause bruising of the muscle or a frank hemorrhage within it. (1) The most common sites are the brachialis anterior (elbow), quadriceps femoris (thigh), adductor muscles of the thigh, medial collateral ligament of the knee (Pellegrini-Stieda disease), and in cases of rupture of the coracoclavicular ligament of the shoulder. (2,3) (Figs. 9-236, 9-237 and 9-238) Other lesser-known sites are the deltoid in foot soldiers, owing to the trauma caused by carrying a rifle. The constant pressure of the saddle against the adductors in riders may cause ossification in the adductor magnus and is known as Prussian’s disease or, erroneously, as a saddle tumor. (Fig. 9-239) Bedridden and wheelchair-confined patients frequently produce heterotopic bone at areas of gravitational stress, most commonly found at the ischial tuberosities. (Fig. 9-240) Up to 50% of paraplegics and quadriplegics exhibit paravertebral ossification (4). Rarely, traumatic myositis ossificans will occur in the paraspinal region of the cervical spine. (5)
Lumbar Ossified Bridge Syndrome.
Hematoma within the psoas muscle may ossify and produce complete or incomplete bony union between two or more lumbar transverse processes. (6) (Fig. 9-241) The bony bar consists of mature osseous tissue with cortex and medullary bone and contains marrow. (7) Removal of the bony bridge in symptomatic cases may relieve a pain syndrome. (7)
P.930

Figure 9-237 POST-TRAUMATIC MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: ANTERIOR THIGH. Note the wavy, ossific density in the anterior thigh involving the quadriceps femoris (arrows). (Courtesy of Mark J. Lieffring, DC, Cloquet, Minnesota.)
Figure 9-238 MEDIAL COLLATERAL LIGAMENT OSSIFICATION. Observe the ossification in the area of the medial collateral ligament following avulsion (arrow). This has been referred to as Pellegrini-Stieda disease. (Courtesy of James R. Brandt, DC, MSc, DABCO, Coon Rapids, Minnesota.)
Figure 9-239 MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: PRUSSIAN’S DISEASE. AP Femur. Observe the large, well-organized ossifying hematoma in the adductor magnus muscle (arrows). Observe the dense cortical margin, with a relatively radiolucent center. COMMENT: This has been referred to as Prussian’s disease and is the result of the constant pressure of the saddle against the adductor muscles, which were found frequently in Prussian soldiers who were horseback riders.
Ossification of the Achilles Tendon.
The most common cause of ossification of the Achilles tendon is surgery; trauma is the second most common cause. Additional causes include diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, fluorosis, ochronosis, Wilson’s disease, renal failure, Reiter’s syndrome, gout, and ankylosing spondylitis. (8) The ossific mass lies within the tendon and consists of mature bone containing marrow and may fracture. (Fig. 9-242)
Cortical Irregularity Syndrome.
Young adults may show roughening of the posterior femoral surface, which has been previously described as a periosteal desmoid. (Fig. 9-243) It represents chronic or previous tearing of the musculotendinous insertion along the distal linea aspera. The condition is commonly confused with osteosarcoma, which can be excluded on the basis of location, appearance, and a failure to show underlying marrow disease on bone scan or MRI.
Pathologic Features
The pathologic process can be divided into three stages: pseudo-sarcoma, differentiation, and maturation.
Stage One: Pseudo-Sarcoma
The process of myositis ossificans is usually initiated with blunt trauma that precipitates contusion from torn or crushed muscular
P.931

tissue. Normally, scar formation is the natural response; however, owing to an unknown cause, cell death and metaplastia precipitates the process of myositis ossificans. Histologically, the sarcolemmal sheath begins to degenerate, allowing fluid and phagocytes to invade and further compromise the tissues. Dilation of the capillary beds produces the classical symptoms of heat, swelling, and tenderness. With an increase of exudate accumulation in the center of the traumatized tissue, liquefaction of the tissues is not uncommon. This induces a transient inflammatory infiltrate (myositis). Close inspection reveals replacement of the injured tissues with non-specific cells. (9)
Figure 9-240 POST-TRAUMATIC MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: PARAPLEGIA. Note the ossifying hematomas below both ischial tuberosities (arrows). These represent sites of myositis ossificans post-traumatica in a non-ambulatory patient restricted to a wheelchair. It occurred as a result of constant mechanical pressure on the soft tissues. Because of the lack of activity and urinary stasis, multiple bladder calculi have developed (arrowheads). These may be differentiated from phleboliths by the lack of a radiolucent center (crossed arrow).
Figure 9-241 MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: LUMBAR SPINE. AP Pelvis. Observe the exuberant bridging ossification between the lumbar transverse processes (arrow). There is evidence of pseudo-joint formation (arrowhead). COMMENT: This pattern of ossification may follow trauma or sudden paraplegia and has been referred to as lumbar ossified bridge syndrome. (Courtesy of Joseph W. Howe, DC, DACBR, FACCR, Los Angeles, California.)
Figure 9-242 MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: ACHILLES TENDON. Lateral Ankle. Note the ossification of a large hematoma within the Achilles tendon (arrows). This is sometimes associated with rupture of the tendon.
P.932

Figure 9-243 CORTICAL IRREGULARITY SYNDROME (MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS). A. Lateral Knee. Observe the solid, wavy periosteal new bone formation along the posterior surface of the distal femoral metaphysis (arrow). B. Bone Scan, Bilateral Knee. Observe the small area of abnormal radiopharmaceutical uptake within the left distal femur (arrows). C. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Knee. Note the eccentric, homogeneous, low signal intensity mass on the posterior surface of the femur (arrow). This region is well encapsulated and is suggestive of a benign process. D. T2-Weighted MRI, Axial Knee. Note that the cortical outline (arrow) is clearly defined and encloses the high signal intensity hemorrhagic edema. These findings are consistent with cortical irregularity syndrome, a condition resulting from traumatic periostitis. COMMENT: A presumptive diagnosis of osteosarcoma was initially made and the patient was scheduled for a biopsy. MRI confirms a fluid signal intensity with no underlying marrow abnormality in the distal femur. (Courtesy of Frank Sivo, DC, North Miami, Florida.)
In the absence of further injury, either from patient activity or overaggressive rehabilitative measures, this degenerative process continues for approximately 2 weeks. Within the next month, extensive proliferation of all mesenchymal cell types occur. This may erroneously resemble neoplasia with histologic analysis. The proper diagnosis at this stage requires a high index of suspicion, which is obtained during the patient history. Identification
P.933

of past trauma within the appropriate time frame is the key. (9)
Stage Two: Differentiation
Gradually, giant cells migrate toward the lesion to clean the area of the necrotic tissue, and the mesenchymal cells begin to differentiate into fibroblasts, osteoblasts, and chondroblasts. It is at this stage that the identification and deposition of osteoid tissue is first noted. Owing to the lack of sufficient blood supply, most of the necrotic cells undergo liquefactive necrosis and resorption. Histologically, this event may cause the area to fill with sheets of non-specific cells or develop into a cyst filled with fluid. (9)
Owing to central necrosis, damage at the periphery of the lesion is less, leading to more rapid and efficient repair in this area. Analysis of the lesion during this stage will reveal peripheral mineralization and subsequent mature ossification to trabecular bone. Ossification becomes progressively less differentiated toward the zones in the central portion. This phenomenon provides the first accurate indication that the lesion is not neoplastic in nature. This “zoning” is characteristic for myositis ossificans and distinguishes it from neoplasms in which the best-differentiated portions are in the center of the lesion. (9)
Stage Three: Maturation
With maturation and complete removal of the necrotic debris, the lesion shrinks in size, and the formation of a central cystic cavity is not uncommon. At the periphery, a periosteum is formed as the bone becomes heavier and more developed. Eventually, stability and reduced activity is noted. With time, smaller lesions have been noted to spontaneously regress from osteoclastic resorption; however, larger or persistent lesions may require surgical removal. Surgery should be performed only after the development of the periosteum to ensure stability and containment of the lesion. The removal of an immature lesion has been associated with an increased risk of recurrence. Aesthetically, the muscle will appear normal after the disappearance of the lesion, whether surgical or spontaneous. (9) In every case some degree of functional loss to the involved muscle should be expected. (10) Before removal, the ossification has rarely been seen to fracture or transform to an extraskeletal osteosarcoma (malignant degeneration). (11,12,13)
Radiologic Features
The ossifying hematoma may be visible radiographically within 3-4 weeks after the initial injury. (1,8) MRI may show the intramuscular hematoma from an early stage. (14) (Fig. 9-244) Initially, the roentgen appearance is a fine, lacy radiopacity, which is followed later by a cloudy ossification within a well-defined mass. Its size depends on the degree of initial trauma and the overall size of the hematoma. Eventually, sequential studies demonstrate a bony mass that is radiopaque in its peripheral margins, with the center of the lesion appearing relatively radiolucent. (Fig. 9-239) The bony mass usually measures 4-5 cm but may be as large as 25 cm. The soft tissue osseous mass distinctively has no direct connection with the closest bone. (Table 9-21)
Radiologic diagnosis is essential because biopsy of this mass in its early stages may show what would appear to be a sarcomatous change centrally. A radiologic sign important in making the distinction between this and a bone neoplasm is the characteristic lucent zone (cleavage plane) between the calcified mass and the subadjacent cortex. (15,16) The mass is usually located adjacent to the diaphysis of a tubular bone, but the cortex of the bone is intact. Other important confirmatory properties are a dense periphery with a more lucent center and a decrease in volume with time. (Figs. 9-245 and 9-246) Increased uptake of bone-seeking radionuclide may be noted, which diminishes with maturity and inactivity of the lesion. (17)
Figure 9-244 INTRAMUSCULAR HEMATOMA. Proton Density-Weighted MRI, Coronal Femora. Observe the prominent heterogeneous increased signal intensity region within the vastus lateralis muscle (arrow). This finding is consistent with post-traumatic hematoma. (Courtesy of Kenneth B. Heithoff, MD, Minneapolis, Minnesota.)
Table 9-21 Radiologic Features of Post-Traumatic Myositis Ossificans

Early features

Hazy soft tissue mass

Cloudy ossification

Later features

Round or linear

Smooth, dense, outer border

Relatively lucent center

No connection with adjacent bone
Differential Diagnosis
The differentiation of myositis ossificans from many soft tissue and bone malignancies is often difficult. (18) Extraskeletal sarcoma may be difficult to differentiate and is a rare condition that tends to occur in older adults. Synovioma, in one third of cases,
P.934

may calcify and can be located remote from the joint owing to its association with tendon sheaths; therefore, this tumor must be given consideration when evaluating a calcified soft tissue mass. A parosteal sarcoma may have a similar appearance, but no lucent zone between it and the diaphysis should be visible. Other soft tissue calcifications such as tumoral calcinosis may present as a densely calcified mass but have an amorphous calcific rather than maturely ossific nature. (19)
Figure 9-245 PSEUDO-SARCOMA APPEARANCE OF POST-TRAUMATICA MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS. A. Proximal Thigh. Note the large soft tissue mass adjacent to the proximal femur. Observe the dense peripheral cortical rim, with a more radiolucent center, which suggests myositis ossificans rather than sarcoma. A clearly defined margin between the soft tissue mass and the cortex of the femur aids in the differential diagnosis (arrows). B. Proximal Thigh. Observe a similar lesion, though it appears less confluent (arrows). COMMENT: Heat was placed on the injury, which probably has not assisted in preventing myositis ossificans from developing. (Courtesy of John J. Danchik, DC, CCSP, Belmont, Massachusetts.)
Figure 9-246 POST-TRAUMATIC MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: THIGH. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thigh. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Thigh. Observe the elongated soft tissue mass present in the anterior aspect of the thigh, representing an organized hematoma. Its dense peripheral margins with a more lucent center is characteristic of post-traumatic myositis ossificans.
P.935

Table 9-22 Named and Eponymic Fractures: General Terms

Fracture

Description

Avulsion

Separated bone fragment from a muscle, tendon, or ligament

Butterfly fragment

Isolated triangular-shaped cortical fragment in a comminuted fracture

Banana-like fracture

Transverse pathologic fracture through a bone affected with Paget’s disease

Chip (corner) fracture

A small bone fragment originating from a joint margin

Closed fracture

Fracture does not penetrate the skin

Comminuted fracture

Two or more bony fragments

Diastatic fracture

Separation of a partly movable joint

Impaction fracture

Trabecular telescoping

Depressed

Inward bulging of the outer cortex

Compression

Decreased bone size owing to trabecular telescoping

Incomplete fracture

Fracture extends only partially across the bone

Greenstick

Buckled trabeculae

Torus

Buckled trabeculae with a cortical bulge

Infraction fracture

A small impaction fracture

Insufficiency fracture

Stress fracture through diseased bone

Oblique fracture

Fracture line at 45° to the long axis

Occult fracture

A subtle, unidentifiable fracture, usually seen on follow-up x-rays 7-10 days after trauma

Open fracture

Fracture penetrates the skin

Pathologic fracture

Fracture through diseased bone

Post-traumatic arthritis

Secondary degenerative joint disease owing to altered joint mechanics after trauma

Pseudo-arthrosis

Residual motion between fracture fragments, creating a false joint

Pseudofracture

An incomplete pathologic fracture-like defect

Salter-Harris classification

Growth plate injuries

Spiral fracture

Fracture line bends circumferentially and longitudinally along the bone

Stress (fatigue) fracture

Microfracture owing to repetitive stress

Thurston-Holland fragment

Metaphyseal fragment in a Salter-Harris type II epiphyseal injury

Transverse fracture

Fracture line at 90° to the long axis
Table 9-23 Named and Eponymic Fractures: Skull and Facial Bones

Fracture

Description

Blowout fracture

Fracture through the infraorbital plate

Diastatic fracture

Fracture with separation of a suture

Growing fracture

Widening of the sutural space owing to leptomeningeal cyst

Le Fort 1-3 fracture

Facial bone fracture or separations

Ping Pong fracture

A depressed skull fracture in a child

Stellate fracture

A depressed skull fracture with lines radiating from its center

Tripod fracture

Three fractures through the zygomatic arch, orbital and maxillary processes
SUMMARY TABLES
This chapter ends with a tabulated compilation of named fractures and their eponyms (Tables 9-22, 9-23, 9-24, 9-25, 9-26, 9-27, 9-28, 9-29, 9-30, 9-31, 9-32, 9-33 and 9-34), named radiologic signs associated with trauma (Table 9-35), and the most common fracture sites. (Table 9-36)
Table 9-24 Named and Eponymic Fractures: Cervical Spine

Fracture

Description

Burst fracture of the atlas

Synonym for Jefferson’s fracture

Burst fracture of the body

Comminuted vertebral body fracture

Carrot stick fracture

Fracture through the ankylosed discovertebral junction in ankylosing spondylitis

Clay shoveler’s fracture

Avulsion of a lower cervical segment spinous process

Coalminer’s fracture

Synonym for clay shoveler’s fracture

Hangman’s fracture (hangee’s fracture)

Jefferson’s fracture

Fractured anterior and posterior arch of the atlas

Pillar fracture

Fractured articular pillar

Teardrop fracture

A displaced, triangular fragment from the anteroinferior body corner

Traumatic spondylolisthesis

Synonym for hangman’s fracture

Wedge fracture

Compressed anterior vertebral body fracture

Description

Chance fracture (seat belt fracture)

Horizontal fracture through a single body and posterior arch
